Synthesis and Structure of Semirigid Tetracarboxylate Copper(II) Porous Coordination Polymers and Their Versatile High-Efficiency Catalytic Dye Degradation in Neutral Aqueous Solution

    Synthesis and Structure of Semirigid Tetracarboxylate Copper(II) Porous Coordination Polymers and Their Versatile High-Efficiency Catalytic Dye Degradation in Neutral Aqueous Solution

    • Chunkai Wang
      • , 
    • Feifei Xing
      • , 
    • Yue-Ling Bai
      • , 
    • Yongmei Zhao
      • , 
    • Ming-Xing Li
      • , and 
    • Shourong Zhu*
    View Author Information
    Innovative Drug Center, Department of Chemistry, College of Science, Shanghai University, Shanghai 200444, China
    *E-mail: shourongzhu@shu.edu.cn. Fax: +86-21-66134594.
    Cite this: Cryst. Growth Des. 2016, 16, 4, 2277–2288
    Publication Date (Web):March 9, 2016

    Publication History

    • Revised26 February 2016

    • Published inissue 6 April 2016

    PDF (7 MB)
    Supporting Info (1)»Supporting Information Supporting Information
    SUBJECTS:
    • Dyes and pigments,
    Crystal Growth & Design
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Three porous Cu(II) coordination polymers {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3n (1), {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)5]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3n (2), {[Cu5(μ8-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3n (3), where KH3L1 and H4L2 are semirigid 3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid and 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid, respectively, were synthesized solvothermally. Their guest-accessible voids are 36%, 59%, and 39% in 1, 2, and 3, respectively. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) dyes in aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics follow v = k[H2O2][RhB], where k = 0.0260 ± 0.001 L·mol–1·min–1 in the presence of 3, while 1 and 2 follow v = [H2O2][RhB]/(1/kK + (1/k)[H2O2]), where K = 5.0 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.057 ± 0.007 min–1 for 1 and K = 4.5 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.083 ± 0.009 min–1 for 2 at pH 7.0. All three catalysts show good catalytic activity in pH 4.8–8 and are essentially constant in this pH range while further increases will decrease catalytic activity. Complexes 1 and 3 exhibited good structural stability in the catalytic process with no discernible catalytic activity decrease after three catalytic cycles. Complex 2 is unstable in the catalytic process. MS data show that the slow catalyst 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylate. Faster 1 further degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylate, while fastest 2 not only degrades RhB, but also the catalyst itself. These catalysts not only degrade RhB but also methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II. Azo dye orange II was oxidized into red nitrosobenzene and then degraded nitrisobenzene into colorless species. Complex 1 has the advantage of good catalytic activity, stability, and availability. Along with ease of recovery, it will be useful in practical applications.

    Synopsis

    Three porous coordination polymers were synthesized. Their porosity varies from 36 to 59%. All three can effectively catalytically oxidize organic dyes in the presence of H2O2 in neutral aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics was studied, and the mechanism and products were proposed.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    In recent years, porous coordination polymers (PCPs),(1) also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have attracted much attention owing to their potential applications in various fields such as catalysis,(2) luminescence,(3) gas storage(4) and separation,(5) ion exchange,(6) toxic gas removal,(7) topological insulators,(8) and magnetism.(9) To date, rational design and synthesis of PCPs with the expected structure and properties still face many difficulties since organic ligands, metallic ions, solvents, reaction temperature, and counterions, etc., may easily affect the structure of PCPs.(10) The greatest advantage of PCPs over other porous materials is their chemical versatility thanks to their chemical composition of metal cations and organic linkers.(2b) Combining appropriate metal cations and organic linkers leads to the formation of open metal sites, which may act as catalyst sites.(2a) If some open metal sites can be produced in PCP frameworks together with their wide range of pore sizes, shapes, and dimensionality, these sites will be very useful as solid catalysts with high activity and/or high selectivity.(11)
    Currently, catalysts are used to eliminate organic compounds or harmful pollutants in green technologies.(12) Organic dyes, especially azo dyes, as raw materials are widely used in solar cells, imaging biological samples, pharmaceuticals, traditional textiles, and other industries.(13) The uncontrolled discharge of azo dyes into the environment is alarming due to their toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic characteristics as well as their transformation products.(13c) Catalytic degradation is an effective means of eliminating dyes effluents.(14) Since the discovery of photocatalytic splitting of water on TiO2 electrodes by Honda and Fujishima,(15) traditional semiconductor-based photocatalysis, using semiconductors such as TiO2,(16) WO3,(17) and ZnO,(18) was used to eliminate organic contaminants.(19) Researchers have sought new high-efficiency catalytic materials for environmental protection. PCPs have received much more attention, not only for their intriguing topological variety but also for their potential applications such as a catalyst.(2a) However, although many PCP-based catalysts were reported,(20) oxidation kinetics, mechanisms, and possible products remained largely unexplored.(11) In this work, three 3D (superscript 3 indicates 3D) porous coordination polymers, {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3n (1), {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)5]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3n (2), {[Cu5(μ8-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3n (3), constructed using 3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid(21) and 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid,(22) and copper(II) ions were reported. Their structures are characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG, XRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Their heterogeneous catalytic oxidation activities toward rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) in the presence of H2O2 were also investigated in aqueous solution. Reaction kinetics, possible mechanism, and products were explored.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Materials and Methods

    All chemicals were of reagent-grade quality, obtained from commercial sources, and were used as received without further purification. C, H, and N analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in 400–4000 cm–1 range. Powder X-ray diffractions were measured at a scanning rate of 5° min–1 on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGAs) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in air. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Pgeneral TU-1900 spectrometer. ESI mass spectra were performed on a Shimadzu LCMS-2020 instrument.

    Syntheses of {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3n (1)

    A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (17.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), KH3L1 (16.9 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (6 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was heated at 80 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Blue prism crystals of were obtained in 55% yield based on KH3L1. Anal. Calcd for C70H98O62N3KCu7 (%): C, 34.46; H, 3.47; N, 1.72. Found: C, 34.48; H, 3.50; N, 1.70. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3367m, 1630s, 1561s, 1455s, 1398s, 1251m, 1105w, 1008m, 911w, 772s, 728w, 704w, 503w.

    {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)5]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3n (2)

    Complex 2 was synthesized identically as 1 except in an open vial at 85 °C for 16 h. Blue brick crystals of were obtained in 52% yield based on KH3L1. Anal. Calcd for C45.5H91.5O47.5N4.5Cu5 (%): C, 31.16; H, 4.90; N, 3.58. Found: C, 31.21; H, 4.88; N, 3.53. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3405m, 1625m, 1570s, 1453m, 1399s, 1377s, 1250m, 1116w, 1009m, 926w, 772m, 729m, 703w.

    {[Cu5(μ7-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3n (3)

    A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (36.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4L2 (17.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (6 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was heated at 100 °C for 72 h (higher than in 1 and 2) and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1. Blue prism crystals of were obtained in 48% yield based on H4L2. Anal. Calcd for C35H50O35.5NCu5 (%): C, 30.67; H, 3.67; N, 1.02. Found: C, 30.72; H, 3.65; N, 1.08. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3413m, 3073w, 1614w, 1567s, 1457m, 1386s, 1266m, 1220m, 1161m, 1076w, 985s, 800m,728m.

    X-ray Crystallographic Study

    Well-shaped single crystals of 1–3 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. Data collections were performed with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXTL program.(23) All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their ideal position if possible. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table S1, Supporting Information.

    Catalytic Activity

    The catalytic activities of these as-synthesized single-crystalline PCPs, namely, 1, 2, and 3, were evaluated by catalysis degradation of RhB, MB, ST, and OII aqueous solution at room temperature. The dyes were dissolved in distilled water. A typical experiment of degradation was carried out as follows: 10 mg of catalyst (1, 2, and 3, respectively) was mixed together with 10 mL of 8 ppm RhB aqueous solution in the presence of 30% H2O2 in a 15 mL glass bottle by shaking in an oscillator continuously for 120 min. The clear solution was transferred to a 1 cm quartz cell to measure UV–vis spectra from 320 to 800 nm on a Pgeneral TU-1900 UV–vis spectrometer (stray light < 0.01%; wavelength accuracy, 0.3 nm) every 15 min within 2 h. Pure water was used as reference in all experiments. Solution without catalyst and solution without H2O2 were also measured as control experiments to estimate degradation of the binary system and possible dye adsorption. The experiments were performed at room temperature, and the pH was adjusted by dropwise addition of 0.1 mol/L muriatic acid or potassium hydroxide as required. Without adjusting pH, all dye solutions have pH ∼ 5.0.
    Table 1. Crystallographic Data and Structure Refinement for Complexes 1–3

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Synthesis and Infrared Spectra

    Blue crystals of 1–3 were solvothermally synthesized by the reactions of CuCl2·2H2O with KH3L1 (3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand or H4L2 (4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand in well-sealed DMF–H2O mixture except in synthesis of complex 2. The molar ratio of CuCl2·2H2O and KH3L1 was kept in 1:2 in the preparation of 1 and 2. The reaction temperature was changed from 85 °C for 1 to 80 °C for 2. In the synthesis of 3, the metal to ligand ratio was 4:1 and the temperature was 100 °C, which was higher than that in the syntheses of 1 and 2. Although 1 and 2 were synthesized essentially the same, their formulas differ greatly. Subtle change reaction conditions make a great difference. In the sealed vial, there are dimetylammonium cation in 1, which is due to partial decomposition of solvent DMF, while, in the open vial, none of this volatile base exists in 2. Coordinated OH– exists in all three polymers. There are potassium cations in 1, which are proved by precipitation in the presence of tetraphenylboron sodium (Figure S1).
    These two ligands, L1 and L2, are isomers, and 2 and 3 have quite similar formulas. However, 2 contains more lattice DMF and water molecules, which is mainly due to higher reaction temperature in the synthesis of 3. The IR spectra of complexes 1–3 show characteristic bands of the coordinated carboxylate groups at 1630, 1561; 1625, 1570; and 1617, 1567 cm–1 for C═O asymmetric stretching vibrations, respectively (Figure S2). The 1630 cm–1 (in 1) is larger than 1625 cm–1 (in 2) (Figure S2 and Scheme 1). The absorption bands at 1398, 1399, and 1389 cm–1 are attributed to the symmetric stretching vibrations of the coordinated carboxylate groups for 1–3, respectively.(24) PXRD (Figure S3) proves the phase purity of these polymers.

    Description of Crystal Structures

    {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3n (1)

    The crystal structures of 1 are shown in Figure 1. The asymmetric unit of {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3n contains four different metal ions, Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4; one K1; two L14– ligands (in orange and yellow color, Figure 1a) that both adopt η7μ7–η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination modes (Scheme 1); three coordinating water molecules; and a bridging OH– group (O4W). [(CH3)2NH2]+ exists in the outer sphere to balance the charge. The ligand in orange links six Cu(II) and a K ion, while the yellow one links seven Cu(II) ions. The two ligands although both η7μ7 mode, differ in coordination mode (Scheme 1). Cu1 is pentacoordinated by four monodentated carboxyl groups and one coordinated water molecule to form a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.21 for Cu1). The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O5, O11, and O15 atoms. The axial positions are occupied by O1W atom with an O1W–Cu1–O1 bond angle of 97.9(2)°. The Cu1–O1, Cu1–O5, Cu1–O11, Cu1O15, and Cu1–O1W bond distances are 2.003 (3), 1.925 (3), 1.931(3), 1.998(4), and 2.160(5) Å, respectively. Cu2 is also in a distorted square pyramidal geometry, coordinated by four monodentate carboxyl oxygen and one coordinated water (τ = 0.22 for Cu2). The Cu2–O bond distances vary from 1.932(3) to 2.141(4) Å. Unlike the square paddle-wheel Cu1 and Cu2, Cu3 is quadricoordinated by the monodentating carboxyl group of two L14– ligands and two coordinated water molecules to complete a square planar geometry. The Cu3–O16 and Cu3–O3W bond distances are 1.911(6), 1.937(9) Å, respectively. Cu4 is five-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygens from four different L14– ligands and one μ2-OH anion (O4W), forming a distorted square pyramidal geometry with a τ value of 0.159. The square plane is formed by the coordination of O3, O7, O12, and O4W atoms. The apical positions are occupied by O13 atoms with O7–Cu4–O13 bond angle of 92.89(15)°. The Cu3–O bond distances vary from 1.911(6) to 1.937(9) Å. The dihedral angles between phenyl rings were 77.871°and 79.042° in orange and yellow colored ligand (Figure 1a), respectively. Cu1 and Cu2 ions are bridged by four L14– ligands to form a propeller-shaped configuration.
    In both ligands, the carboxylate in the m-phthalate are almost co-planar to the benzene ring (<20°), while, in the o-phthalate, the carboxylate adjacent to the phenol oxygen is almost perpendicular to the benzene ring (70°–80°).
    The complex packs into the 3D structure as shown in Figure 1b,c. For clarity, Cu1Cu2 paddle wheel is a deep-blue ball, 2Cu4 is simplified in yellow balls. Each ligand (O9 andO18) is a four-link node. Cu3 links two ligands; the paddle-wheel Cu1Cu2 (deep blue) links four ligands, while Cu4 dinuclear center (yellow ball) links six ligands. As shown in Figure 1b, there are cavities in the c-axis. The full structure of the cavity is illustrated in Figure 1e,f. In the cavity, adjacent Cu3 have distances of 10.40 Å. This distance is comparable with some dye molecules such as rhodamine and so on. Cu3 has lower coordination number, labile water molecules, and guest-accessible voids; this ion may be a catalytic center. Platon(25) calculation shows this complex has a guest-accessible void of 36.5% after removal of lattice water molecule and the dimethylamine.

    Structure of {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)5]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3n (2)

    The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of six different Cu(II) ions. L14– ligands adopt a η8μ8–η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode (Scheme 1). All of the carboxylates are in 1,3-bridging modes. Cu3 and Cu4 both have occupancies of 1/4, while the other four Cu(II) ions have occupancies of 1/2. Three coordinated water molecules (monodentate) and a μ3-OH group (O7W) are also in the inner sphere of complex 2 (Figure 2a). There are 4.5 DMF molecules and 18 lattice water molecules in the outer sphere. As illustrated in Figure 2b, Cu2 coordinated with two carboxylates O2 and water oxygen O2W and O7W to form essentially square planar geometry. All other Cu(II) ions coordinate in square pyramids. Cu1 and Cu2 are linked via O1–C13–O2 (CO2–) and μ3-OH– to form butterfly Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4 coordination structures (Figure 2b).
    Cu3, Cu4 and Cu5, Cu6 exhibit a propeller-shaped configuration (Figure 2a). All Cu ions are surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from four different L14– ligands and one coordinated water molecule. The intermetallic distances between Cu3···Cu4 and Cu5···Cu6 are 2.652(2) and 2.653(2) Å, respectively. While in the μ3-OH (O7W) bridged butterfly structure, Cu···Cu distances are 3.281(3) and 2.977(2) Å for Cu1···Cu2 and Cu1···Cu1, respectively. The Cu2···Cu2 distance is 4.925(3) Å.
    The carboxylates are almost co-planar to the benzene rings they attached to except the o-carboxylate in the phthalate moiety, which are identical to that in 1. The complex packs into a 3D structure which is illustrated in Figure 2c,d. For simplicity, the ligand is presented as O9, which is a four-linked node (Figure 2a). (Cu1Cu2)2 is simplified as large blue balls, which link four ligands as shown in Figure 2b–d. In the most simplified structure (Figure 2c, 2d), not only ligands (O9) but also the paddle-wheel 2Cu centers, as well as the (Cu1Cu2)2, are all four-linked nodes. Interestingly, there are two different cavities in 2. One is a hydrophilic cavity (yellow ball, Figure 2e) surrounded by eight ligands via the phthalate carboxylate with a cavity diameter of 9 Å (Cu1···Cu1, 9.34 Å; Figure 2e). The hydrophilic properties arise from the two paddle-wheel Cu3Cu4 and two butterfly Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4. The other cavity is hydrophobic (blue ball, Figure 2f). The Cu···Cu distances in the hydrophobic cavity varies from 8.12 to 19.67 Å. The solvent-accessible volume (after removal lattice solvents) is estimated to be 59.3% by PLATON.

    Structure of {[Cu5(μ7-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3n (3)

    Complex 3 is quite similar to literature reported {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O}n.(22) Clearly, the formulas differ in lattice DMF and water molecules. The difference between these two complexes is mainly due to reaction temperature. Our synthesizing temperature is 100 °C rather than literature’s 130 °C. The coordination geometry is almost identical except for more accurate bond distances and lower R indices. Due to the existence of DMF and more lattice water molecules, the cell volume is 1280.6(3) Å3, which is 0.79% larger than 1270.95(11) Å3 in {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O}n.
    The formulas of 3 and 2 are quite similar. Complex 3 differs from 2 in the following aspects: there are only three different Cu(II) ions rather than six in 2; there is no paddle-wheel dinuclear Cu(II) in 3; and although there are tetranuclear Cu(II) clusters, the coordination environment/configuration is different from the tetranuclear cluster in 2. First of all, the tetranuclear clusters in 3 are all five-coordinated (τ = 0.24 and 0.39 for Cu1 and Cu2, respectively) rather than a combination of four and five in 2. The Cu2 ions are trans to each other rather than in the cis butterfly in 2. With a higher number and fewer water molecules, the tetranuclear cluster is linked via six 1,3-coordination carboxylates to form Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 rather than four 1,3-coordination carboxylates in Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4 in 2.
    Figure 3b is the 3D structure of 3. There are cavities in 3. Platon calculation gives 38.9% voids after removal of lattice solvents, which is considerably less than 59.3% in 2. This can be explained by the larger cell volume of 2, which is 1.4 times the volume of 3. The cavity has a diameter of ∼1 nm. The Cu2···Cu2 distances in the cavity are 12.18 Å. The m-phthalate links different Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 in the ac plane (Figure 3a,b), while the o-phthalate links Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 and Cu3 in a way shown in Figure 3d. The Cu3···Cu2 distance is 4.388 Å. The topology view clearly shows that the ligand is a four-link node (Figure 3c), while the tetranuclear cluster is a six-link node.
    Thermogravimetric Analysis
    The thermal stabilities of complexes 1–3 were determined in the temperature range of room temperature (RT) ∼ 800 °C (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric curve indicates that 1 released all 24 water molecules and three [(CH3)2NH] in 30–253 °C (found, 20.0%; calcd, 23.1%). The experimental data are 3.1% less than those theoretically calculated, which indicates that 4.23 water molecules were lost before the TGA experiment. The framework then decomposes drastically from 255 to 420 °C. The remaining is 24.4% corresponds to CuO and K2O (calcd, 24.6%). Complex 2 released 23 water molecules and 4.5 DMF in 30–232 °C (found, 37.7%; calcd, 41.8%). Again, 4.05 water molecules volatized before TGA analysis due to very weak binding in the cavity. The 23.9% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 22.3%). For 3, the weight loss of 19.2% could be ascribed to the loss of a free DMF molecule and 14.5 water molecules from 25 to 250 °C (calcd, 24.4%). The 27.3% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 29.0%). The good agreement between theoretical and experimental data indicate all complexes are pure compounds.
    Catalytic Activity
    Organic dyes, especially azo dyes, are ionic, toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic organic compounds which are very stable toward light and oxidation. They are extensively used in industries such as textiles, leather, paper, printing, dyestuff, plastic, and so on.(13a) However, organic dyes such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue, safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) are some of the largest sources of industrial pollutants. Dumping of these compounds leads to algae propagation and eutrophication in bodies of water, and their extensive application generates considerable amounts of wastewater that poses a serious environmental threat. Furthermore, in consideration of their relatively high chemical stability in aqueous solution, removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater is a challenging task to scientists.(11)
    Recently, PCPs were used for degradation of dyes aqueous solutions.(26) The presence of metal clusters consisting of unsaturated coordination sites or loosely bound solvents are often considered as the criterion of a potential catalyst, and the presence of a cavity inside the network further enhances the possibility of catalytic activity.(2a) In the present scenario, 1–3 with different cavities and Cu(II) centers with vacant coordination sites and/or loosely bound water molecules offer a broad scope of study of catalysis. All three compounds have cavities with a cavity size of ∼1 nm and are expected to have some catalytic oxidation activity. The catalytic activities of 1–3 were examined by the degradation of dye in aqueous solution at room temperature (Scheme 2). We chose RhB as a representative to investigate the degradation process in detail (Figure 4). Rhodamine B is one of the more important xanthene dyes. It is a common organic pollutant that exhibits considerably high resistance to photodegradation and oxidative degradation.(27)
    Effect of Dye Concentration
    Before we investigate catalytic oxidation in the presence of H2O2, which is a catalyst–H2O2–dye ternary system, possible reaction in binary systems was run as control experiments. RhB itself is a commonly used dye that is quite stable and difficult to degrade. In the presence of 0.32 M H2O2, 8.0 ppm RhB is also quite stable in pH 4.8–8 (Figure S5). In pH = 9, the degradation cannot be neglected. Without H2O2, there is no fading within 3 h in the presence of 1, 2, or 3 (Figure S6), which indicates that there is no encapsulation. These phenomena indicate that the color fading is exclusively due to catalytic oxidation.
    RhB can easily degrade in the presence of 1–3. Figure 5 is time dependent UV–vis spectra of 8.0 ppm RhB aqueous solution in the presence of 0.32 M H2O2 at pH = 7.0. The intensity of 553 nm peaks gradually decreased with time until they completely disappeared within ∼2 h in the presence of 1 or 2. In the presence of 3, the color bleached completely in 4 h (Figure 4).
    In the experimental condition, H2O2 is in large excess and therefore its concentration is expected to remain constant during the whole process. The reaction kinetic can be expressed as v = k[H2O2]n[dye]m = kobs[dye]m, where kobs = k[H2O2]n. Plot of – ln(At/A0) (where At and A0 are the 553 nm absorbance at times t and 0) vs time gives a straight line (Figure 5 inset). This indicates that the degradation reaction is first order to RhB concentration. The observed first-order rate constants (kobs) are 0.032 ± 0.001, 0.040 ± 0.003, and 0.0150 ± 0.0003 min–1 for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. Complexes 1 and 2 have better catalytic activity than that of 3. The half-life times are 30, 25, and 60 min respectively in the presence of 1, 2, and 3. In addition, it is worth mentioning that the degradation spectra are similar between 1 and 2, but different from 3 as the ∼400 nm absorbance differs greatly. This is a hint that they may have different mechanisms/products.
    In order to prove the industrial practicability of these catalysts, 100 ppm RhB aqueous solution was used instead of 8 ppm. It took 4–8 h to reach complete degradation of RhB in the presence of 1 or 2 (Figure S7). In this high RhB concentration, the activity of 3 is far lower than that of 1 and 2 as the color is still red after 8 h.
    Effect of H2O2 Concentrations
    Dye concentrations have an influence not only on the reaction rate but also on H2O2. The degradation of RhB by 1–3 in different H2O2 concentrations is conducted at pH 4.8. (Figure S8 for complex 3). At each H2O2 concentration, a first-order reaction kobs can be obtained (Figure 6 and Figure S9). A plot of the kobs vs H2O2 concentration gives straight lines in the presence of 3 (Figure S10c). That is, the observed first-order rate constants increase linearly with the increase of H2O2 concentrations in the presence of 3. The second-order rate constant k is 0.0260 ± 0.001 L·mol–1·min–1 in the presence of 3.
    For complexes 1 and 2, the kobs vs [H2O2] plot is not linear. However, the 1/kobs vs 1/[H2O2] line is more linear for 1 and 2 (Figure S10a,b). The fit is 1/kobs = a + b/[H2O2], where a and b are the intercept and slope of the line.
    Rearranging gives(1)This rate law corresponds to the following mechanism:(2)(3)From eq 2(4)From rate determining eq 3(5)(6)where [RhB]0 is the initial concentration.
    If eq 4 is put into eq 6,(7)(8)(9)(10)
    With eq 5 substituted into eq 10,(11)(12)Equation 1 can then be compared with eq 12.
    The intercept a = 1/k, the slope b = 1/kK, and K = a/b.
    This mechanism is similar to homogeneous degradation of orange II dye in the presence of H2O2 at pH 7 catalyzed by Fe(III) complexes of tetraamido macrocyclic ligand (K = k1/k–1 in the pre-equilibrium step).(28) Our rate k (0.083 min–1, or 1.4 × 10–3 s–1) is comparable with reported rates for the homogeneous Fe(III) catalyst, whose k is (0.5–3) × 10–3 s–1.(28) The pre-equilibrium constant is quite low in our system. It is reasonable to assume that RhB–H2O2 adducts are not very stable. The pre-equilibrium K was unreasonably large for the reported systems due to their k1 = ∼100 M–1 s–1, while k–1 ≈ 0. However, the comparatively larger Fe(III)–H2O2 binding constant is reasonable.
    This indicates that the reaction kinetics of 1 and 2 are different from that of 3. At comparatively low [H2O2], K[H2O2] is obviously much less than 1. Equation 12 can be simplified as kobs = kK[H2O2], which is the reaction that is first order to [H2O2] in low concentration. Kk is 0. 37 and 0.28 L·mol–1·min–1 for 2 and 1, respectively, in 0–0.8 M H2O2, corresponding to the second-order rate constant in low H2O2 concentration. These rate constants are obviously larger than 0.0260 L·mol–1·min–1 for 3. This may be explained by the possible activation center in 1 located in the cavity (Figure 1) and 2’s larger cavity (Figure 2). However, in 3, the Cu3, a possible activation center, is blocked by the tetranuclear cluster (Figure 3). Compared with the cavities in 1 and 2, substrate access to the metal center is much more difficult.
    Effect of Initial pH Value
    The pH of the solution also plays an important role in the catalytic degradation. The RhB degradations at pH 4.8, 8.0, and 9.0 are shown in Figures S11, S12, and S13, respectively. The RhB degradation percentage with time at different pH in the presence of 1 is shown in Figure 7. The degradation profiles for 1, 2, and 3 at pH 4.8, 7.0, 8.0, and 9.0 are shown in Figure S14a–d. For comparison, catalytic degradation percentages of a particular catalyst at different pH were shown in Figure S15. From Figure S14, the degradation efficiency (Ct/C0 = At/A0) is in the order 2 > 1 > 3 in pH 4.8–9. From Figure 7, the catalytic degradation is essentially constant in pH 4.8–8 for complex 1. In this pH range, RhB self-degradation (without catalyst) is negligible. The degradation is attributed to catalytic oxidation. In pH 9, RhB self-degradation is significantly increased while catalytic oxidation is insignificant. These phenomena can be explained by, at pH 9, the activation site of Cu(II) being occupied by OH–, which is much more difficult to replace by guest molecule H2O2. The difference in the absence and presence of catalyst in pH 9 decreased significantly. The half-degradation time in pH 4.8–8 is estimated to be about 30 min. The RhB degradation over 80% within an hour for complex 1, which is faster than literature data(29) (Tables S2–S5). Complexes 2 and 3 are somewhat similar to that of 1, but the degradation is obviously slower at pH 8 compared to those at pH 4.8–7.0 (Figure S15). The observed first-order rate constants at 0.32 M H2O2 are listed in Table 2. Most studies relate to photocatalytic degradation with half-life times of 30–60 min in the presence of 30% H2O2.(11, 30) Our system can degrade RhB in the dark; it has an obvious advantage over photodegradation.
    Table 2. First-Order Rate Constant Kobs (min–1) for Oxidation of 10 mL of 8.0 ppm RhB Aqueous Solution in the Presence of 0.32 M H2O2 and 10 mg of Complex at Various pHa
    pH4.87.08.09.0
    blank0.000631 ± 0.000030.00117 ± 0.000040.00121 ± 0.000020.00583 ± 0.00007
    10.0319 ± 0.00030.0322 ± 0.0010.0273 ± 0.00080.0148 ± 0.001
    20.0415 ± 0.0040.0399 ± 0.0030.0323 ± 0.00080.0195 ± 0.0004
    30.0187 ± 0.00030.0150 ± 0.00030.0113 ± 0.00040.00521 ± 0.0001
    a

    The blank groups without complexes have been given for comparison.

    Reaction Products
    Mass spectrometry (MS) is an effective method to identify products of RhB degradation in solution. It is commonly known that the reaction product highly depends on time. In the oxidation process, catalyst 2 is the most effective as seen from Table 2. In the presence of 1, 2, and 3, 8.0 ppm RhB has half-lives of ∼30, ∼25, and ∼60 min, respectively, in pH 4.8–8.0. After 4 h, catalyst 2 has obviously been lost possibly due to oxidation/degradation of ligands. Complex 2 completely disappeared overnight in the catalytic oxidation process, while 1 and 3 have insignificant losses. Complexes 1 and 3 will be completely lost in 3 days. The catalyst degradation, especially compound 2, may be due to its large cavity (59%) making 2 unstable. As a common sense, except kinetically inert Cr(III) and Zr(IV) polymers, most other porous coordination polymers are not sufficiently stable in aqueous solution, especially large porous polymers.(31) Our experiments further prove this phenomenon.
    The MS spectra were run after 6 h reaction. Their MS spectra were shown in Figure 8. No RhB can be found in the MS spectra in all three experiments as there is no sign in 443.2 (M+ of free RhB), 399.2 (M+ – C3H8), and 355.1 (M+ – 2C3H8).(32) Possible products were assigned, which are shown in Figure 8 (better than 0.1 mass difference). The catalytic degradation products within 6 h are all due to the RhB in the presence of 1. The degradation product at m/z 104, 145, 230, and 310 are all degradation products of RhB (Figure 8a). In the presence of 2, however, losses are mainly due to the degradation of ligands in complex (Figure 8b). This agrees well with the experimental phenomena. In the MS spectra, the ligand is hydrolyzed into hydroxyl phthalate or degraded into biphenyl tetracarboxylate (Figure 8b).
    The m/z 347.18 peak in Figure 8c is quite similar to the ligand peak at 347.04, but the error 0.14 is far larger than any other designation. We designated this peak to an RhB degradation product (Figure 8c). Clearly, the 183.6 peak can only be assigned to +2 cation of two nitrogen containing species. No ligand degradation product can be found. The degradation product in the presence of 3 is somewhat similar to that of 1 as they are all RhB degradation products. However, the RhB degradation product in the presence of 3 is different from that of 1 as there are no aliphatic dicarboxylates in the presence of 3. The reason is that the degradation of RhB is always from the 2-position of the benzoic acid to form an aromatic carboxylate. Further degradation of aromatic acid forms aliphatic acid. The reaction is much faster in the presence of 1 than in the presence of 3 (Table 2); thus RhB degradation is much deeper in the presence of 1. Further degradation may generate CO2 or other smaller compounds through mineralization, which is not a focus in this study.
    From the MS data, the products are mainly carboxylate, which can also act as ligand coordination to Cu(II) ions, especially in higher concentrations. This is the reason why catalysts were lost in extended contact with the solution. These MS results agree well with the reaction kinetics. That is, 3 is the slowest catalyst; it can degrade RhB into aromatic carboxylate, the first stage of RhB degradation. Complex 1 is faster than 3; it degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylate (second degradation stage). The fastest 2 degrades not only RhB but also 2 itself. In summary, 1 showed the best performance not only with higher reaction rate constant but also with the ability of quickly degrading dyes into smaller species by breaking aromatic rings. Although 2 is the fastest, it is unstable in the oxidation process.
    Other Dyes
    RhB can be oxidized not only in the presence of 1, 2, and 3 but also in other ways. Figures S16–S18 show spectral changes of 8.0 ppm methylene blue in the presence of 1–3 at neutral pH. Safranine T (cation dye, 24 ppm) and orange II (anion dye, 24 ppm) spectra are shown in Figures S19–S21 and S22–S23, respectively. Similar to the degradation of RhB, these dyes can also be oxidized into colorless products. An 8.0 ppm amount of MB has half-life times of 10, 15, and 40 min in the presence of 2, 1, and 3, respectively (Figure S18), which is faster than that of RhB oxidation. A 24 ppm amount of safranine T (Figure S21) has almost an identical half-life to that of 8 ppm MB. Note that in the oxidation of orange II, the color quickly changes from orange (484 nm) to red (522 nm) within 10 min, followed by the decomposition of 522 nm compounds. The half-time of the 522 nm species is 40, 20, and 65 min in the presence of 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Figure S23). Natural diatomites as a green catalyst for Fenton-like oxidation of orange II in the presence of H2O2 was studied.(33) Its half-life is several hours at room temperature. Graphene base cathode can also degrade orange II via Fenton reaction in the presence of H2O2.(33) This 522 nm species has not been mentioned elsewhere.(28, 34) Orange II has peaks at 484 nm in acidic to pH 11 (Figure S24). Only in a strong basic solution does the orange color at 484 nm split into two peaks at 450 and 520 nm (Figure S24). In our experiments, the solution is neutral or slightly acidic. The 522 nm peak is not the dianion dye as their shapes differ greatly (no 450 nm peak in the presence of our complexes). Previously, in attempts to synthesize MOF with azo ligands, azo was oxidized into nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N(O):N(O)C6H4X or XC6H4N(O):NC6H4X (X is carboxylate) in air atmosphere.(35) Sakaue et al. reported that the oxidized products of various substituted anilines XC6H4NH2 were selectively converted into the corresponding nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N(O):N(O)C6H4X (II) or nitrobenzenes XC6H4NO2 (Xs are substituents) by oxidation with aqueous hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by heteropolyoxometalates.(36) The homogeneous catalytic activity of the N-tailed tetraamido macrocyclic Fe(IIII) activators in the oxidative bleaching of orange II dye by H2O2 in aqueous solution was studied; it was found that Fe(III) complexes have the best catalytic activity at pH 10.5,(28) but there is no peak at 522 nm. We attribute this 522 nm peak to the oxo-azo orange II, possibly due to the cavity favoring oxygenation of the azo group. This phenomenon has resulted in an azo compound (but not the orange II) in the presence of strong oxidant.(37)
    Stability and Reusability of Catalysts
    The reusability of complexes 1–3 was evaluated by 8.0 ppm RhB degradation in the presence of H2O2 at pH 4.8. After each experiment (1.5 and 2 h for 1 and 3, respectively), the catalyst was separated by filtration and used without further treatment. Noticeably, the catalyst did not exhibit significant loss of catalytic activity and the degradation efficiency was still higher than 88% after three recycles for 1 and 3. To confirm the stability of the catalysts, we compared IR and PXRD before and after catalysis. The IR pattern of each compound was similar to those of the fresh compound (Figure S25). After catalysis, a new peak at 1732 cm–1 appeared, possibly because some carboxylic acid molecules (degradation product) contaminated/were adsorbed in the cavity of 1. For 2 and 3, there is no sign of IR change before and after catalysis. The PXRD patterns of 1 and 3 are identical before and after catalysis (Figure S26a,c). However, for 2, the PXRD pattern changes obviously before and after catalysis (Figure S26b). This may explain why 2 dissolves in the catalytic process. Our results demonstrated that 1 and 3 may be reusable for the catalytic reduction of toxic organic dyes and for purifying of wastewater.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    In summary, three porous Cu(II) coordination polymers were synthesized through the solvothermal method. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for degradation of dyes aqueous solution, such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) without light irradiation. Reaction kinetics and possible product were studied in detail. The reaction kinetics is first order to [RhB] and [H2O2] in low concentration. The rate of catalyst degradation is in the order of 2 > 1 > 3. However, 2 with a cavity of 59% is unstable in the oxidation process. The reaction rates are essentially constant in pH 4.8–8. Further increases in pH will greatly decrease catalytic activity. Within 6 h, slowest 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylates and 2 degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylates, while fastest 2 degrades RhB and itself. Both 1 and 3 can be reused at least 3 times without decreases in catalytic activity. These porous coordination polymers can also catalyze the oxidation of methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II as well. Based on the excellent catalytic activity and stability, 1 and 3 have great potential to be a green catalyst for heterogeneous degradation of hazardous dyes.

      Kajiwara, T.; Higuchi, M.; Yuasa, A.; Higashimura, H.; Kitagawa, S. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49 (89) 10459– 10461 DOI: 10.1039/c3cc43384f
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      One-dimensional alignment of strong Lewis acid sites in a porous coordination polymer
      Kajiwara, Takashi; Higuchi, Masakazu; Yuasa, Akihiro; Higashimura, Hideyuki; Kitagawa, Susumu
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (89), 10459-10461CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A new lanthanoid porous coordination polymer, [La(BTTc)(DMF)·x(solv)]∞ [BTTc = benzene-1,3,5-tris(2-thiophene-5-carboxylate), solv = water, acetone, DMF, nitrogen, ammonia, ethanol], was synthesized and structurally characterized to have densely aligned one-dimensional open metal sites. La(BTTc)(DMF) 1 acts as strong Lewis acid after the removal of the coordinated solvent and reacts with 1-hexene. Compd. 1 was used as a catalyst for the cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde. Addnl., three compds. with cerium, praseodymium, and neodymium [Ln(BTTc)(DMF)·DMFx] (Ln = Ce, Pr, Nd; x = 2 for Ce) were also synthesized.

    2. 2
      (a) Ranocchiari, M.; van Bokhoven, J. A. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2011, 13 (14) 6388– 6396 DOI: 10.1039/c0cp02394a
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2a
      Catalysis by metal-organic frameworks: fundamentals and opportunities
      Ranocchiari, Marco; van Bokhoven, Jeroen Anton
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2011), 13 (14), 6388-6396CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Cryst. porous materials are extremely important for developing catalytic systems with high scientific and industrial impact. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show unique potential that still has to be fully exploited. This perspective summarizes the properties of MOFs with the aim to understand what are possible approaches to catalysis with these materials. We categorize three classes of MOF catalysts: (1) those with active site on the framework, (2) those with encapsulated active species, and (3) those with active sites attached through post-synthetic modification. We identify the tunable porosity, the ability to fine tune the structure of the active site and its environment, the presence of multiple active sites, and the opportunity to synthesize structures in which key-lock bonding of substrates occurs as the characteristics that distinguish MOFs from other materials. We experience a unique opportunity to imagine and design heterogeneous catalysts, which might catalyze reactions previously thought impossible.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjsFKkt70%253D&md5=369df768bec6816f8793240dfba1aa00
      (b) Zou, R.-Q.; Sakurai, H.; Xu, Q. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45 (16) 2542– 2546 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200503923
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2b
      Preparation, adsorption properties, and catalytic activity of three-dimensional porous metal-organic frameworks composed of cubic building blocks and alkali-metal ions
      Zou, Ru-Qiang; Sakurai, Hiroaki; Xu, Qiang
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (16), 2542-2546CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Unexpected catalytic activity for the oxidn. of CO to CO2 is exhibited by one of two novel three-dimensional porous metal-org. frameworks in which [Ni8L12]20- (H3L = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid) cubic building blocks (CBBs) are linked by Li1 or Na1 ions. The clathrating ability towards Li1 ions of such CBBs is seen in the powder XRD x-ray crystal structure, which simulates the potential guest-bonding sites in the building blocks of the MOFs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvVCmsbs%253D&md5=e3e928162fa9a39ecd0553ca1f65a7b1
      (c) Wang, S.; Wang, X. Small 2015, 11 (26) 3097– 3112 DOI: 10.1002/smll.201500084
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2c
      Multifunctional Metal-Organic Frameworks for Photocatalysis
      Wang, Sibo; Wang, Xinchen
      Small (2015), 11 (26), 3097-3112CODEN: SMALBC; ISSN:1613-6810. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant research attention in diverse areas due to their unique phys. and chem. characteristics that allow their innovative application in various research fields. Recently, the application of MOFs in heterogeneous photocatalysis for water splitting, CO2 redn., and org. transformation have emerged, aiming at providing alternative solns. to address the world-wide energy and environmental problems by taking advantage of the unique porous structure together with ample physicochem. properties of the metal centers and org. ligands in MOFs. In this review, the latest progress in MOF-involved solar-to-chem. energy conversion reactions are summarized according to their different roles in the photoredox chem. systems, e.g., photocatalysts, co-catalysts, and hosts. The achieved progress and existing problems are evaluated and proposed, and the opportunities and challenges of MOFs and their related materials for their advanced development in photocatalysis are discussed and anticipated.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXnt1SlsLw%253D&md5=a58fd955a4772a34ca52d69b66fb58e7
    3. 3
      (a) Sivakumar, S.; Reddy, M. L. P.; Cowley, A. H.; Vasudevan, K. V. Dalton Trans. 2010, 39 (3) 776– 786 DOI: 10.1039/B917256D
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3a
      Synthesis and crystal structures of lanthanide 4-benzyloxy benzoates: Influence of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups on luminescent properties
      Sivakumar, Sarika; Reddy, M. L. P.; Cowley, Alan H.; Vasudevan, Kalyan V.
      Dalton Transactions (2010), 39 (3), 776-786CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Three new 4-benzyloxy HOBz derivs. [4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL1; 3-methoxy-4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL2; 3-nitro-4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL3] were employed as ligands for the support of six lanthanide coordination compds. [Tb3+ = 1-3; Eu3+ = 4-6] with the aim of testing the influence of electron releasing (-OMe) or electron withdrawing (-NO2) substituents on the photophys. properties. The new complexes were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic techniques and two of the Tb3+ complexes [1 and 2] were structurally authenticated by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Compds. 1 and 2 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/n and their mol. structures consist of homodinuclear species that are bridged by two O atoms from two benzoate ligands. In the case of 1, the carboxylate ligands coordinate to the central Tb3+ ion in bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes. By contrast, three different coordination modes (bidentate chelating, bidentate bridging and monodentate) are obsd. in the case of compd. 2. Examn. of the packing diagrams for 1 and 2 revealed a 1-dimensional mol. array that is held together by intermol. H-bonding interactions. The incorporation of an electron-releasing substituent on position 3 of 4-benzyloxybenzoic acid increases the electron d. of the ligand and consequently improves the photoluminescence of the Tb3+ complexes. However, the presence of an electron-withdrawing group at this position dramatically decreases the overall sensitization efficiency of the Tb3+-centered luminescence due to dissipation of the excitation energy by a π*-n transition of the NO2 substituent along with the participation of the ILCT bands. The weaker photoluminescence of the Eu3+ complexes is attributable to the poor match of the triplet energy levels of the 4-benzyloxybenzoic acid derivs. with that of the emitting level of the central metal ion.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsF2isLbM&md5=8ea922262dc0fc77dd38a18ac6532b28
      (b) Rocha, J.; Carlos, L. D.; Paz, F. A. A.; Ananias, D. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2011, 40 (2) 926– 940 DOI: 10.1039/C0CS00130A
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3b
      Luminescent multifunctional lanthanides-based metal-organic frameworks
      Rocha, Joao; Carlos, Luis D.; Paz, Filipe A. Almeida; Ananias, Duarte
      Chemical Society Reviews (2011), 40 (2), 926-940CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks based on trivalent lanthanides (LnMOFs) are a very promising class of materials for addressing the challenges in engineering of luminescent centers. Lanthanide-bearing phosphors find numerous applications in lighting, optical communications, photonics and biomedical devices. In this crit. review we discuss the potential of LnMOFs as multifunctional systems, which combine light emission with properties such as microporosity, magnetism, chirality, mol. and ion sensing, catalysis and activity as multimodal imaging contrast agents. We argue that these materials present a unique chance of observing synergy between several of these properties, such as the coupling between photoluminescence and magnetism. Moreover, an integrated approach towards the design of efficient, stable, cheap, environmentally-friendly and multifunctional luminescent LnMOFs is still missing. Although research into LnMOFs is at its early stage and much basic knowledge is still needed, the field is ripe for new ideas, which will enable sensor devices and photonic prototypes to become a com. reality (81 refs.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXptFSktA%253D%253D&md5=58a208684663b39fc48fc3ae96fda4b1
      (c) Chen, B.; Yang, Y.; Zapata, F.; Qian, G.; Luo, Y.; Zhang, J.; Lobkovsky, E. B. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45 (22) 8882– 8886 DOI: 10.1021/ic060568u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3c
      Enhanced near-infrared-luminescence in an erbium tetrafluoroterephthalate framework
      Chen, Banglin; Yang, Yu; Zapata, Fatima; Qian, Guodong; Luo, Yongshi; Zhang, Jiahua; Lobkovsky, Emil B.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (22), 8882-8886CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two Er-org. frameworks Er2(BDC)3(DMF)2(H2O)2.H2O (1) and Er2(BDC-F4)3(DMF)(H2O).DMF (2) (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; BDC-F4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate or tetrafluoroterephthalate; DMF = DMF) were synthesized and structurally characterized. Studies on TGA and the spectroscopic and luminescent properties of 1, 2, and their desolvated solid Er2(BDC)3 (1a) and partially desolvated solid Er2(BDC-F4)3(DMF).DMF (2a) indicate that fluorination can significantly improve the luminescence intensity of the Er ions by reducing the fluorescence quenching effect of the vibrational C-H bond; thus, the near-IR-luminescence intensity of 2a is 3 times higher than that of 1a.

    4. 4
      (a) Sumida, K.; Rogow, D. L.; Mason, J. A.; McDonald, T. M.; Bloch, E. D.; Herm, Z. R.; Bae, T.-H.; Long, J. R. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112 (2) 724– 781 DOI: 10.1021/cr2003272
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4a
      Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs12hsLzE&md5=eb8236e7dfe12981387c71415374f958
      (b) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295 (5554) 469– 472 DOI: 10.1126/science.1067208
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4b
      Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
      Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
      (c) Millward, A. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127 (51) 17998– 17999 DOI: 10.1021/ja0570032

      4c
      Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
      Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (51), 17998-17999CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp. Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar. Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm. The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns. The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2. Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GktLnJ&md5=ad433b990b72836a16c8647c09ec85f2
      (d) Miller, S. R.; Pearce, G. M.; Wright, P. A.; Bonino, F.; Chavan, S.; Bordiga, S.; Margiolaki, I.; Guillou, N.; Ferey, G.; Bourrelly, S.; Llewellyn, P. L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130 (47) 15967– 15981 DOI: 10.1021/ja804936z
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4d
      Structural Transformations and Adsorption of Fuel-Related Gases of a Structurally Responsive Nickel Phosphonate Metal-Organic Framework, Ni-STA-12
      Miller, Stuart R.; Pearce, Gordon M.; Wright, Paul A.; Bonino, Francesca; Chavan, Sachin; Bordiga, Silvia; Margiolaki, Irene; Guillou, Nathalie; Ferey, Gerard; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (47), 15967-15981CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The structure of the Ni N,N'-piperazinebismethylenephosphonate, Ni-STA-12 (St. Andrews porous material-12), was detd. in the hydrated (Ni2L·8H2O, L = O3PCH2NC4H8NCH2PO3), partially dehydrated (Ni2L·2H2O), and fully dehydrated (Ni2L) forms from high-resoln. synchrotron x-ray powder diffraction. The framework structures of Ni2L·8H2O and Ni2L·2H2O are almost identical (R‾3, a 27.8342(1), c 6.2421(2) Å; R‾3, a 27.9144(1), c 6.1655(2) Å) with addnl. physisorbed H2O of the as-prepd. Ni-STA-12 present in an ordered H-bonded network in the channels. Ab initio structure soln. of the fully dehydrated solid indicates it has changed symmetry to triclinic (P‾1, a 6.03475(5), b 14.9157(2), c 16.1572(2) Å, α 112.5721(7), β 95.7025(11), γ 96.4950(11)°) as a result of a topotactic structural rearrangement. The fully dehydrated solid possesses permanent porosity with elliptical channels 8 Å × 9 Å in free diam. The structural change results from the loss of H2O coordinated to the Ni cations, so that the Ni coordination changes from edge-sharing octahedral NiO5N to edge- and corner-sharing 5-fold NiO4N. During this change, two out of three phosphonate groups rotate to become fully coordinated to Ni cations, leaving the remainder of the phosphonate groups coordinated to Ni cations by two O atoms and with a P=O bond projecting into the channels. This transformation, which is completely reversible, causes substantial changes in both vibrational and electronic properties as shown by IR, Raman, and UV-visible spectroscopies. Complementary adsorption, calorimetric, and IR studies of the probe adsorbates H2, CO, and CO2 reveal several distinct adsorption sites in the solid, which are attributed to their interactions with Ni cations which are weak Lewis acid sites, as well as with P=O groups that project into the pores. At 304 K, the adsorption isotherms and enthalpies of adsorption on dehydrated Ni-STA-12 were measured for CO2 and CH4: Ni-STA-12 gives adsorption uptakes of CO2 of 2.5 mmol g-1 at 1 bar, an uptake ca. 10 Times that of CH4.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlWqurvN&md5=443bdbd4de665aa6713b6a25fd7ee4a0

      5a
      Metal-Organic Frameworks as A Tunable Platform for Designing Functional Molecular Materials
      Wang, Cheng; Liu, Demin; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (36), 13222-13234CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers, represent an interesting class of cryst. mol. materials that were synthesized by combining metal-connecting points and bridging ligands. The modular nature of and mild conditions for MOF synthesis have permitted the rational structural design of numerous MOFs and the incorporation of various functionalities via constituent building blocks. The resulting designer MOFs showed promise for applications in a no. of areas, including gas storage/sepn., nonlinear optics/ferroelectricity, catalysis, energy conversion/storage, chem. sensing, biomedical imaging, and drug delivery. The structure-property relations of MOFs can also be readily established by taking advantage of the knowledge of their detailed at. structures, which enables fine-tuning of their functionalities for desired applications. Through the combination of mol. synthesis and crystal engineering, MOFs thus present an unprecedented opportunity for the rational and precise design of functional materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXht1OjurbN&md5=59f57bfc391fa41f22f299ab704d8b22
      (b) Holcroft, J. M.; Hartlieb, K. J.; Moghadam, P. Z.; Bell, J. G.; Barin, G.; Ferris, D. P.; Bloch, E. D.; Algaradah, M. M.; Nassar, M. S.; Botros, Y. Y.; Thomas, K. M.; Long, J. R.; Snurr, R. Q.; Stoddart, J. F. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137 (17) 5706– 5719 DOI: 10.1021/ja511878b
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5b
      Carbohydrate-Mediated Purification of Petrochemicals
      Holcroft, James M.; Hartlieb, Karel J.; Moghadam, Peyman Z.; Bell, Jon G.; Barin, Gokhan; Ferris, Daniel P.; Bloch, Eric D.; Algaradah, Mohammed M.; Nassar, Majed S.; Botros, Youssry Y.; Thomas, K. Mark; Long, Jeffrey R.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Stoddart, J. Fraser
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (17), 5706-5719CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are known to facilitate energy-efficient sepns. of important industrial chem. feedstocks. Here, we report how a class of green MOFs-namely CD-MOFs-exhibits high shape selectivity toward arom. hydrocarbons. CD-MOFs, which consist of an extended porous network of γ-cyclodextrins (γ-CDs) and alkali metal cations, can sep. a wide range of benzenoid compds. as a result of their relative orientation and packing within the transverse channels formed from linking (γ-CD)6 body-centered cuboids in three dimensions. Adsorption isotherms and liq.-phase chromatog. measurements indicate a retention order of ortho- > meta- > para-xylene. The persistence of this regioselectivity is also obsd. during the liq.-phase chromatog. of the ethyltoluene and cymene regioisomers. In addn., mol. shape-sorting within CD-MOFs facilitates the sepn. of the industrially relevant BTEX (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene isomers) mixt. The high resoln. and large sepn. factors exhibited by CD-MOFs for benzene and these alkylaroms. provide an efficient, reliable, and green alternative to current isolation protocols. Furthermore, the isolation of the regioisomers of (i) ethyltoluene and (ii) cymene, together with the purifn. of (iii) cumene from its major impurities (benzene, n-propylbenzene, and diisopropylbenzene) highlight the specificity of the shape selectivity exhibited by CD-MOFs. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations and single component static vapor adsorption isotherms and kinetics reveal the origin of the shape selectivity and provide insight into the capability of CD-MOFs to serve as versatile sepn. platforms derived from renewable sources.

      Metal-Organic Framework Threaded with Aminated Polymer Formed in Situ for Fast and Reversible Ion Exchange
      Gao, Liang; Li, Chi-Ying Vanessa; Chan, Kwong-Yu; Chen, Zhe-Ning
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (20), 7209-7212CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A porous metal-org. framework composite with flexible anion-exchange polymers threaded within the host cavity demonstrates very fast and reversible ion-exchange activity. Polyvinyl benzyl trimethylammonium hydroxide (PVBTAH) caged in ZIF-8 is synthesized in steps of chloro-monomer impregnation, in situ polymn., amination, and alk. ion exchange. The synthesized non-crosslinked PVBTAH∼ZIF-8 material exhibits superior ion-exchange kinetics compared to conventional ion-exchange resins.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXns1Ciuro%253D&md5=50a87542f3766f8ac261b85189312891
      (c) Plabst, M.; McCusker, L. B.; Bein, T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131 (50) 18112– 18118 DOI: 10.1021/ja904636y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6c
      Exceptional Ion-Exchange Selectivity in a Flexible Open Framework Lanthanum(III) tetrakisphosphonate
      Plabst, Monika; McCusker, Lynne B.; Bein, Thomas
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (50), 18112-18118CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The flexible, anionic, open-framework material NaLa[(PO3H)2CH-C6H4-CH(PO3H)2]·4H2O (NaLa(H4L)) exhibits an exceptional selectivity for monovalent metal cations. This study elucidates the relation between the ion-exchange behavior and the framework flexibility of this recently discovered material. The exchange of the Na+ ions in NaLa(H4L) with alk.-earth, alk., and selected transition metal ions was studied. EDX and ICP-OES elemental anal. revealed that ion exchange was successful with monovalent ions, while higher-valent ions were rejected. An explanation for this charge selectivity could be found in the site-specific role of the guest cation. X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric studies on the reversible hydration and dehydration behavior demonstrate that NaLa(H4L) has a flexible framework. Contraction of the channels upon dehydration decreases the cell vol. of 15%. Rietveld refinement of the structure of the dehydrated form NaLa(H4L)dehyd revealed the key role played by the guest cation in the channel-shrinking mechanism. In the hydrated, expanded form, each Na+ ion guest shares three phosphonate oxygens with a La3+ ion in a La phosphonate chain that defines part of the wall of a rhombic channel. The Na+ ion completes its octahedral coordination sphere with two H2O mols. and a weaker bond to a 4th phosphonate O. In the dehydrated, contracted form, the Na+ ion loses the two H2O mols. and moves toward a 2nd La3+ ion, which is located in an adjacent La phosphonate chain, to share two more phosphonate oxygens, and becomes 5-coordinate. This gave an -La-O-Na-O-La- chain and a concomitant shrinking of the channels. A comparison of the monovalent metal (M(I)) ion-exchanged compds., M(I)La(H4L), reveals that both the ionic radius and the enthalpy of hydration of the guest cation affect the equil. between the expanded and the contracted forms, and that the framework adapts specifically to the size of the guest cation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVens7bI&md5=b8e5957ec78243520eb0a3955a60e0ce
    7. 7
      Montoro, C.; Linares, F.; Quartapelle Procopio, E.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S.; Galli, S.; Masciocchi, N.; Barea, E.; Navarro, J. A. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133 (31) 11888– 11891 DOI: 10.1021/ja2042113
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Capture of Nerve Agents and Mustard Gas Analogues by Hydrophobic Robust MOF-5 Type Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Montoro, Carmen; Linares, Fatima; Quartapelle Procopio, Elsa; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan; Galli, Simona; Masciocchi, Norberto; Barea, Elisa; Navarro, Jorge A. R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (31), 11888-11891CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      In this communication, a series of observations and data analyses coherently confirms the suitability of the novel metal-org. framework (MOF) [Zn4(μ4-O)(μ4-4-carboxy-3,5-dimethyl-4-carboxy-pyrazolato)3] (1) in the capture of harmful volatile org. compds. (VOCs). It is worthy of attention that 1, whose crystal structure resembles that of MOF-5, exhibits remarkable thermal, mech., and chem. stability, as required if practical applications are sought. In addn., it selectively captures harmful VOCs (including models of Sarin and mustard gas, which are chem. warfare agents), even in competition with ambient moisture (i.e., under conditions mimicking operative ones). The results can be rationalized on the basis of Henry const. and adsorption heat values for the different essayed adsorbates as well as H2O/VOC partition coeffs. as obtained from variable-temp. reverse gas chromatog. expts. To further strengthen the importance of 1, its performance in the capture of harmful VOCs has been compared with those of well-known materials, namely, a MOF with coordinatively unsatd. metal sites, [Cu3(btc)2] and the mol. sieve active carbon Carboxen. The results of this comparison show that coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (preferential guest-binding sites) are ineffective for the capture of VOCs in the presence of ambient moisture. Consequently, we propose that the driving force of the VOC-MOF recognition process is mainly dictated by pore size and surface hydrophobicity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXptFKmsr0%253D&md5=03e430027a9daed8d7286ea28880c1b2
    8. 8
      Zagorodniy, K.; Seifert, G.; Hermann, H. Appl. Phys. Lett. 2010, 97 (25) 251905 DOI: 10.1063/1.3529461
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Metal-organic frameworks as promising candidates for future ultralow-k dielectrics
      Zagorodniy, K.; Seifert, G.; Hermann, H.
      Applied Physics Letters (2010), 97 (25), 251905/1-251905/2CODEN: APPLAB; ISSN:0003-6951. (American Institute of Physics)
      A class of Zn4O(CO2)6-based metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is theor. analyzed with respect to suitability as an interlayer dielec. material for applications in semiconducting devices. The static dielec. const. is calcd. using the Clausius-Mossotti approach. For 3 out of ∼30 of the considered MOFs excellent combinations of ultralow dielec. const., elastic bulk modulus, and gap energy are found favoring these materials as outstanding candidates for future ultralow-k dielec. materials. (c) 2010 American Institute of Physics.

      (a) Stock, N.; Biswas, S. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112 (2) 933– 969 DOI: 10.1021/cr200304e
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10a
      Synthesis of Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs): Routes to Various MOF Topologies, Morphologies, and Composites
      Stock, Norbert; Biswas, Shyam
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 933-969CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has attracted immense attention during the last 2 decades due to the possibility to obtain a large variety of aesthetically interesting structures that could also be of great interest for applications in a no. of fields related to porous materials. This includes the more traditional areas of storage, sepn., and catalysis, which are based on the pore size and shape as well as the host guest interactions involved. In addn., biomedical applications or the use as sensor materials are currently intensively investigated. Although MOF synthesis was originally set out for making new compds. and structures with interesting properties, the field has matured and is broadening its scope. This holds for the synthesis methods applied as well as the areas of application. While conventional syntheses methods have been widely used, the fields of mechano-, sono-, and electrochem. synthesis as well as microwave-assisted syntheses are just emerging. They have demonstrated to be applicable for some compds., often under milder reaction conditions, yielding materials with different particle sizes and properties. This could be of interest for up-scaling of syntheses and the application of MOFs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsV2ju73P&md5=76323bab0fb9da58bcdf45e03537eed7
      (b) Allendorf, M. D.; Stavila, V. CrystEngComm 2015, 17 (2) 229– 246 DOI: 10.1039/C4CE01693A
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10b
      Crystal engineering, structure-function relationships, and the future of metal-organic frameworks
      Allendorf, Mark D.; Stavila, Vitalie
      CrystEngComm (2015), 17 (2), 229-246CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Metal-Org. Frameworks (MOFs) are a rapidly expanding class of hybrid org.-inorg. materials that can be rationally designed and assembled through crystal engineering. The explosion of interest in this subclass of coordination polymers results from their outstanding properties and myriad possible applications, which include traditional uses of microporous materials, such as gas storage, sepns., and catalysis, as well as new realms in biomedicine, electronic devices, and information storage. The objective of this Highlight article is to provide the reader with a sense of where the field stands after roughly fifteen years of research. Remarkable progress has been made, but the barriers to practical and com. advances are also evident. We discuss the basic elements of MOF assembly and present a conceptual hierarchy of structural elements that assists in understanding how unique properties in these materials can be achieved. Structure-function relationships are then discussed; several are now well understood, as a result of the focused efforts of many research groups over the past decade. Prospects for the use of MOFs in membranes, catalysis, biomedicine, and as active components in electronic and photonic devices are also discussed. Finally, we identify the most pressing challenges in our view that must be addressed for these materials to realize their full potential in the marketplace.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslGisr7F&md5=d41c24fb48fe34cdcadf4f9de51caa92
    11. 11
      Bala, S.; Bhattacharya, S.; Goswami, A.; Adhikary, A.; Konar, S.; Mondal, R. Cryst. Growth Des. 2014, 14 (12) 6391– 6398 DOI: 10.1021/cg501226v
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Designing Functional Metal-Organic Frameworks by Imparting a Hexanuclear Copper-Based Secondary Building Unit Specific Properties: Structural Correlation With Magnetic and Photocatalytic Activity
      Bala, Sukhen; Bhattacharya, Sudeshna; Goswami, Arijit; Adhikary, Amit; Konar, Sanjit; Mondal, Raju
      Crystal Growth & Design (2014), 14 (12), 6391-6398CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      In continuation of the authors' research interest in pyrazole-based multifunctional metal org. frameworks (MOFs), the authors report here three Cu(II) MOFs using pyrazole and various arom. carboxylic acid-based ligands. The main theme of interest is to design functional MOFs by imparting a multinuclear metal center as a secondary building unit (SBU). Accordingly, three MOFs were synthesized based on a hexanuclear Cu-pyrazolate unit as the SBU with some intriguing structural networks like (4,4) type herringbone grid or an archetypal Kagome topol. The authors have successfully synthesized functional MOFs by incorporating hexanuclear Cu-pyrazolate SBU-specific properties viz. magnetism and catalysis, the central theme of this work. The prepd. complexes are {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(NAPH)]DMF.H2O.CH3OH}n (MOF-1, 1), [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(BIPH)(H2O)2]n (MOF-2, 2), and [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(PDC)(H2O)2(CH3OH)]n (MOF-3, 3) (where HPyz = 1H-pyrazole, H2NAPH = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, H2BIPH = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid, and H2PDC = 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid). All the MOFs show some photocatalytic degrdn. of toxic dye mols. However, magnetic behaviors of MOF-2 and MOF-3 assocd. with the Cu6 unit also were studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A Bismuth-Based Metal-Organic Framework as an Efficient Visible-Light-Driven Photocatalyst
      Wang, Guanzhi; Sun, Qilong; Liu, Yuanyuan; Huang, Baibiao; Dai, Ying; Zhang, Xiaoyang; Qin, Xiaoyan
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (6), 2364-2367CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A visible-light-responsive bismuth-based metal-org. framework (Bi-mna) is demonstrated to show good photoelec. and photocatalytic properties. Combining exptl. and theor. results, a ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) process is found to be responsible for the high performance, which gives rise to a longer lifetime of photogenerated charge carriers. Our results suggest that bismuth-based MOFs could be promising candidates for the development of efficient visible-light photocatalysts.

      13a
      Energy-Efficient Photodegradation of Azo Dyes with TiO2 Nanoparticles Based on Photoisomerization and Alternate UV-Visible Light
      Zhang, Hao; Chen, Da; Lv, Xiaojun; Wang, Ying; Chang, Haixin; Li, Jinghong
      Environmental Science & Technology (2010), 44 (3), 1107-1111CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
      We demonstrated a UV-vis light alternate photocatalysis (UVLAP) strategy in the photodegrdn. of azo dyes. The UVLAP of azo dyes over TiO2 catalysts exhibited significantly higher energy efficiency than the conventional UV process by 40%, which was attributed to the photoisomerization of azo dyes and the resulting diversity of dyes' cis and trans states in interfacial properties, including conductance and spatial effects. This UVLAP strategy could contribute to the energy-saving photodegrdn. of azo dyes and other pollutants with photoisomerization properties and facilitate the practical application of TiO2 in the environmental remediation.
