      Decontamination of wastewaters containing synthetic organic dyes by electrochemical methods: A general review
      Martinez-Huitle, Carlos A.; Brillas, Enric
      Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental (2009), 87 (3-4), 105-145CODEN: ACBEE3; ISSN:0926-3373. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review of efficient electrochem. technologies to decolorize and/or degrade dyeing wastewater, providing fundamentals for each technol. to better understand their advantages and limitations, is given. Topics discussed include: electrocoagulation (Fe or steel anode, Al anode, comparative anode behavior); electrochem. redn.; electrochem. oxidn. (model for org. oxidn. with heterogeneous OH-, electrochem. systems and exptl. parameters [PbO2 anode, dimensionally-stable anode-type electrodes], Pt anode, carbonaceous and other anode materials, B-doped diamond electrodes [Ti/, Ni/, and Si/B-doped diamond electrodes, diamond electrodes with unspecified support], comparative anode oxidn. power); indirect electrooxidn. with strong oxidants (active Cl2 [electro-generation of active Cl2 species, exptl. systems, dimensionally-stable electrodes, metal anodes, graphite anodes], electro-Fenton method [homogeneous OH- generation, electrochem. systems and exptl. conditions, dye treatment], other indirect electrochem. techniques); photo-assisted electrochem. methods (photo-Fenton, photo-electrocatalysis, coupled photo-assisted treatments); and conclusions.

      13c
      High adsorption capacity NaOH-activated carbon for dye removal from aqueous solution
      Wu, Feng-Chin; Tseng, Ru-Ling
      Journal of Hazardous Materials (2008), 152 (3), 1256-1267CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The surface coverage ratio (Sc/Sp) and monolayer cover adsorption amt. per unit surface area (qmon/Sp) were employed to investigate the adsorption isotherm equil. of the adsorption of dyes (AB74, BB1, and MB) on NaOH-activated carbons (FWNa2, FWNa3, and FWNa4); the adsorption rate of the Elovich equation (1/b) and the ratio of 1 min adsorption amt. of adsorbate to the monolayer cover amt. of adsorbate (q 1/q mon) were employed to investigate adsorption kinetics. The qmon/Sp of NaOH-activated carbons was better than that of KOH-activated carbons prepd. from the same raw material (fir wood). The Sc/Sp values of the adsorption of all adsorbates on adsorbent FWNa3 in this study were found to be higher than those in related literature. Parameters 1/b and q1 of the adsorption of dyes on activated carbons in this study were higher than those on KOH-activated carbons; the q1/qmon value of FWNa3 was the highest. The pore structure and the TPD measurement of the surface oxide groups were employed to explain the superior adsorption performance of FWNa3. A high-surface activated carbon (FWNa3) with excellent adsorption performance on dyes with relation to adsorption isotherm equil. and kinetics was obtained in this study. Several adsorption data processing methods were employed to describe the adsorption performance.

      14a
      Selectively catalytic pastry-shape micro-crystals: A new linear metal-organic framework with [Cu(NO3)2(bpd)(DMF)]∞
      Meng, Qingxiang; Ye, Jing; Xu, Zhen-liang; Xu, Haitao
      Materials Letters (2014), 116 (), 378-381CODEN: MLETDJ; ISSN:0167-577X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Pastry-shaped micro-crystals of a new linear metal-org. framework (MOF), [Cu(NO3)2(bpd)(DMF)]∞ (1) (bpd = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-azo-1,3-butadiene), were synthesized and characterized. The crystals were monoclinic with space group P2(1)/c, a = 9.5401(8), b = 14.3545(12), c = 14.9823(12) Å, β = 106.37(10)° and Z = 4. In the title compd. (1), each Cu(II) center exists in a pentagonal-bipyramid environment, contributed by two N atoms from two bpds and five O atoms belonging to two nitrates and one DMF. The {Cu(NO3)2(DMF)} moieties are bridged by bpds to form 1-D mol. chains along the ac-axis. The catalytic degrdn. activity of the micro-crystals of 1 is high for methyl orange (90%), and lower for Orange G (55%), indicating that the catalyst synthesized in the authors' work is not only highly active and selective for org.-dye degrdn. reactions, but is also very efficient.

      Ye, Jing; Gou, Yongxia; Xu, Zhen-Liang; Xu, Haitao

      Metal-org. framework micro-crystals [Co(4-bpdh)(HIA)].varies. (1), crystd. in the monoclinic system (space group P12/n1, a 10.0009(16), b 15.472(3), c 18.563(3) Å, β 91.81(0)°, and Z = 4), were controllably synthesized through the adjustment of the solvent system. The Co2+ ion center located in a six-coordinated environment combined with 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (HIA, 2) to produce ladder-like structures, which again linked with 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (4-bpdh, 3) to yield a double-layer network. Micro-crystals 1 exhibited selectively oxidn.-catalytic properties for the degrdn. of methyl orange (conversion 90%) owing to ligand to metal charge transfer. The authors' work detd. that the synthesized catalyst is not only highly selective for degrdn. of org. dyes, but also very efficient.

      15
      Electrochemical photolysis of water at a semiconductor electrode
      Fujishima, Akira; Honda, Kenichi
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1972), 238 (5358), 37-8CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      For electrochem. decompn. of H2O, a p.d. of >1.23 V is necessary between the anode and the cathode. This p.d. is equal to the energy of radiation with wavelength of ∼1000 nm. This energy, in the form of visible light, can be used effectively in an electrochem. system to decomp. H2O. A novel type of electrochem. cell was developed, in which a TiO2 electrode was connected with a Pt-black electrode through an external load. The direction of current revealed that oxidn. occurred at the TiO2 electrode and redn. at the Pt-black electrode. To increase the efficiency of the process, more reducible species, such as dissolved O2 or Fe3+, must be added in the Pt electrode compartment. The use of a p-type semiconductor electrode instead of Pt leads to more effective electrochem. photolysis of H2O.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE38XltVykurw%253D&md5=71f39843802b5cdb5f7cb0deb7f0c63c

      Aarthi, T.; Madras, G. Catal. Commun. 2008, 9 (5) 630– 634 DOI: 10.1016/j.catcom.2007.07.001
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Photocatalytic reduction of metals in presence of combustion synthesized nano-TiO2
      Aarthi, T.; Madras, Giridhar
      Catalysis Communications (2008), 9 (5), 630-634CODEN: CCAOAC; ISSN:1566-7367. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The photocatalytic redn. of the metal ions, Cu(II) and Cr(VI), was investigated in presence of soln. combustion synthesized (CS) nano-TiO2. The efficiency of this catalyst was compared with that of com. titania, Degussa P-25. For the redn. of Cu2+, the first-order rate consts. were 0.003 and 0.018 min-1 in presence of Degussa P-25 and CS TiO2, resp. For the redn. of Cr6+, the initial rate consts. were 0.007 and 0.247 min-1 in presence of Degussa P-25 and CS TiO2, resp. Thus, the rate of redn. of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) is higher in CS TiO2 compared to Degussa P-25 TiO2. The effect of pH and the effect of initial concn. on the photocatalytic redn. of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) in presence of soln. combustion synthesized TiO2 and Degussa P-25 catalyst were investigated. The variation of the photoredn. rate of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) with respect to pH correlates with the variation of the driving force, which is the difference between the std. redn. potential of the metal ion and the energy level of the electrons in the conduction band. The other metal ions like Zn(II), Cd(II), Pb(II) and Mn(II) could not be reduced in both the catalytic systems and this is attributed to the thermodn. in-feasibility of their redn. by photo generated electrons.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Jing, T.; Dai, Y.; Wei, W.; Ma, X.; Huang, B. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16 (34) 18596– 18604 DOI: 10.1039/C4CP01846J
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Near-infrared photocatalytic activity induced by intrinsic defects in Bi2MO6 (M = W, Mo)
      Jing, Tao; Dai, Ying; Wei, Wei; Ma, Xiangchao; Huang, Baibiao
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (34), 18596-18604CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The electronic structure and related photocatalytic properties of Bi2MO6 (M = W, Mo) with various intrinsic defects are studied based on the first-principles d. functional theory (DFT). Our results indicate that O vacancies form easily in both Bi2WO6 and Bi2MoO6 under Bi rich/O poor conditions. The near-IR light transitions can be realized involving electrons from the O vacancy induced impurity states within the band gap to the conduction band. Rather than acting as photogenerated carrier recombination centers, the impurity states caused by O vacancies favor the transfer of photogenerated holes and further benefit the photocatalytic process due to the delocalized nature. The spatial sepn. of photogenerated carriers among different layers can be realized, which reduces the carrier recombination and improves the photocatalytic activity. In addn., Bi2WO6 with O vacancies is desirable for having better near-IR photocatalytic performance than Bi2MoO6 due to the larger mobility of photogenerated holes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFOjtL%252FF&md5=33f8ec9e00f63c0b283026a4d6cc63d7
    18. 18
      Lee, J. C.; Park, S.; Park, H.-J.; Lee, J.-H.; Kim, H.-S.; Chung, Y.-J. J. Electroceram. 2009, 22 (1–3) 110– 113 DOI: 10.1007/s10832-007-9356-3

      18
      Photocatalytic degradation of TOC from aqueous phenol solution using solution combusted ZnO nanopowders
      Lee, Jae Chun; Park, Sung; Park, Hye-Jung; Lee, Ju-Hyeon; Kim, Hong-Sick; Chung, Yun-Joong
      Journal of Electroceramics (2009), 22 (1-3), 110-113CODEN: JOELFJ; ISSN:1385-3449. (Springer)
      ZnO nanopowders were prepd. by soln. combustion method (SCM). The ZnO nanopowders synthesized using Zn(OH)2 and glycine as an oxidant and a fuel (with fuel/oxidant ratio, F/O = 0.8), showed excellent cryst. and photocatalytic characteristics. In order to evaluate the photocatalytic reactivity of the prepd. ZnO nanopowder, it was tried to decomp. total org. carbon (TOC) from aq. phenol soln. Several kinds of TiO2 nanopowders were also tried to compare the photocatalytic reactivity. Surprisingly, SCM ZnO nanopowder shows 1.6 fold higher destruction rates of the org. pollutant than P-25 TiO2 nanopowder that is known as a kind of std. photocatalyst.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXitVOrs7c%253D&md5=47d27d8402621cd065cc8327235f9879

      19a
      Photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes under solar light irradiation combined with Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites
      Xu, Rui; Li, Jia; Wang, Jun; Wang, Xiaofang; Liu, Bin; Wang, Baoxin; Luan, Xiaoyu; Zhang, Xiangdong
      Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2010), 94 (6), 1157-1165CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
      In order to extend the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, two new photocatalysts of Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites were prepd. by the sol-gel process and characterized by XRD and TG-DTA. And then, their photocatalytic activities through the degrdn. of azo Fuchsine under solar light irradn. were evaluated by HPLC techniques and UV-vis spectra. The influencing factors such as the Er3+:YAlO3 content, heat-treated temp. and heat-treated time on the photocatalytic activities of Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites were reviewed. Otherwise, the solar light irradn. time, initial concn. of azo Fuchsine, photocatalyst addn. amt. and kind of org. dyes on the photocatalytic degrdn. of azo fuchsine were also studied. All exptl. results indicate that the Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites are more effective than Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 powders. That is because the Er3+:YAlO3 can transform the visible light into the UV light and enhance the photocatalytic activities of Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 powders. It is possible to provide a new way to utilize the Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites under the solar light irradn. for the treatment of wastewater in the future.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXkvFeiu7g%253D&md5=72a0fdba10f656d98cae2518bc589a52

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19b
      Photocatalytic degradation of Methylene Blue using a mixed catalyst and product analysis by LC/MS
      Rauf, Muhammad A.; Meetani, Mohammed A.; Khaleel, A.; Ahmed, Amal
      Chemical Engineering Journal (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2010), 157 (2-3), 373-378CODEN: CMEJAJ; ISSN:1385-8947. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Cr-Ti binary oxide with 10% molar Cr3+ content (Ti-10Cr) was prepd. by sol-gel method and characterized by using transmission electron microscope (TEM) and x-ray diffraction anal. (XRD). The photoinduced degrdn. of Methylene Blue (MB) dye in the presence of Ti-10 Cr was studied with UV-vis absorption. The absorption intensity of the dye soln. monitored at 668 nm decreased with time upon irradn. in the presence of the catalyst. A max. degrdn. efficiency of 70% of the dye was achieved in the presence of Ti-10 Cr catalyst at pH 7. Photocatalytic degrdn. of the dye followed the pseudo-second-order-kinetics. Degrdn. product anal. was done using the LC-UV/vis-MS technique and the results showed that the dye degrdn. is initiated by demethylation of the mol. The intermediates structure was confirmed by tandem mass spectrometric anal.

      19c
      Photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue by ZnGa2O4 thin films
      Zhang, Weiwei; Zhang, Junying; Chen, Ziyu; Wang, Tianmin
      Catalysis Communications (2009), 10 (13), 1781-1785CODEN: CCAOAC; ISSN:1566-7367. (Elsevier B.V.)
      ZnGa2O4 thin films were synthesized using a sol-gel process, characterized by SEM, x-ray diffraction (XRD) and UV-vis spectrophotometry measurements. The photocatalytic decompg. properties to methylene blue (MB) dye were studied for the first time. Effects of calcining temp., crystallites size and film thickness on the photocatalytic activity were investigated. The film obtained at calcining temp. of 700°, consisting of the smallest crystallites, exhibits highest photocatalytic activity. With increasing the film thickness, the photocatalysis rate const. increased first to 0.0195, and then decreased drastically to 0.0089 due to the competition between UV absorption and carriers diffusion. The photocatalytic activity of ZnGa2O4 films maintained more than 90% of the initial value after 6 cycles, compared favorably with the 70% of ZnGa2O4 powder.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXosVGksL0%253D&md5=09b64ae2df370906c01314855c8eebb9

      (a) Wang, C.; Xie, Z.; de Krafft, K. E.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133 (34) 13445– 13454 DOI: 10.1021/ja203564w
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20a
      Doping Metal-Organic Frameworks for Water Oxidation, Carbon Dioxide Reduction, and Organic Photocatalysis
      Wang, Cheng; Xie, Zhigang; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (34), 13445-13454CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Catalytically competent Ir, Re, and Ru complexes H2L1-H2L6 with dicarboxylic acid functionalities were incorporated into a highly stable and porous Zr6O4(OH)4(bpdc)6 (UiO-67, bpdc = para-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) framework using a mix-and-match synthetic strategy. The matching ligand lengths between bpdc and L1-L6 ligands allowed the construction of highly cryst. UiO-67 frameworks (metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) 1-6) that were doped with L1-L6 ligands. MOFs 1-6 were isostructural to the parent UiO-67 framework as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and exhibited high surface areas ranging from 1092 to 1497 m2/g. MOFs 1-6 were stable in air up to 400 °C and active catalysts in a range of reactions that are relevant to solar energy utilization. MOFs 1-3 contg. [Cp*IrIII(dcppy)Cl] (H2L1), [Cp*IrIII(dcbpy)Cl]Cl (H2L2), and [IrIII(dcppy)2(H2O)2]OTf (H2L3) (where Cp* is pentamethylcyclopentadienyl, dcppy is 2-phenylpyridine-5,4'-dicarboxylic acid, and dcbpy is 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid) were effective water oxidn. catalysts (WOCs), with turnover frequencies (TOFs) of up to 4.8 h-1. The [ReI(CO)3(dcbpy)Cl] (H2L4) derivatized MOF 4 served as an active catalyst for photocatalytic CO2 redn. with a total turnover no. (TON) of 10.9, three times higher than that of the homogeneous complex H2L4. MOFs 5 and 6 contained phosphorescent [IrIII(ppy)2(dcbpy)]Cl (H2L5) and [RuII(bpy)2(dcbpy)]Cl2 (H2L6) (where ppy is 2-phenylpyridine and bpy is 2,2'-bipyridine) and were used in three photocatalytic org. transformations (aza-Henry reaction, aerobic amine coupling, and aerobic oxidn. of thioanisole) with very high activities. The inactivity of the parent UiO-67 framework and the reaction supernatants in catalytic water oxidn., CO2 redn., and org. transformations indicate both the mol. origin and heterogeneous nature of these catalytic processes. The stability of the doped UiO-67 catalysts under catalytic conditions was also demonstrated by comparing PXRD patterns before and after catalysis. This work illustrates the potential of combining mol. catalysts and MOF structures in developing highly active heterogeneous catalysts for solar energy utilization.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXpvVWltrk%253D&md5=d97d78fa80f220f2be578112a620d6f6
      (b) Falkowski, J. M.; Sawano, T.; Zhang, T.; Tsun, G.; Chen, Y.; Lockard, J. V.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136 (14) 5213– 5216 DOI: 10.1021/ja500090y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Privileged Phosphine-Based Metal-Organic Frameworks for Broad-Scope Asymmetric Catalysis
      Falkowski, Joseph M.; Sawano, Takahiro; Zhang, Teng; Tsun, Galen; Chen, Yuan; Lockard, Jenny V.; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (14), 5213-5216CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A robust and porous Zr metal-org. framework (MOF) based on a BINAP-derived dicarboxylate linker, BINAP-MOF, was synthesized and post-synthetically metalated with Ru and Rh complexes to afford highly enantioselective catalysts for important org. transformations. The Rh-functionalized MOF is not only highly enantioselective (up to >99% ee) but also 3 times as active as the homogeneous control. XAFS studies revealed that the Ru-functionalized MOF contains Ru-BINAP precatalysts with the same coordination environment as the homogeneous Ru complex. The post-synthetically metalated BINAP-MOFs provide a versatile family of single-site solid catalysts for catalyzing a broad scope of asym. org. transformations, including addn. of aryl and alkyl groups to α,β-unsatd. ketones and hydrogenation of substituted alkene and carbonyl compds.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A Multifunctional Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Structure Based on MnIII-Porphyrin and Polyoxometalate as a Highly Effective Dye Scavenger and Heterogenous Catalyst
      Zou, Chao; Zhang, Zhijuan; Xu, Xuan; Gong, Qihan; Li, Jing; Wu, Chuan-De
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (1), 87-90CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A two-step synthesis strategy has led to a unique layered polyoxometalate MnIII metalloporphyrin-based hybrid material. The hybrid solid demonstrates remarkable capability for scavenging of dyes and for heterogeneous selective oxidn. of alkylbenzenes with excellent product yields and 100% selectivity.

      Structure versatility of coordination polymers constructed from a semirigid ligand and polynuclear metal clusters
      Yang, De-Liang; Zhang, Xin; Yao, Yuan-Gen; Zhang, Jian
      CrystEngComm (2014), 16 (34), 8047-8057CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Five new coordination polymers, namely [Cd3(dcppa)(Hdcppa)(H2O)]·(Me2NH2)·(DMA)2 (1), [CdCa(dcppa)(DMA)2] (2), [CdCa(dcppa)(H2O)2(DMA)] (3), [Ba2(H2dcppa)2(μ2-H2O)(H2O)(DMA)]·(H2O) (4), and [Ba2(H2dcppa)2(μ2-H2O)(H2O)(DMF)]·(H2O) (5) (Me2NH2+ = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide; H4dcppa = 3-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid), were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Compd. 1 presents a unique binodal (3,6)-connected {43}2{47·88} topol. structure, which is a 2D layer anionic network with Me2NH2+ cations occupying the voids, built upon a trinuclear Cd3 unit. Compds. 2 and 3 are all bimetallic Cd-Ca compds. consisting of tetranuclear Cd2Ca2 units extending to a 3D (3,6)-connected rtl topol. structure and a 2D (3,6)-connected kgd topol. structure, resp. Compds. 4 and 5 are isostructural and exhibit an unprecedented 3D (4,10)-connected topol. structure in which a 1D infinite barium chain is obsd. From the viewpoint of crystal structure diversity and comparison, the authors' results further demonstrate that the coordination modes of metal ions and ligands are the vital elements in forming the final crystal structure. In addn., the thermal stabilities and solid-state luminescence properties of compds. 1-5 are also discussed.

      Seven Coordination Polymers Derived from Semirigid Tetracarboxylic Acids and N-Donor Ligands: Topological Structures, Unusual Magnetic Properties, and Photoluminescences
      Si, Chang-Dai; Hu, Dong-Cheng; Fan, Yan; Wu, Yu; Yao, Xiao-Qiang; Yang, Yun-Xia; Liu, Jia-Cheng
      Crystal Growth & Design (2015), 15 (5), 2419-2432CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Seven new complexes based on H4L1 and H4L2, namely, [Cd2(L1)(H2O)5]n (1), {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O}n (2), {[Cd2(L1)(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)3]·2H2O}n (3), [Zn2(L1)(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)3]n (4), {[Ni7(L1)4(4,4'-bipy)12(H2O)12]·2H2O}n (5), {[Ni1.5(L2)(4,4'-bipy)1.5(H2O)4]·H2O}n (6), and {[Ni9(L2)6(dib)12(H2O)18]·18H2O}n (7) [H4L1 = 4-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy)phthalic acid, H4L2 = 3-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy)phthalic acid, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, dib = 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene], were synthesized by solvothermal reactions. Complex 1 possesses a 4-connected chiral three-dimensional (3D) structure with a Schlafli symbol of (4.63.82). Complex 2 presents a (4,6)-connected porous architecture based on a chair-shaped [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ secondary building unit (SBU) with a Schlafli symbol of (43.63)2(46.66.83), revealing unusual ferromagnetic behavior. Complex 3 exhibits a 2-dimensional → 3-dimensional framework through H-bonding interactions, which is a (3,3,4)-connected 2-fold interpenetrated structure with a Schlafli symbol of (6.82)2(63.83). Complex 4 shows a (3,4,6)-connected (4.64.8)2(62.8)2(42.66.86.10) topol. Complex 5 displays a rare (3,4)-connected polycatenation structure, possessing identical topologies with a Schlafli symbol of (63)(65.8) and weakly ferromagnetic behavior. Complex 6 features a (3,4)-connected 3-dimensional framework with a Schlafli symbol of (4 × 102)2(42.103.12). Complex 7 can be regarded as a (4,4)-connected (63.83)2(85.10) topol. Also, diverse structural topologies were not documented hitherto. The magnetic properties of 2 and 5 are discussed. The fluorescence properties also were analyzed with d. functional theory calcns., indicating that the emissions can be ascribed to intraligand charge transfer for 1 and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer for 3-4.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed From a V-shaped Tripodal Carboxylate Ligand: Syntheses, Structures, Photoluminescent, and Magnetic Properties
      Zhao, Shu-Na; Su, Sheng-Qun; Song, Xue-Zhi; Zhu, Min; Hao, Zhao-Min; Meng, Xing; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhang, Hong-Jie
      Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (7), 2756-2765CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Six novel complexes, namely, {[Zn1.5(L)(bix)0.5(H2O)]·H2O}n (1), {[Co1.5(L)(bix)0.5(H2O)]·H2O}n (2), {[Co3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·5H2O}n (3), {[Cd3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·4.5H2O}n (4), {[Cu3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·3H2O}n (5), and {[Ni1.5(L)(4,4'-bpy)1.5(H2O)3]·2H2O}n (6) were synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of 5-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenoxy)isophthalic acid (H3L) with different transition metal ions in the presence of ancillary ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy). Complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural, possessing a (3,8)-connected tfz-d type topol. with the Schlaefli symbol of {43}2{46·618·84}. The 3-dimensional structures of complexes 3-5 are very similar to complex 1 with only a little difference of the H3L coordination motif in complexes 4 and 5. The authors also use 4,4'-bpy instead of bix as the ancillary ligand in all three complexes. Complex 6 is a mixed 1-dimensional chain and two-dimensional sheet structure, which are further linked to each other in a three-dimensional framework by H-bond interactions. All the complexes were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG anal., and elemental anal. The luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 4 are discussed, and the magnetic properties of complexes 2 and 3 are also studied.

      24b
      Structural Diversity and Luminescence Properties of Coordination Polymers Built With a Rigid Linear Dicarboxylate and Zn(II)/Pb(II) Ion
      Sahu, Jhasaketan; Ahmad, Musheer; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
      Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (6), 2618-2627CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A rigid linear ligand incorporating a carboxylic acid group at either end, 2',5'-dimethyl-p-terphenyl-4,4''-dicarboxylic acid (H2L) was used to construct four coordination polymers with Zn(II) through solvothermal techniques. The four products formed are {[Zn3(L)2(OH)2]·8EtOH·4DMF}n (1), {[Zn(L)(bpmp)0.5]·EtOH·0.5DMF}n (2), {[(Zn)0.5(L)0.5(py)0.5]·5/2DMF·EtOH}n (3), and [Zn(L)(HNMe2)]n (4). With Pb(NO3)2 the ligand affords two polymers, {[Pb2(L)1.5(O)0.5]·EtOH·2H2O}n (5) and {[Pb3(L)3(H2O)]·6H2O}n (6). All of these compds. were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG, elemental anal., and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. Topol. analyses reveal that complex 2 is a 6-connected pcu net, while complexes 3 and 4 are simplified as a 4-connected sql net. In the case of complexes 1 and 6, 1-dimensional rod-shaped metal carboxylate based secondary building units were obtained. However, an uncommon structure and topol. were obtained in complex 5. Surprisingly, such type of parallel ladder-like packing is not explored much in coordination polymers. Solid-state photoluminescence studies were carried out for all of the complexes upon excitation at 347 nm at room temp.

      25
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Fluorescence Detection of Anilines and Photocatalytic Degradation of Rhodamine B by a Multifunctional Metal-Organic Framework
      Wang, Fengqin; Dong, Caifu; Wang, Zechuan; Cui, Yaru; Wang, Chengmiao; Zhao, Yongnan; Li, Guodong
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (36), 6239-6245CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A multifunctional transition metal CdII coordination polymer based on an amide-inserted flexible multicarboxylate ligand, bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)terephthalamide (H4L), [CdL]·[+H2N(CH3)2] (DMF)(H2O)3 (MOF1) was synthesized by the solvothermal method. Its structure was detd. by single-crystal X-ray diffraction anal. and it was characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy and TGA. MOF1 shows selective sensitivity to detecting aniline pollutants in both aq. media and as vapors due to its strong fluorescence emission and microporous structure. In addn., the visible-light-driven photocatalytic degrdn. of Rhodamine B (RhB) by MOF1 and polyaniline (PANI) composite material (named PANI/MOF1), which was prepd. by loading PANI onto the surface of MOF1, was also studied. The results obtained illustrate that PANI/MOF1 exhibits improved photocatalytic activity over MOF1, which could be used to effectively treat wastewater contg. org. dyes in the future.

      Selective adsorption and degradation of Rhodamine B with modified titanium dioxide photocatalyst
      Bao, Lanlan; Meng, Minjia; Sun, Kaiyong; Li, Weibing; Zhao, Dexiang; Li, Huaming; He, Minqiang
      Journal of Applied Polymer Science (2014), 131 (20), 40890/1-40890/12CODEN: JAPNAB; ISSN:0021-8995. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A new highly selective photocatalyst (RhB-MIP/TiO2) was prepd. by surface mol. imprinting technique using Rhodamine B (RhB) as the template mol. The adsorption kinetics show RhB-MIP/TiO2 possessed fast adsorption rate, and adsorption behavior followed the pseudo-2nd-order kinetics. The static binding expts. revealed RhB-MIP/TiO2 displayed strong affinity and high adsorption capacity for RhB. The equil. adsorption rate of RhB-MIP/TiO2 for RhB can be well fitted by the Langmuir isotherm model. The thermodn. parameters indicated that the binding system of RhB-MIP/TiO2 was endothermic and spontaneous. Compared with non-imprinted photocatalyst (NIP/TiO2), RhB-MIP/TiO2 exhibited excellent selectivity toward RhB, whose selectivity coeff. for RhB relative to rhodamine 6G (Rh6G) was 2.99. Selective photocatalytic degrdn. expts. indicated that the apparent rate const. for the photodegrdn. of RhB over RhB-MIP/TiO2 is 0.0212/min, being 216% of that over NIP/TiO2 (0.0098/min). Therefore, RhB-MIP/TiO2 exhibited higher photocatalytic selectivity toward RhB. The prepd. photocatalyst RhB-MIP/TiO2 has a promising perspective in industrial wastewater treatment. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Appl. Polym. Sci. 2014, 131, 40890.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXnvVSrur0%253D&md5=4a3974d686de3530069a14575500df71

      Reactivity and Operational Stability of N-Tailed TAMLs through Kinetic Studies of the Catalyzed Oxidation of Orange II by H2O2: Synthesis and X-ray Structure of an N-Phenyl TAML
      Warner, Genoa R.; Mills, Matthew R.; Enslin, Clarissa; Pattanayak, Shantanu; Panda, Chakadola; Panda, Tamas Kumar; Sen Gupta, Sayam; Ryabov, Alexander D.; Collins, Terrence J.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (16), 6226-6233CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The catalytic activity of the N-tailed (biuret) TAML (tetraamido macrocyclic ligand) activators [Fe{4-XC6H3-1,2-(NCOCMe2NCO)2NR}Cl]2- (3; N atoms in boldface are coordinated to the central iron atom; the same nomenclature is used in for compds. 1 and 2 below), [X, R=H, Me (a); NO2, Me (b); H, Ph (c)] in the oxidative bleaching of Orange II dye by H2O2 in aq. soln. is mechanistically compared with the previously studied activator [Fe{4-XC6H3-1,2-(NCOCMe2NCO)2CMe2}OH2]- (1) and the more aggressive analog [Fe(Me2C{CON(1,2-C6H3-4-X)NCO}2)OH2]- (2). Catalysis by 3 of the reaction between H2O2 and Orange II (S) occurs according to the rate law found generally for TAML activators (v =kIkII[FeIII][S][H2O2]/(kI[H2O2]+kII[S])) and the rate consts. kI and kII at pH 7 both decrease within the series 3 b>3 a>3 c. The pH dependency of kI and kII was studied for 3 a. As with all TAML activators studied to-date, bell-shaped profiles were found for both rate consts. For kI, the maximal activity was found at pH 10.7 marking it as having similar reactivity to 1 a. For kII, the broad bell pH profile exhibits a max. at pH about 10.5. The condition kI«kII holds across the entire pH range studied. Activator 3 b exhibits pronounced activity in neutral to slightly basic aq. solns. making it worthy of consideration on a tech. performance basis for water treatment. The rate consts. ki for suicidal inactivation of the active forms of complexes 3 a-c were calcd. using the general formula ln([S0]/[S∞])=(kII/ki)[FeIII]; here [FeIII], [S0], and [S∞] are the total catalyst concn. and substrate concn. at time zero and infinity, resp. The synthesis and x-ray characterization of 3 c are also described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      UV-Light-Driven Photocatalysts of Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Acylamide-Inserted Multi-Carboxylic Acid
      Wang, Chengmiao; Wang, Fengqin; Dong, Caifu; Yu, Zongchao; Wang, Zechuan; Zhao, Yongnan; Li, Guodong
      Zeitschrift fuer Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie (2015), 641 (6), 1125-1129CODEN: ZAACAB; ISSN:1521-3749. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two functional metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), [Zn·L]·[+H2N(CH3)2]2(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (1) and [Cu2L(H2O)2]·xG (G = solvent mol.) (2) [H4L = bis(3,5-dicarboxypheny1)terephthalamide] were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Their photoresponses in the UV region make them promising candidates for photodegrdn. of Rhodamine B (RhB) under UV light irradation. We studied the photocatalytic activities of the two MOFs and polyaniline (PANI) composite materials (named PANI/MOFs), which were prepd. by loading the PANI on the surface of MOFs. The results indicate that PANI/MOFs composite materials exbibit excellent photostabilities and higher photocatalytic activities than the pure MOFs photocatalysts for degrdn./removal of org. pollutants from wastewaters.

      Nanoscaled Bismuth Oxido Clusters: Probing Factors of Structure Formation and Photocatalytic Activity
      Schlesinger, Maik; Weber, Marcus; Rueffer, Tobias; Lang, Heinrich; Mehring, Michael
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (2), 302-309CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Hydrolysis of bismuth(III) nitrate in the presence of sodium benzoate (NaOBz) in DMSO gave the bismuth oxido cluster [{Bi38O45(NO3)20(OBz)4(DMSO)24}·4DMSO][{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)26}·4DMSO] (1), which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with a 35.8728(12), b 20.2750(5), c 34.8624(11) Å, and β 111.797(4)°. The asym. unit contains two crystallog. independent bismuth oxido clusters of different compn. Because of the distinct structural relation of this type of bismuth oxido clusters with the photocatalytically active polymorph β-Bi2O3, colloidal suspensions of nanoscaled 1 as well as colloids composed of the recently reported clusters [Bi6O4(OH)4(NO3)6]·H2O (2), [{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)26}·2DMSO][{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)24}·0.5DMSO] (3), and [Bi38O45(OMc)24(DMSO)9]·2DMSO·7H2O (4; OMc = methacrylate) were probed for their photocatalytic activity. The bismuth oxido cluster 3 decomps. >85% of a 1 × 10-5M aq. soln. of rhodamine B (RhB) under visible-light irradn. within 150 min. Colloids of such clusters might serve as model compds. for indirect photodegrdn. processes of org. contaminants at the metal oxide surface.

      30a
      Magnetic iron/carbon nanorods derived from a metal organic framework as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the chemical oxidation process in water
      Andrew Lin, Kun-Yi; Hsu, Fu-Kong
      RSC Advances (2015), 5 (63), 50790-50800CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      By one-step carbonization, metal org. frameworks (MOFs) can be conveniently turned into hierarchical hybrid materials which exhibit versatile functionalities. Even though theor. all MOFs can be carbonized to yield carbon-based hybrids, iron-based MOFs seem to be suitable precursors owing to the abundance and low-toxicity of iron. While many iron-based MOFs have been developed, most of these MOFs are synthesized using DMF, a carcinogenic solvent. Thus, an iron-based MOF, MIL-88A, appears to be an ideal precursor because it can be prepd. just in water. MIL-88A-derived carbonaceous material consists of iron oxide nanoparticles and porous carbon, making it a magnetic porous support/adsorbent. However, its iron content and porosity in fact can enable it to be a promising heterogeneous and magnetic catalyst for chem. oxidn., which, however, has not been investigated. Herein, MIL-88A was used to prep. a magnetic iron/carbon nanorod (MICN). The MICN was characterized and then evaluated as a heterogeneous catalyst to activate oxidants, including hydrogen peroxide and sodium persulfate to decolorize Rhodamine B (RB) dye in water. While RB could not be removed via the adsorption to MICN, and degrdn. by oxidants, the combination of MICN and oxidants successfully decolorized RB owing to the iron content of MICN which activated peroxide and persulfate through a Fenton-like reaction. In addn., MICN loading was found to be a more crit. factor than the oxidant dosage for RB decolorization. Elevated temp. also improved the RB decolorization, whereas basic conditions were not favorable for MICN-activated oxidative processes. Ultrasonication represented a useful external facilitator to enhance the decolorization while the addn. of ascorbic acid greatly inhibited the activation process. The recyclability of MICN was also demonstrated, showing that MICN could be reused for multiple cycles without regeneration treatment. These features enable MICN to be an effective and easy-to-recover chem. oxidative catalyst.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXpsV2nsbw%253D&md5=2f2a6bbb4e13571574004a745a369481
      (b) Chen, Y.; Yao, Z.; Miras, H. N.; Song, Y.-F. Chem. - Eur. J. 2015, 21, 10812– 10820 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201501214
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30b
      Modular Polyoxometalate-Layered Double Hydroxide Composites as Efficient Oxidative Catalysts
      Chen, Yang; Yao, Zhixiao; Miras, Haralampos N.; Song, Yu-Fei
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (30), 10812-10820CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The exploitation of intercalation techniques in the field of two-dimensional layered materials offers unique opportunities for controlling chem. reactions in confined spaces and developing nanocomposites with desired functionality. In this study, the exploitation of the novel and facile "one-pot" anion-exchange method for the functionalization of layered double hydroxides (LDHs) is demonstrated. As a proof-of-concept, we demonstrate the intercalation of a series of polyoxometalate (POM) clusters, Na3[PW12O40].15 H2O (Na3PW12), K6[P2W18O62].14 H2O (K6P2W18), and Na9LaW10O36.32 H2O (Na9LaW10) into tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (Tris)-modified layered double hydroxides (LDHs) under ambient conditions without the necessity of degassing CO2. Investigation of the resultant intercalated materials of Tris-LDHs-PW12 (1), Tris-LDH-P2W18 (2), and Tris-LDH-LaW10 (3) for the degrdn. of methylene blue (MB), rhodamine B (RB) and crystal violet (CV) has been carried out, where Tris-LDH-PW12 reveals the best performance in the presence of H2O2. Addnl., degrdn. of a mixt. of RB, MB and CV by Tris-LDH-PW12 follows the order of CV>MB>RB, which is directly related to the designed accessible area of the interlayer space. Also, the composite can be readily recycled and reused at least ten cycles without measurable decrease of activity.

      Removal of Anionic Dyes from Water by Potash Alum Doped Polyaniline: Investigation of Kinetics and Thermodynamic Parameters of Adsorption
      Patra, Braja N.; Majhi, Deola
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2015), 119 (25), 8154-8164CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      Polyaniline was synthesized by the oxidative polymn. method by using ammonium persulfate as an oxidant. The pos. charge in the backbone of the polymer was generated by using Potash alum as a dopant. SEM, Fourier transform IR (FTIR), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques were used for characterization of doped polyaniline. The doped polyaniline can be used for selective adsorption of various dyes (selectively sulfonated dyes) from aq. soln. Adsorption studies regarding the effect of contact time, initial dye concn., pH, doses of adsorbent, and temp. on adsorption kinetics were investigated. The influence of other anions like Cl-, NO3-, and SO42- on the adsorption d. of dyes onto doped polyaniline was also explored. Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetics were found to be the most appropriate models to describe the removal of anionic dyes from water through adsorption. Thermodn. parameters such as free energy (ΔG0), enthalpy (ΔH0), and entropy (ΔS0) changes were also evaluated. The interaction of dyes with doped polyaniline was also investigated by FTIR and UV spectroscopy.

      Facile Fabrication of Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 Type II Heterostructures with High Visible Photocatalytic Activity
      Peng, Yin; Yu, Pian-Pian; Chen, Qing-Guo; Zhou, Hai-Yan; Xu, An-Wu
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (23), 13032-13040CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      One-dimensional (1D) Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 type II heterostructures were synthesized by calcining BiOBr/Bi(OHC2O4)·2H2O heterostructures in air at 400 °C. The photocatalytic activity of the as-prepd. products was evaluated by the degrdn. of phenol and Rhodamine B (RhB) under visible light irradn. The Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 hierarchical heterostructures show enhanced visible light catalytic activity with the increase of the loaded/Bi24O31Br10 content, which results from the efficient sepn. of photogenerated charge carriers due to the staggered band potentials of the two materials. Radical scavenger expts. confirm that photogenerated holes (h+) are the main active species for oxidizing RhB mols. during the photocatalytic processes.

      Supramolecular Fluorescent Nanoparticles Constructed via Multiple Non-Covalent Interactions for the Detection of Hydrogen Peroxide in Cancer Cells
      Wei, Xuan; Dong, Ruijiao; Wang, Dali; Zhao, Tianyu; Gao, Yongsheng; Duffy, Patrick; Zhu, Xinyuan; Wang, Wenxin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (32), 11427-11434CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Overabundance of hydrogen peroxide originating from environmental stress and/or genetic mutation can lead to pathol. conditions. Thus, the highly sensitive detection of H2O2 is important. Herein, supramol. fluorescent nanoparticles self-assembled from fluorescein isothiocyanate modified β-cyclodextrin (FITC-β-CD)/rhodamine B modified ferrocene (Fc-RB) amphiphile were prepd. through host-guest interaction between FITC-β-CD host and Fc-RB guest for H2O2 detection in cancer cells. The self-assembled nanoparticles based on a combination of multiple noncovalent interactions in aq. medium showed high sensitivity to H2O2 while maintaining stability under physiol. condition. Owing to the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) effect, addn. of H2O2 led to obvious fluorescence change of nanoparticles from red (RB) to green (FITC) in fluorescent expts. In vitro study showed the fluorescent nanoparticles could be efficiently internalized by cancer cells and then disrupted by endogenous H2O2, accompanying with FRET from "on" to "off". These supramol. fluorescent nanoparticles constructed via multiple noncovalent interactions are expected to have potential applications in diagnosis and imaging of diseases caused by oxidative stresses.

      Assembly of a basket-like {Sr ⊂ P6Mo18O73} cage from 0D dimer to 2D network and its photo-/electro-catalytic properties
      Zhang, He; Lv, Jing-hua; Yu, Kai; Wang, Chun-mei; Wang, Chun-xiao; Sun, Di; Zhou, Bai-bin
      Dalton Transactions (2015), 44 (28), 12839-12851CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Basket-like heteropoly blues, formulated as (H4bth)[{Cu(H2O)}2{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·4H2O (1), {H2bih}3[{FeII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (2), (H2bih)3[{CoII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (3), (H2bih)3[{NiII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (4), (H2bih)2(H2bip)[{Zn (H2O)0.5}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·5.5H2O (5), (bth = 1,6-bis(triazolyl)hexane; bih = 1,6-bis(imidazolyl)hexane; bip = 1,5-bis(imidazolyl)pentane) were synthesized hydrothermally and fully characterized. The structural anal. shows that all the compds. contain two electron reduced polyanions [Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73]8- (abbreviated as {P6Mo18O73}), which consists of a tetra vacant γ-Dawson-type{P2Mo14} unit and a handle-shaped {P4Mo4} segment encapsulating a Sr2+ cation in the central cavity. Compd. 1 is a 6-connected two-dimensional (2D) layer, which represents the first 2D assembly of basket-type polyoxometalates. Compds. 2-4 are isostructural one-dimensional zigzag chains linked by an M(H2O)2 linker (M = iron for 2, cobalt for 3, and nickel for 4). Compd. 5 is a dimeric cluster supported by a binuclear {Zn2(H2O)} unit. The optical band gaps of 1-5 reveal their semiconductive natures. The compds. if used as photocatalysts exhibit a universal high efficiency degrdn. ability for dyes such as methylene blue, Rhodamine B, and Azophloxine. The lifetime and reaction mechanism of the catalysts were investigated with expts. The compds. also show good bifunctional electrocatalytic behavior for the oxidn. of ascorbic acid (AA) and redn. of nitrite ions.

      Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Materials Based on Basket-like {Ca⊂P6Mo18O73} Cages
      Zhang, He; Yu, Kai; Lv, Jing-hua; Gong, Li-hong; Wang, Chun-mei; Wang, Chun-xiao; Sun, Di; Zhou, Bai-Bin
      Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (14), 6744-6757CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Four basket-like org.-inorg. hybrids, formulated as [{CuII(H2O)2}{Ca4(H2O)4(HO0.5)3(en)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV4Mo14VIO73}]·7H2O (1), (H4bth)[{FeII(H2O)}{Ca⊂P6Mo18VIO73}]·4H2O (2), (H2bih)3[{CuII(H2O)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV2Mo16VIO73}]·2H2O (3), (H2bib)3[{FeII(H2O)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV2 Mo16VIO73}]·4H2O (4), (bth = 1,6-bis(triazole)hexane; bih = 1,6-bis(imidazol)hexane; bib = 1,4-bis(imidazole)butane) were hydrothermally synthesized and fully characterized. Compds. 1-4 contain polyoxoanion [Ca⊂P6MoVnMo18-nVIO73](6+n)- (n = 0, 2, or 4) (abbreviated as {P6Mo18O73}) as a basic building block, which is composed of a basket body {P2Mo14} unit and a handle-like {P4Mo4} fragment encasing an alk.-earth metal Ca2+ cation in the cage. Compd. 1 exhibits an infrequent 2-dimensional layer structure linked by the Cu(H2O)2 linker and an uncommon tetranuclear Ca complex, while compd. 2 is 8-connected 2-dimensional layers connected by binuclear {Fe2(H2O)3} segments, which are obsd. for the first time as 2-dimensional basket-like assemblies. Compds. 3 and 4 are similar 1-dimensional Z-type chains bonded by M(H2O)2 units (M = Cu for 3 and Fe for 4). The optical band gaps of 1-4 reveal their semiconductive natures. They exhibit universal highly efficient degrdn. ability for typical dyes such as methylene blue, Methyl orange, and rhodamine B under UV light. The lifetime and catalysis mechanism of the catalysts were studied. The compds. also show good bifunctional electrocatalytic behavior for oxidn. of amino acids and redn. of NO2-.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFWgsrzN&md5=50daa12c5b6478871b5ab3df8b80931c

      (a) Canivet, J.; Fateeva, A.; Guo, Y.; Coasne, B.; Farrusseng, D. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2014, 43 (16) 5594– 5617 DOI: 10.1039/C4CS00078A

      31a
      Water adsorption in MOFs: fundamentals and applications
      Canivet, Jerome; Fateeva, Alexandra; Guo, Youmin; Coasne, Benoit; Farrusseng, David
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5594-5617CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. This review article presents the fundamental and practical aspects of water adsorption in Metal-Org. Frameworks (MOFs). The state of the art of MOF stability in water, a crucial issue to many applications in which MOFs are promising candidates, is discussed here. Stability in both gaseous (such as humid gases) and aq. media is considered. By considering a non-exhaustive yet representative set of MOFs, the different mechanisms of water adsorption in this class of materials are presented: reversible and continuous pore filling, irreversible and discontinuous pore filling through capillary condensation, and irreversibility arising from the flexibility and possible structural modifications of the host material. Water adsorption properties of more than 60 MOF samples are reported. The applications of MOFs as materials for heat-pumps and adsorbent-based chillers and proton conductors are also reviewed. Some directions for future work are suggested as concluding remarks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Slu7bO&md5=28aa081a483b68086bf3e93369d02a11
      (b) Feng, D.; Gu, Z.-Y.; Li, J.-R.; Jiang, H.-L.; Wei, Z.; Zhou, H.-C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2012, 51 (41) 10307– 10310 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201204475
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31b
      Zirconium-Metalloporphyrin PCN-222: Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Ultrahigh Stability as Biomimetic Catalysts
      Feng, Dawei; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Li, Jian-Rong; Jiang, Hai-Long; Wei, Zhangwen; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2012), 51 (41), 10307-10310, S10307/1-S10307/46CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Zirconium-metalloporphyrin PCN-222 mesoporous metal-org. frameworks with ultrahigh stability as biomimetic catalysts are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1aqtLvK&md5=1f53cd17d6e9bf7e130b29acdafc98cb
      (c) Jasuja, H.; Burtch, N. C.; Huang, Y.-g.; Cai, Y.; Walton, K. S. Langmuir 2013, 29 (2) 633– 642 DOI: 10.1021/la304204k
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31c
      Kinetic Water Stability of an Isostructural Family of Zinc-Based Pillared Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Jasuja, Himanshu; Burtch, Nicholas C.; Huang, You-gui; Cai, Yang; Walton, Krista S.
      Langmuir (2013), 29 (2), 633-642CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      The rational design of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with structural stability in the presence of humid conditions is crit. to the commercialization of this class of materials. However, the systematic water stability studies required to develop design criteria for the construction of water-stable MOFs are still scarce. In this work, the authors show that by varying the functional groups on the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) linker of DMOF [Zn(BDC)(DABCO)0.5], they can systematically tune the kinetic water stability of this isostructural, pillared family of MOFs. To illustrate this concept, water adsorption studies were performed on four novel, methyl-functionalized DMOF variations along with a no. of already reported functionalized analogs contg. polar (fluorine) and nonpolar (methyl) functional groups on the BDC ligand. These results are distinctly different from previous reports where the apparent water stability is improved through the inclusion of functional groups such as -CH3, -C2H5, and -CF3 which only serve to prevent significant amts. of water from adsorbing into the pores. In this study, the authors present the first demonstration of tuning the inherent kinetic stability of MOF structures in the presence of large amts. of adsorbed water. Notably, while the parent DMOF structure is unstable, the DMOF variation contg. the tetra-Me BDC ligand remains fully stable after adsorbing large amts. of water vapor during cyclic water adsorption cycles. These trends cannot be rationalized in terms of hydrophobicity alone; exptl. water isotherms show that MOFs contg. the same no. of Me groups per unit cell will have different kinetic stabilities and that the precise placements of the Me groups on the BDC ligand are therefore critically important in detg. their stability in the presence of water. Water adsorption isotherms, PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction) patterns, and BET surface areas before and after water exposure are presented to illustrate these trends. Furthermore, the important distinction between kinetic and thermodn. stability in MOFs is discussed. Mol. simulations are also used to provide insight into the structural characteristics governing these trends in kinetic water stability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslyltLbK&md5=dd3cb8bf8450c769ce9f5856751aedab
      (d) Mondloch, J. E.; Katz, M. J.; Planas, N.; Semrouni, D.; Gagliardi, L.; Hupp, J. T.; Farha, O. K. Chem. Commun. 2014, 50 (64) 8944– 8946 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC02401J
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31d
      Are Zr6-based MOFs water stable? Linker hydrolysis vs. capillary-force-driven channel collapse
      Mondloch, Joseph E.; Katz, Michael J.; Planas, Nora; Semrouni, David; Gagliardi, Laura; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (64), 8944-8946CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two Zr6-based frameworks, UiO-67 and NU-1000, are shown to be stable towards linker hydrolysis in water, but collapse during activation from water. This framework collapse can be overcome by utilizing solvent exchange to solvents exhibiting lower capillary forces such as acetone.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtVOnsrrI&md5=60fc1aa723ce457f38084e51927915ff

      Li, X. Q.; Zhang, Q. H.; Ma, K.; Li, H. M.; Guo, Z. Food Chem. 2015, 182, 316– 326 DOI: 10.1016/j.foodchem.2015.03.019
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Identification and determination of 34 water-soluble synthetic dyes in foodstuff by high performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection-ion trap time-of-flight tandem mass spectrometry
      Li, Xiu Qin; Zhang, Qing He; Ma, Kang; Li, Hong Mei; Guo, Zhen
      Food Chemistry (2015), 182 (), 316-326CODEN: FOCHDJ; ISSN:0308-8146. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      An accurate method combining high performance liq. chromatog. (HPLC) with diode array detection (DAD) and ion-trap time-of-flight mass spectrometry (IT-TOF/MS) was developed for simultaneous identification and quantification of 34 water-sol. synthetic dyes in foodstuff. Fragmentation patterns of synthetic dyes were proposed based on IT-TOF/MS. The mol. ion [M+H]+ was not obsd. in the conventional single-stage mass spectra for most of synthetic dyes. The single-stage mass spectra of synthetic dyes all afforded the diagnostic ions [(M-nNa+nH)+H]+ or [(M-nNa+nH)-H]- in the pos. or neg. mode. Doubly charged ions were the characteristic ions of azo dyes. An HPLC-DAD method was developed to analyze 34 synthetic dyes in foodstuffs. The limits of detection (LOD) for the dyes were 0.01-0.05 μg/mL. The recoveries were between 76.1% and 105.0% with a RSD ranging from 1.4% to 6.4%. This method was successfully applied to analyzing the 34 water-sol. synthetic dyes in 21 com. foods.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (a) Inchaurrondo, N.; Font, J.; Ramos, C. P.; Haure, P. Appl. Catal., B 2016, 181, 481– 494 DOI: 10.1016/j.apcatb.2015.08.022
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33a
      Natural diatomites: Efficient green catalyst for Fenton-like oxidation of Orange II
      Inchaurrondo, N.; Font, J.; Ramos, C. P.; Haure, P.
      Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental (2016), 181 (), 481-494CODEN: ACBEE3; ISSN:0926-3373. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The Fenton-like oxidn. of the anionic azo-dye Orange II (100-500 mg/L) was batchwise performed using com. grade diatomites (3.5% Fe content) thermally treated. Solid samples were thoroughly characterized by several techniques. Peroxidn. expts. were performed varying the diatomite calcination temp. (500, 700, 1000°), reaction temp. (50, 60, 70, 80°), catalyst load (0.47, 0.94, 1.89 and 3.78 g), H2O2 concn. (11.0, 13.7, 20.6 mmol/L) and dosing, pH (2-3.5) and initial dye concn. (0.28, 0.57, 1.43 mmol/L). The effect of NaCl and oxalic acid on the catalytic performance and stability was also addressed. The best results were obtained with samples calcined at 700°, with initial pH 3, at 70° and using the stoichiometric amt. of H2O2, since complete decolorization, TOC redn. close to 67% and negligible Fe leaching were achieved. The stability of the catalyst maintains after 20 h of usage, with a final Fe loss of 2.25%. An av. of 0.88 mg/L Fe leached after each run, which is below the discharge limit.

      (b) Le, T. X. H.; Bechelany, M.; Lacour, S.; Oturan, N.; Oturan, M. A.; Cretin, M. Carbon 2015, 94, 1003– 1011 DOI: 10.1016/j.carbon.2015.07.086

      33b
      High removal efficiency of dye pollutants by electron-Fenton process using a graphene based cathode
      Le, Thi Xuan Huong; Bechelany, Mikhael; Lacour, Stella; Oturan, Nihal; Oturan, Mehmet A.; Cretin, Marc
      Carbon (2015), 94 (), 1003-1011CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A new cathode for electro-Fenton process was set up by electrochem. deposition of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) on the surface of C felt (CF). The structure and properties of modified electrode was studied. Among the different redn. methods used, the const. potential technique demonstrated significant advantages. The parameters affecting the conversion of GO to rGO, such as pH, applied potential and duration of the redn. process, were examd. The rGO modified cathode presents enhanced electrochem. properties like an increase of the redox current and a decrease of the charge transfer resistance in presence of the redox probe [Fe(CN)6]3-/[Fe(CN)6]4- showing better kinetic properties compared to raw CF. This improvement enhanced significantly the prodn. of H2O2, a key parameter in electro-Fenton (EF) process, which was confirmed by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) anal. Therefore, the use of graphene modified cathode could decolorize efficiently Acid Orange 7, a model azo dye mol., within only 5 min and almost completely mineralized (94.3%) it in 8 h treatment under optimal c.d. applied. The new cathode exhibited good stability as the mineralization ratio in 2 h that was still >64% after 10 cycles degrdn., showing that this rGO-CF is a powerful and promising electrode for improving the removal efficiency of dyes using EF technol.

      (a) Jiang, T.; Poyraz, A. S.; Iyer, A.; Zhang, Y.; Luo, Z.; Zhong, W.; Miao, R.; El-Sawy, A. M.; Guild, C. J.; Sun, Y.; Kriz, D. A.; Suib, S. L. J. Phys. Chem. C 2015, 119 (19) 10454– 10468 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b02057
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34a
      Synthesis of Mesoporous Iron Oxides by an Inverse Micelle Method and Their Application in the Degradation of Orange II under Visible Light at Neutral pH
      Jiang, Ting; Poyraz, Altug S.; Iyer, Aparna; Zhang, Yashan; Luo, Zhu; Zhong, Wei; Miao, Ran; El-Sawy, Abdelhamid M.; Guild, Curtis J.; Sun, Yu; Kriz, David A.; Suib, Steven L.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (19), 10454-10468CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Mesoporous iron oxides (2-line ferrihydrite, α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3, and Fe3O4) are successfully synthesized by modifying the reaction temps. and calcination atmospheres of the sol-gel-based inverse micelle method. Different characterization techniques, such as PXRD, N2 sorption, SEM, HRTEM, Raman spectroscopy, and XANES, are performed to det. the properties of the catalysts. Larger pore sizes can be obtained in mesoporous γ-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 compared with mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite and α-Fe2O3. The catalytic performance of mesoporous iron oxides are examd. as Fenton catalysts in orange II degrdn. in the presence of oxidant H2O2 at neutral pH under visible light. Adsorption capacities of mesoporous iron oxides on orange II are greater than that of com. Fe2O3. The greatest adsorption capacity is found to be 49.3 mg/g with mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite. In addn., the degrdn. efficiency of orange II is found to be markedly improved by mesoporous iron oxides compared with the com. catalyst. In the best case scenario, 2-line ferrihydrite shows the highest degrdn. rate const. (0.0258 min-1) among all the catalysts tested. The excellent performance of 2-line ferrihydrite is mainly attributed to the larger surface area but also related to surface hydroxyl groups, acidic products, and possible addnl. adsorption sites. The recyclability of mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite catalyst can be achieved up to 3 times without performance decay. At last, a discussion regarding the possible mechanisms of degrdn. of orange II over mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite is proposed, based on the previous literature work and the obsd. reaction intermediates monitored by ESI/MS in this study.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXntVCgtro%253D&md5=c4210a226497191b8c8fb43718f68738
      (b) Su, Y.; Wu, Z.; Wu, Y.; Yu, J.; Sun, L.; Lin, C. J. Mater. Chem. A 2015, 3 (16) 8537– 8544 DOI: 10.1039/C5TA00839E
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34b
      Acid Orange II degradation through a heterogeneous Fenton-like reaction using Fe-TiO2 nanotube arrays as a photocatalyst
      Su, Yufeng; Wu, Zhi; Wu, Yongneng; Yu, Jiangdong; Sun, Lan; Lin, Changjian
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2015), 3 (16), 8537-8544CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The photocatalytic degrdn. of the non-biodegradable azo dye Acid Orange II (AO II) was performed via a heterogeneous Fenton-like process using Fe incorporated TiO2 nanotube arrays (Fe-TiO2 NTAs) as a photocatalyst in the presence of H2O2 under UV irradn. Fe-TiO2 NTAs were prepd. by an ultrasound-assisted impregnating-calcination method. The effects of reaction conditions including the amt. of Fe incorporated into TiO2 NTAs, initial concn. of H2O2, and initial pH of the AO II soln. on the photocatalytic degrdn. rate of AO II were investigated. The results revealed that the Fe-TiO2 NTAs prepd. by ultrasonic deposition for 25 min exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity compared with pure TiO2 NTA and other Fe-TiO2 NTA samples. In the presence of H2O2, the photocatalytic degrdn. rate of AO II was significantly enhanced. About 80% AO II can be decompd. at pH 2.96 using Fe-TiO2 NTAs prepd. by ultrasonic deposition for 25 min as a photocatalyst with 3mM H2O2 after 120 min of UV irradn., which was 1.7 times higher than that without H2O2 (∼30%). Very interestingly, there was an obvious synergistic effect between the photocatalytic process of Fe-TiO2 NTAs and H2O2 oxidn. The Fe-TiO2 NTA photocatalyst exhibited excellent stability in the heterogeneous Fenton-like process. Thus, we demonstrated that the heterogeneous Fenton-like process combining the Fe-TiO2 NTA photocatalyst with H2O2 oxidn. has a promising application in practical wastewater treatment.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlt1agurY%253D&md5=870957f44ab9e60e1c92233e76770a00
      (c) Yao, Y.; Lu, F.; Zhu, Y.; Wei, F.; Liu, X.; Lian, C.; Wang, S. J. Hazard. Mater. 2015, 297, 224– 233 DOI: 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2015.04.046
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Magnetic core-shell CuFe2O4@C3N4 hybrids for visible light photocatalysis of Orange II
      Yao, Yunjin; Lu, Fang; Chen, Hao; Wei, Fengyu; Liu, Xueting; Lian, Chao; Wang, Shaobin
      Journal of Hazardous Materials (2015), 297 (), 224-233CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Novel CuFe2O4@C3N4 core-shell photocatalysts were fabricated through a self-assembly method and characterized by x-ray diffraction, FTIR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric anal., XPS, transmission electron microscopy and Uv-vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy. The photocatalytic performances of the CuFe2O4@C3N4 catalysts were evaluated in photoFenton-like decolorization of Orange II dye using H2O2 as an oxidant under visible-light irradn. (λ >420 nm). It was found the CuFe2O4@C3N4 hybrid (mass ratio of CuFe2O4/g-C3N4 at 2:1) exhibits a superior activity as compared with single component of CuFe2O4 or g-C3N4 and the mixt. of g-C3N4 and CuFe2O4, due to the elevation of the sepn. efficiency of photoinduced electron-hole pairs, resulted from the heterojunction between the interfaces of g-C3N4 and CuFe2O4. The quenching tests of different scavengers displayed that O2•-, ·OH and h+ are responsible for the Orange II decolorization. The effects of initial concn. of the dye concn. (0.014-0.140mM), different anions (Cl-, SO42-, NO3-, CH3COO- and HCO3-) and temp. (15-65°) in photoreaction were studied. The CuFe2O4@C3N4 sample exhibited stable performance without obvious loss of catalytic activity after 5 successive runs, showing a promising application for the photo-oxidative degrdn. of environmental contaminants.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Synthesis, structure and adsorption of coordination polymers constructed from 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and Zn ions
      Xing, Feifei; Jia, Juan; Liu, Licong; Zhong, Lina; Shao, Min; Bai, Yue-ling; Zhao, Yongmei; Zhu, Shourong; He, Xiang; Li, Mingxing
      CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (24), 4970-4980CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      3,3',5,5'-Azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc) was synthesized by redn. of 5-nitroisophthalic acid in basic aq./ethanol soln. in the presence of Zn powder. Three novel coordination polymers {[Zn2(η6-ao2btc)(η2-2,2'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·2H2O}1n (1), {[Zn2(η8-aobtc)(η2-phen)(H2O)]·DMF}3n (2), and {(Hap)2[Zn3(η9-aobtc)2]·2H2O}3n (3) (2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, ap = 4-aminopyridine, ao2btc4- and aobtc4- are two oxidized forms of H4abtc ligand) were prepd. under hydrothermal conditions. The structures of 1-3 were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Complex 1 is a 1-dimensional chain polymer, while 2 and 3 are porous 3-dimensional metal-org. frameworks with a cavity size of 9 Å diam. and 7 × 15 Å rectangular cavities, resp. In 1, ao2btc4- links four mononuclear ZnO6 chromophores. Ligand aobtc4- in 2 links four dinuclear Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)N2, while aobtc4- in 3 bridges four trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8. From a topol. point of view, ao2btc4- or aobtc4- are all 4-connected linkers in 1-3, while the mononuclear ZnO6 in 1, dinuclear Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)N2 in 2 and trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8 in 3 are 2, 4 and 8 connected nodes, resp. Zn(II) in complex 2 can be replaced by Cu(II), Ni(II) and Co(II) with simultaneous loss of crystallinity. The metal ion exchange rate decrease in the order Co(II) < Ni(II) < Cu(II). Complex 2 can encapsulate iodine (I2) in cyclohexane soln. to form 2∋0.1I2. The encapsulated I2 can be released completely in ethanol. The Hap+ in 3 can be replaced by methylene blue in aq. soln. to form 3∋0.1methylene blue. The insignificant replacement is an indication that the guest mol. in the cavity channel is immobile, which prevents further substitution. With a bis-oxo group in the azo moiety, the framework of 1 is so unstable that it will decomp. at ∼150° with simultaneous release of NO. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable at 330°. IR and fluorescence spectra are also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXot1eqtbg%253D&md5=2feaa3220559f52cae878b6f574f9ad5

      36
      Oxidation of aromatic amines with hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by cetylpyridinium heteropolyoxometalates
      Sakaue, Sigeki; Tsubakino, Takashi; Nishiyama, Yutaka; Ishii, Yasutaka
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1993), 58 (14), 3633-8CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      Various substituted anilines XC6H4NH2 (I, X = H, 4-Me, 4-NO2, 2-CO2Me, etc.) were selectively converted into the corresponding nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N(O):N(O)C6H4X (II) or nitrobenzenes XC6H4NO2 (III) by oxidn. with aq. hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by heteropolyoxometalates. The oxidns. of I with 35% H2O2 catalyzed by peroxotungstophosphate (PCWP) at room temp. in chloroform under two-phase conditions afforded II with high selectivity. When the same reactions were carried out at higher temp. (e.g., refluxing chloroform), III were obtained in good yields. The oxidn. of PhNH2 with dil. H2O2 catalyzed by PCWP (2 wt %) in an aq. medium produced azoxybenzene, PhN(O):NPh with high selectivity. Phenylazoxyalkanes 4-XC6H4N(O):NR (R = Bu, n-hexyl, cyclohexyl, X = H, Me, Cl) were prepd. by the first direct cooxidn. of PhNH2 in the presence of primary aliph. amines RNH2. The reaction path for the conversion of anilines to azoxy-, nitroso-, and nitrobenzenes is described.

      37
      The oxidation of azoketones and azonitriles
      Angeli, A.
      Atti della Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei, Classe di Scienze Fisiche, Matematiche e Naturali, Rendiconti (1915), 24 (I), 1185-90CODEN: AANLAW; ISSN:0001-4435.
      In order to extend his expts. on the action of peracetic acid on the azo derivs. A. has studied its action on RN:NC6H4Ac, RN:NC6H4CN, RN:NC6H4CH2CN, RN:NC6H4NMe2, RN:NCN, and RN:N:N in which R for the present is an aromatic residue. The results with the ketones and nitriles are reported here. It was found that in order to limit the oxidation to the azo group it was necessary to work in dil. AcOH at not high temps. In this way PhN:NC6H4Ac gives PhN(:O):NC6H4Ac (a), m. 92°, and PhN:N(:O)C6H4Ac (b), m. 132°, and PhN:- NC6H4CH2CN gives PhN(:O)NC6H4CH2CN (C), in. 94°, and PhN:N(:O)C6H4CH2CN (d), m. 132°. Their structure was easily detd. by oxidizing with KMnO4 in alk. soln. by which the side chains were transformed into CO2H and the acids PhN(:O)NC6H4CO2H and PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H were obtained which were identical with those previously obtained by the oxidation of the azo acid (A. and Valori, C. A. 7, 2223). The azoketone, PhN:NC6H4Ac, prepd. by condensing equimol. amts. of PhNO and p-NH2C6H4Ac in AcOH, rose laminas from EtOH, m. 115°; with NH2OH it gives an oxime, PhN2C6H4C(:NOH)Me, m. 169°. The azoketone oxidized in AcOH with perhydrol gave 2 isomeric azoxy compounds that were sepd. by their different soly. in EtOH; the less sol. (b) recrystd. from C6H6 m. 132°; the other (a) purified from ligroin, m. 92°. (b) gave an oxime, m. 181°. (b) oxidized with KMnO4 in the presence of a little KOH gave a yellow liquid which on treatment with dil. H2SO4 sepd. PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H, which for better identification was converted with Br into p-BrC6H4N:N(:O)C6H4CO2H. Both (a) and (b) give on treatment with. H2SO4 p-HOC6H4N2C6H4Ac; red, sol. in alkalies, m. 134°. Similarly condensation of PhNO with p-H2NC6H4Bz gives the azoketone PhN:NC6H4Bz, m. 106°, which with H2O2 gives an azoxy compd., m. 72°. Lack of material prevented a further study. The azonitrile, PhN:NC6H4CH2CN, was obtained by condensing PhNO with p-H2NC6H4CH2CN, as orange-red laminas, m. 127°. Oxidized with H2O2 it gave 2 isomeric azoxy compounds, (c) and (d), that were purified by recrystn. from C6H6. The more sol. one (c) m. 94° and the less sol. one (d) m. 132°. (d) oxidized with KMnO4 gives PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H which thus dets. the structure of these isomers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaC28XntVSk&md5=9bf214fa7ed7e43cc014335a4b1cc046
