      1. 1
        Kajiwara, T.; Higuchi, M.; Yuasa, A.; Higashimura, H.; Kitagawa, S. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49 (89) 10459– 10461 DOI: 10.1039/c3cc43384f
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        One-dimensional alignment of strong Lewis acid sites in a porous coordination polymer
        Kajiwara, Takashi; Higuchi, Masakazu; Yuasa, Akihiro; Higashimura, Hideyuki; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (89), 10459-10461CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new lanthanoid porous coordination polymer, [La(BTTc)(DMF)·x(solv)]∞ [BTTc = benzene-1,3,5-tris(2-thiophene-5-carboxylate), solv = water, acetone, DMF, nitrogen, ammonia, ethanol], was synthesized and structurally characterized to have densely aligned one-dimensional open metal sites. La(BTTc)(DMF) 1 acts as strong Lewis acid after the removal of the coordinated solvent and reacts with 1-hexene. Compd. 1 was used as a catalyst for the cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde. Addnl., three compds. with cerium, praseodymium, and neodymium [Ln(BTTc)(DMF)·DMFx] (Ln = Ce, Pr, Nd; x = 2 for Ce) were also synthesized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1WlsbvI&md5=8bb1b635ec55c4e2695c7e37d7f7953f
      2. 2
        (a) Ranocchiari, M.; van Bokhoven, J. A. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2011, 13 (14) 6388– 6396 DOI: 10.1039/c0cp02394a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2a
        Catalysis by metal-organic frameworks: fundamentals and opportunities
        Ranocchiari, Marco; van Bokhoven, Jeroen Anton
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2011), 13 (14), 6388-6396CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Cryst. porous materials are extremely important for developing catalytic systems with high scientific and industrial impact. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show unique potential that still has to be fully exploited. This perspective summarizes the properties of MOFs with the aim to understand what are possible approaches to catalysis with these materials. We categorize three classes of MOF catalysts: (1) those with active site on the framework, (2) those with encapsulated active species, and (3) those with active sites attached through post-synthetic modification. We identify the tunable porosity, the ability to fine tune the structure of the active site and its environment, the presence of multiple active sites, and the opportunity to synthesize structures in which key-lock bonding of substrates occurs as the characteristics that distinguish MOFs from other materials. We experience a unique opportunity to imagine and design heterogeneous catalysts, which might catalyze reactions previously thought impossible.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjsFKkt70%253D&md5=369df768bec6816f8793240dfba1aa00
        (b) Zou, R.-Q.; Sakurai, H.; Xu, Q. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45 (16) 2542– 2546 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200503923
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2b
        Preparation, adsorption properties, and catalytic activity of three-dimensional porous metal-organic frameworks composed of cubic building blocks and alkali-metal ions
        Zou, Ru-Qiang; Sakurai, Hiroaki; Xu, Qiang
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (16), 2542-2546CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Unexpected catalytic activity for the oxidn. of CO to CO2 is exhibited by one of two novel three-dimensional porous metal-org. frameworks in which [Ni8L12]20- (H3L = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid) cubic building blocks (CBBs) are linked by Li1 or Na1 ions. The clathrating ability towards Li1 ions of such CBBs is seen in the powder XRD x-ray crystal structure, which simulates the potential guest-bonding sites in the building blocks of the MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvVCmsbs%253D&md5=e3e928162fa9a39ecd0553ca1f65a7b1
        (c) Wang, S.; Wang, X. Small 2015, 11 (26) 3097– 3112 DOI: 10.1002/smll.201500084
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2c
        Multifunctional Metal-Organic Frameworks for Photocatalysis
        Wang, Sibo; Wang, Xinchen
        Small (2015), 11 (26), 3097-3112CODEN: SMALBC; ISSN:1613-6810. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant research attention in diverse areas due to their unique phys. and chem. characteristics that allow their innovative application in various research fields. Recently, the application of MOFs in heterogeneous photocatalysis for water splitting, CO2 redn., and org. transformation have emerged, aiming at providing alternative solns. to address the world-wide energy and environmental problems by taking advantage of the unique porous structure together with ample physicochem. properties of the metal centers and org. ligands in MOFs. In this review, the latest progress in MOF-involved solar-to-chem. energy conversion reactions are summarized according to their different roles in the photoredox chem. systems, e.g., photocatalysts, co-catalysts, and hosts. The achieved progress and existing problems are evaluated and proposed, and the opportunities and challenges of MOFs and their related materials for their advanced development in photocatalysis are discussed and anticipated.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXnt1SlsLw%253D&md5=a58fd955a4772a34ca52d69b66fb58e7
      3. 3
        (a) Sivakumar, S.; Reddy, M. L. P.; Cowley, A. H.; Vasudevan, K. V. Dalton Trans. 2010, 39 (3) 776– 786 DOI: 10.1039/B917256D
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3a
        Synthesis and crystal structures of lanthanide 4-benzyloxy benzoates: Influence of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups on luminescent properties
        Sivakumar, Sarika; Reddy, M. L. P.; Cowley, Alan H.; Vasudevan, Kalyan V.
        Dalton Transactions (2010), 39 (3), 776-786CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Three new 4-benzyloxy HOBz derivs. [4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL1; 3-methoxy-4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL2; 3-nitro-4-benzyloxybenzoic acid = HL3] were employed as ligands for the support of six lanthanide coordination compds. [Tb3+ = 1-3; Eu3+ = 4-6] with the aim of testing the influence of electron releasing (-OMe) or electron withdrawing (-NO2) substituents on the photophys. properties. The new complexes were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic techniques and two of the Tb3+ complexes [1 and 2] were structurally authenticated by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Compds. 1 and 2 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/n and their mol. structures consist of homodinuclear species that are bridged by two O atoms from two benzoate ligands. In the case of 1, the carboxylate ligands coordinate to the central Tb3+ ion in bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes. By contrast, three different coordination modes (bidentate chelating, bidentate bridging and monodentate) are obsd. in the case of compd. 2. Examn. of the packing diagrams for 1 and 2 revealed a 1-dimensional mol. array that is held together by intermol. H-bonding interactions. The incorporation of an electron-releasing substituent on position 3 of 4-benzyloxybenzoic acid increases the electron d. of the ligand and consequently improves the photoluminescence of the Tb3+ complexes. However, the presence of an electron-withdrawing group at this position dramatically decreases the overall sensitization efficiency of the Tb3+-centered luminescence due to dissipation of the excitation energy by a π*-n transition of the NO2 substituent along with the participation of the ILCT bands. The weaker photoluminescence of the Eu3+ complexes is attributable to the poor match of the triplet energy levels of the 4-benzyloxybenzoic acid derivs. with that of the emitting level of the central metal ion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsF2isLbM&md5=8ea922262dc0fc77dd38a18ac6532b28
        (b) Rocha, J.; Carlos, L. D.; Paz, F. A. A.; Ananias, D. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2011, 40 (2) 926– 940 DOI: 10.1039/C0CS00130A
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        Luminescent multifunctional lanthanides-based metal-organic frameworks
        Rocha, Joao; Carlos, Luis D.; Paz, Filipe A. Almeida; Ananias, Duarte
        Chemical Society Reviews (2011), 40 (2), 926-940CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks based on trivalent lanthanides (LnMOFs) are a very promising class of materials for addressing the challenges in engineering of luminescent centers. Lanthanide-bearing phosphors find numerous applications in lighting, optical communications, photonics and biomedical devices. In this crit. review we discuss the potential of LnMOFs as multifunctional systems, which combine light emission with properties such as microporosity, magnetism, chirality, mol. and ion sensing, catalysis and activity as multimodal imaging contrast agents. We argue that these materials present a unique chance of observing synergy between several of these properties, such as the coupling between photoluminescence and magnetism. Moreover, an integrated approach towards the design of efficient, stable, cheap, environmentally-friendly and multifunctional luminescent LnMOFs is still missing. Although research into LnMOFs is at its early stage and much basic knowledge is still needed, the field is ripe for new ideas, which will enable sensor devices and photonic prototypes to become a com. reality (81 refs.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXptFSktA%253D%253D&md5=58a208684663b39fc48fc3ae96fda4b1
        (c) Chen, B.; Yang, Y.; Zapata, F.; Qian, G.; Luo, Y.; Zhang, J.; Lobkovsky, E. B. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45 (22) 8882– 8886 DOI: 10.1021/ic060568u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        Enhanced near-infrared-luminescence in an erbium tetrafluoroterephthalate framework
        Chen, Banglin; Yang, Yu; Zapata, Fatima; Qian, Guodong; Luo, Yongshi; Zhang, Jiahua; Lobkovsky, Emil B.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (22), 8882-8886CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two Er-org. frameworks Er2(BDC)3(DMF)2(H2O)2.H2O (1) and Er2(BDC-F4)3(DMF)(H2O).DMF (2) (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; BDC-F4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate or tetrafluoroterephthalate; DMF = DMF) were synthesized and structurally characterized. Studies on TGA and the spectroscopic and luminescent properties of 1, 2, and their desolvated solid Er2(BDC)3 (1a) and partially desolvated solid Er2(BDC-F4)3(DMF).DMF (2a) indicate that fluorination can significantly improve the luminescence intensity of the Er ions by reducing the fluorescence quenching effect of the vibrational C-H bond; thus, the near-IR-luminescence intensity of 2a is 3 times higher than that of 1a.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XpvFKisLY%253D&md5=b8547e9bea917e9224c5cd942e8ae0fb
        (d) Liu, C. B.; Ferreira, R. A. S.; Almeida Paz, F. A.; Cadiau, A.; Carlos, L. D.; Fu, L. S.; Rocha, J.; Shi, F. N. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48 (64) 7964– 7966 DOI: 10.1039/c2cc33223j
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3d
        Highly emissive Zn-Ln metal-organic frameworks with an unusual 3D inorganic subnetwork
        Liu, C. B.; Ferreira, R. A. S.; Almeida Paz, F. A.; Cadiau, A.; Carlos, L. D.; Fu, L. S.; Rocha, J.; Shi, F.-N.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (64), 7964-7966CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Mixed Zn-lanthanide (Zn-Ln) metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) based on the 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylate ligand exhibit an unusual three-dimensional (3D) inorg. subnetwork and display highly efficient photoluminescence.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVegtb7N&md5=92f7cd13d164ccf808469431809dcc02
      4. 4
        (a) Sumida, K.; Rogow, D. L.; Mason, J. A.; McDonald, T. M.; Bloch, E. D.; Herm, Z. R.; Bae, T.-H.; Long, J. R. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112 (2) 724– 781 DOI: 10.1021/cr2003272
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4a
        Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs12hsLzE&md5=eb8236e7dfe12981387c71415374f958
        (b) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295 (5554) 469– 472 DOI: 10.1126/science.1067208
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4b
        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
        (c) Millward, A. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127 (51) 17998– 17999 DOI: 10.1021/ja0570032
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4c
        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
        Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (51), 17998-17999CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp. Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar. Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm. The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns. The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2. Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GktLnJ&md5=ad433b990b72836a16c8647c09ec85f2
        (d) Miller, S. R.; Pearce, G. M.; Wright, P. A.; Bonino, F.; Chavan, S.; Bordiga, S.; Margiolaki, I.; Guillou, N.; Ferey, G.; Bourrelly, S.; Llewellyn, P. L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130 (47) 15967– 15981 DOI: 10.1021/ja804936z
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4d
        Structural Transformations and Adsorption of Fuel-Related Gases of a Structurally Responsive Nickel Phosphonate Metal-Organic Framework, Ni-STA-12
        Miller, Stuart R.; Pearce, Gordon M.; Wright, Paul A.; Bonino, Francesca; Chavan, Sachin; Bordiga, Silvia; Margiolaki, Irene; Guillou, Nathalie; Ferey, Gerard; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (47), 15967-15981CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The structure of the Ni N,N'-piperazinebismethylenephosphonate, Ni-STA-12 (St. Andrews porous material-12), was detd. in the hydrated (Ni2L·8H2O, L = O3PCH2NC4H8NCH2PO3), partially dehydrated (Ni2L·2H2O), and fully dehydrated (Ni2L) forms from high-resoln. synchrotron x-ray powder diffraction. The framework structures of Ni2L·8H2O and Ni2L·2H2O are almost identical (R‾3, a 27.8342(1), c 6.2421(2) Å; R‾3, a 27.9144(1), c 6.1655(2) Å) with addnl. physisorbed H2O of the as-prepd. Ni-STA-12 present in an ordered H-bonded network in the channels. Ab initio structure soln. of the fully dehydrated solid indicates it has changed symmetry to triclinic (P‾1, a 6.03475(5), b 14.9157(2), c 16.1572(2) Å, α 112.5721(7), β 95.7025(11), γ 96.4950(11)°) as a result of a topotactic structural rearrangement. The fully dehydrated solid possesses permanent porosity with elliptical channels 8 Å × 9 Å in free diam. The structural change results from the loss of H2O coordinated to the Ni cations, so that the Ni coordination changes from edge-sharing octahedral NiO5N to edge- and corner-sharing 5-fold NiO4N. During this change, two out of three phosphonate groups rotate to become fully coordinated to Ni cations, leaving the remainder of the phosphonate groups coordinated to Ni cations by two O atoms and with a P=O bond projecting into the channels. This transformation, which is completely reversible, causes substantial changes in both vibrational and electronic properties as shown by IR, Raman, and UV-visible spectroscopies. Complementary adsorption, calorimetric, and IR studies of the probe adsorbates H2, CO, and CO2 reveal several distinct adsorption sites in the solid, which are attributed to their interactions with Ni cations which are weak Lewis acid sites, as well as with P=O groups that project into the pores. At 304 K, the adsorption isotherms and enthalpies of adsorption on dehydrated Ni-STA-12 were measured for CO2 and CH4: Ni-STA-12 gives adsorption uptakes of CO2 of 2.5 mmol g-1 at 1 bar, an uptake ca. 10 Times that of CH4.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlWqurvN&md5=443bdbd4de665aa6713b6a25fd7ee4a0
      5. 5
        (a) Wang, C.; Liu, D.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135 (36) 13222– 13234 DOI: 10.1021/ja308229p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5a
        Metal-Organic Frameworks as A Tunable Platform for Designing Functional Molecular Materials
        Wang, Cheng; Liu, Demin; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (36), 13222-13234CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers, represent an interesting class of cryst. mol. materials that were synthesized by combining metal-connecting points and bridging ligands. The modular nature of and mild conditions for MOF synthesis have permitted the rational structural design of numerous MOFs and the incorporation of various functionalities via constituent building blocks. The resulting designer MOFs showed promise for applications in a no. of areas, including gas storage/sepn., nonlinear optics/ferroelectricity, catalysis, energy conversion/storage, chem. sensing, biomedical imaging, and drug delivery. The structure-property relations of MOFs can also be readily established by taking advantage of the knowledge of their detailed at. structures, which enables fine-tuning of their functionalities for desired applications. Through the combination of mol. synthesis and crystal engineering, MOFs thus present an unprecedented opportunity for the rational and precise design of functional materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXht1OjurbN&md5=59f57bfc391fa41f22f299ab704d8b22
        (b) Holcroft, J. M.; Hartlieb, K. J.; Moghadam, P. Z.; Bell, J. G.; Barin, G.; Ferris, D. P.; Bloch, E. D.; Algaradah, M. M.; Nassar, M. S.; Botros, Y. Y.; Thomas, K. M.; Long, J. R.; Snurr, R. Q.; Stoddart, J. F. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137 (17) 5706– 5719 DOI: 10.1021/ja511878b
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5b
        Carbohydrate-Mediated Purification of Petrochemicals
        Holcroft, James M.; Hartlieb, Karel J.; Moghadam, Peyman Z.; Bell, Jon G.; Barin, Gokhan; Ferris, Daniel P.; Bloch, Eric D.; Algaradah, Mohammed M.; Nassar, Majed S.; Botros, Youssry Y.; Thomas, K. Mark; Long, Jeffrey R.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Stoddart, J. Fraser
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (17), 5706-5719CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are known to facilitate energy-efficient sepns. of important industrial chem. feedstocks. Here, we report how a class of green MOFs-namely CD-MOFs-exhibits high shape selectivity toward arom. hydrocarbons. CD-MOFs, which consist of an extended porous network of γ-cyclodextrins (γ-CDs) and alkali metal cations, can sep. a wide range of benzenoid compds. as a result of their relative orientation and packing within the transverse channels formed from linking (γ-CD)6 body-centered cuboids in three dimensions. Adsorption isotherms and liq.-phase chromatog. measurements indicate a retention order of ortho- > meta- > para-xylene. The persistence of this regioselectivity is also obsd. during the liq.-phase chromatog. of the ethyltoluene and cymene regioisomers. In addn., mol. shape-sorting within CD-MOFs facilitates the sepn. of the industrially relevant BTEX (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene isomers) mixt. The high resoln. and large sepn. factors exhibited by CD-MOFs for benzene and these alkylaroms. provide an efficient, reliable, and green alternative to current isolation protocols. Furthermore, the isolation of the regioisomers of (i) ethyltoluene and (ii) cymene, together with the purifn. of (iii) cumene from its major impurities (benzene, n-propylbenzene, and diisopropylbenzene) highlight the specificity of the shape selectivity exhibited by CD-MOFs. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations and single component static vapor adsorption isotherms and kinetics reveal the origin of the shape selectivity and provide insight into the capability of CD-MOFs to serve as versatile sepn. platforms derived from renewable sources.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlt1Wmurw%253D&md5=db6125c76dc43d92cad6690e460557ec

        A new family of porous lanthanide-based coordination polymers with tunable luminescent properties based on reversible ion-dependent exchange is reported.

        6b
        Metal-Organic Framework Threaded with Aminated Polymer Formed in Situ for Fast and Reversible Ion Exchange
        Gao, Liang; Li, Chi-Ying Vanessa; Chan, Kwong-Yu; Chen, Zhe-Ning
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (20), 7209-7212CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A porous metal-org. framework composite with flexible anion-exchange polymers threaded within the host cavity demonstrates very fast and reversible ion-exchange activity. Polyvinyl benzyl trimethylammonium hydroxide (PVBTAH) caged in ZIF-8 is synthesized in steps of chloro-monomer impregnation, in situ polymn., amination, and alk. ion exchange. The synthesized non-crosslinked PVBTAH∼ZIF-8 material exhibits superior ion-exchange kinetics compared to conventional ion-exchange resins.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXns1Ciuro%253D&md5=50a87542f3766f8ac261b85189312891
        (c) Plabst, M.; McCusker, L. B.; Bein, T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131 (50) 18112– 18118 DOI: 10.1021/ja904636y
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6c
        Exceptional Ion-Exchange Selectivity in a Flexible Open Framework Lanthanum(III) tetrakisphosphonate
        Plabst, Monika; McCusker, Lynne B.; Bein, Thomas
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (50), 18112-18118CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The flexible, anionic, open-framework material NaLa[(PO3H)2CH-C6H4-CH(PO3H)2]·4H2O (NaLa(H4L)) exhibits an exceptional selectivity for monovalent metal cations. This study elucidates the relation between the ion-exchange behavior and the framework flexibility of this recently discovered material. The exchange of the Na+ ions in NaLa(H4L) with alk.-earth, alk., and selected transition metal ions was studied. EDX and ICP-OES elemental anal. revealed that ion exchange was successful with monovalent ions, while higher-valent ions were rejected. An explanation for this charge selectivity could be found in the site-specific role of the guest cation. X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric studies on the reversible hydration and dehydration behavior demonstrate that NaLa(H4L) has a flexible framework. Contraction of the channels upon dehydration decreases the cell vol. of 15%. Rietveld refinement of the structure of the dehydrated form NaLa(H4L)dehyd revealed the key role played by the guest cation in the channel-shrinking mechanism. In the hydrated, expanded form, each Na+ ion guest shares three phosphonate oxygens with a La3+ ion in a La phosphonate chain that defines part of the wall of a rhombic channel. The Na+ ion completes its octahedral coordination sphere with two H2O mols. and a weaker bond to a 4th phosphonate O. In the dehydrated, contracted form, the Na+ ion loses the two H2O mols. and moves toward a 2nd La3+ ion, which is located in an adjacent La phosphonate chain, to share two more phosphonate oxygens, and becomes 5-coordinate. This gave an -La-O-Na-O-La- chain and a concomitant shrinking of the channels. A comparison of the monovalent metal (M(I)) ion-exchanged compds., M(I)La(H4L), reveals that both the ionic radius and the enthalpy of hydration of the guest cation affect the equil. between the expanded and the contracted forms, and that the framework adapts specifically to the size of the guest cation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVens7bI&md5=b8e5957ec78243520eb0a3955a60e0ce
      7. 7
        Montoro, C.; Linares, F.; Quartapelle Procopio, E.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S.; Galli, S.; Masciocchi, N.; Barea, E.; Navarro, J. A. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133 (31) 11888– 11891 DOI: 10.1021/ja2042113
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Capture of Nerve Agents and Mustard Gas Analogues by Hydrophobic Robust MOF-5 Type Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Montoro, Carmen; Linares, Fatima; Quartapelle Procopio, Elsa; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan; Galli, Simona; Masciocchi, Norberto; Barea, Elisa; Navarro, Jorge A. R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (31), 11888-11891CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        In this communication, a series of observations and data analyses coherently confirms the suitability of the novel metal-org. framework (MOF) [Zn4(μ4-O)(μ4-4-carboxy-3,5-dimethyl-4-carboxy-pyrazolato)3] (1) in the capture of harmful volatile org. compds. (VOCs). It is worthy of attention that 1, whose crystal structure resembles that of MOF-5, exhibits remarkable thermal, mech., and chem. stability, as required if practical applications are sought. In addn., it selectively captures harmful VOCs (including models of Sarin and mustard gas, which are chem. warfare agents), even in competition with ambient moisture (i.e., under conditions mimicking operative ones). The results can be rationalized on the basis of Henry const. and adsorption heat values for the different essayed adsorbates as well as H2O/VOC partition coeffs. as obtained from variable-temp. reverse gas chromatog. expts. To further strengthen the importance of 1, its performance in the capture of harmful VOCs has been compared with those of well-known materials, namely, a MOF with coordinatively unsatd. metal sites, [Cu3(btc)2] and the mol. sieve active carbon Carboxen. The results of this comparison show that coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (preferential guest-binding sites) are ineffective for the capture of VOCs in the presence of ambient moisture. Consequently, we propose that the driving force of the VOC-MOF recognition process is mainly dictated by pore size and surface hydrophobicity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXptFKmsr0%253D&md5=03e430027a9daed8d7286ea28880c1b2

        Zagorodniy, K.; Seifert, G.; Hermann, H. Appl. Phys. Lett. 2010, 97 (25) 251905 DOI: 10.1063/1.3529461

        8
        Metal-organic frameworks as promising candidates for future ultralow-k dielectrics
        Zagorodniy, K.; Seifert, G.; Hermann, H.
        Applied Physics Letters (2010), 97 (25), 251905/1-251905/2CODEN: APPLAB; ISSN:0003-6951. (American Institute of Physics)
        A class of Zn4O(CO2)6-based metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is theor. analyzed with respect to suitability as an interlayer dielec. material for applications in semiconducting devices. The static dielec. const. is calcd. using the Clausius-Mossotti approach. For 3 out of ∼30 of the considered MOFs excellent combinations of ultralow dielec. const., elastic bulk modulus, and gap energy are found favoring these materials as outstanding candidates for future ultralow-k dielec. materials. (c) 2010 American Institute of Physics.

      10. 10
        (a) Stock, N.; Biswas, S. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112 (2) 933– 969 DOI: 10.1021/cr200304e
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10a
        Synthesis of Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs): Routes to Various MOF Topologies, Morphologies, and Composites
        Stock, Norbert; Biswas, Shyam
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 933-969CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has attracted immense attention during the last 2 decades due to the possibility to obtain a large variety of aesthetically interesting structures that could also be of great interest for applications in a no. of fields related to porous materials. This includes the more traditional areas of storage, sepn., and catalysis, which are based on the pore size and shape as well as the host guest interactions involved. In addn., biomedical applications or the use as sensor materials are currently intensively investigated. Although MOF synthesis was originally set out for making new compds. and structures with interesting properties, the field has matured and is broadening its scope. This holds for the synthesis methods applied as well as the areas of application. While conventional syntheses methods have been widely used, the fields of mechano-, sono-, and electrochem. synthesis as well as microwave-assisted syntheses are just emerging. They have demonstrated to be applicable for some compds., often under milder reaction conditions, yielding materials with different particle sizes and properties. This could be of interest for up-scaling of syntheses and the application of MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsV2ju73P&md5=76323bab0fb9da58bcdf45e03537eed7
        (b) Allendorf, M. D.; Stavila, V. CrystEngComm 2015, 17 (2) 229– 246 DOI: 10.1039/C4CE01693A
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10b
        Crystal engineering, structure-function relationships, and the future of metal-organic frameworks
        Allendorf, Mark D.; Stavila, Vitalie
        CrystEngComm (2015), 17 (2), 229-246CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Metal-Org. Frameworks (MOFs) are a rapidly expanding class of hybrid org.-inorg. materials that can be rationally designed and assembled through crystal engineering. The explosion of interest in this subclass of coordination polymers results from their outstanding properties and myriad possible applications, which include traditional uses of microporous materials, such as gas storage, sepns., and catalysis, as well as new realms in biomedicine, electronic devices, and information storage. The objective of this Highlight article is to provide the reader with a sense of where the field stands after roughly fifteen years of research. Remarkable progress has been made, but the barriers to practical and com. advances are also evident. We discuss the basic elements of MOF assembly and present a conceptual hierarchy of structural elements that assists in understanding how unique properties in these materials can be achieved. Structure-function relationships are then discussed; several are now well understood, as a result of the focused efforts of many research groups over the past decade. Prospects for the use of MOFs in membranes, catalysis, biomedicine, and as active components in electronic and photonic devices are also discussed. Finally, we identify the most pressing challenges in our view that must be addressed for these materials to realize their full potential in the marketplace.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslGisr7F&md5=d41c24fb48fe34cdcadf4f9de51caa92
      11. 11
        Bala, S.; Bhattacharya, S.; Goswami, A.; Adhikary, A.; Konar, S.; Mondal, R. Cryst. Growth Des. 2014, 14 (12) 6391– 6398 DOI: 10.1021/cg501226v
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Designing Functional Metal-Organic Frameworks by Imparting a Hexanuclear Copper-Based Secondary Building Unit Specific Properties: Structural Correlation With Magnetic and Photocatalytic Activity
        Bala, Sukhen; Bhattacharya, Sudeshna; Goswami, Arijit; Adhikary, Amit; Konar, Sanjit; Mondal, Raju
        Crystal Growth & Design (2014), 14 (12), 6391-6398CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        In continuation of the authors' research interest in pyrazole-based multifunctional metal org. frameworks (MOFs), the authors report here three Cu(II) MOFs using pyrazole and various arom. carboxylic acid-based ligands. The main theme of interest is to design functional MOFs by imparting a multinuclear metal center as a secondary building unit (SBU). Accordingly, three MOFs were synthesized based on a hexanuclear Cu-pyrazolate unit as the SBU with some intriguing structural networks like (4,4) type herringbone grid or an archetypal Kagome topol. The authors have successfully synthesized functional MOFs by incorporating hexanuclear Cu-pyrazolate SBU-specific properties viz. magnetism and catalysis, the central theme of this work. The prepd. complexes are {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(NAPH)]DMF.H2O.CH3OH}n (MOF-1, 1), [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(BIPH)(H2O)2]n (MOF-2, 2), and [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(PDC)(H2O)2(CH3OH)]n (MOF-3, 3) (where HPyz = 1H-pyrazole, H2NAPH = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, H2BIPH = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid, and H2PDC = 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid). All the MOFs show some photocatalytic degrdn. of toxic dye mols. However, magnetic behaviors of MOF-2 and MOF-3 assocd. with the Cu6 unit also were studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        A Bismuth-Based Metal-Organic Framework as an Efficient Visible-Light-Driven Photocatalyst
        Wang, Guanzhi; Sun, Qilong; Liu, Yuanyuan; Huang, Baibiao; Dai, Ying; Zhang, Xiaoyang; Qin, Xiaoyan
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (6), 2364-2367CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A visible-light-responsive bismuth-based metal-org. framework (Bi-mna) is demonstrated to show good photoelec. and photocatalytic properties. Combining exptl. and theor. results, a ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) process is found to be responsible for the high performance, which gives rise to a longer lifetime of photogenerated charge carriers. Our results suggest that bismuth-based MOFs could be promising candidates for the development of efficient visible-light photocatalysts.

        13a
        Energy-Efficient Photodegradation of Azo Dyes with TiO2 Nanoparticles Based on Photoisomerization and Alternate UV-Visible Light
        Zhang, Hao; Chen, Da; Lv, Xiaojun; Wang, Ying; Chang, Haixin; Li, Jinghong
        Environmental Science & Technology (2010), 44 (3), 1107-1111CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
        We demonstrated a UV-vis light alternate photocatalysis (UVLAP) strategy in the photodegrdn. of azo dyes. The UVLAP of azo dyes over TiO2 catalysts exhibited significantly higher energy efficiency than the conventional UV process by 40%, which was attributed to the photoisomerization of azo dyes and the resulting diversity of dyes' cis and trans states in interfacial properties, including conductance and spatial effects. This UVLAP strategy could contribute to the energy-saving photodegrdn. of azo dyes and other pollutants with photoisomerization properties and facilitate the practical application of TiO2 in the environmental remediation.

        Decontamination of wastewaters containing synthetic organic dyes by electrochemical methods: A general review
        Martinez-Huitle, Carlos A.; Brillas, Enric
        Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental (2009), 87 (3-4), 105-145CODEN: ACBEE3; ISSN:0926-3373. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review of efficient electrochem. technologies to decolorize and/or degrade dyeing wastewater, providing fundamentals for each technol. to better understand their advantages and limitations, is given. Topics discussed include: electrocoagulation (Fe or steel anode, Al anode, comparative anode behavior); electrochem. redn.; electrochem. oxidn. (model for org. oxidn. with heterogeneous OH-, electrochem. systems and exptl. parameters [PbO2 anode, dimensionally-stable anode-type electrodes], Pt anode, carbonaceous and other anode materials, B-doped diamond electrodes [Ti/, Ni/, and Si/B-doped diamond electrodes, diamond electrodes with unspecified support], comparative anode oxidn. power); indirect electrooxidn. with strong oxidants (active Cl2 [electro-generation of active Cl2 species, exptl. systems, dimensionally-stable electrodes, metal anodes, graphite anodes], electro-Fenton method [homogeneous OH- generation, electrochem. systems and exptl. conditions, dye treatment], other indirect electrochem. techniques); photo-assisted electrochem. methods (photo-Fenton, photo-electrocatalysis, coupled photo-assisted treatments); and conclusions.

        13c
        High adsorption capacity NaOH-activated carbon for dye removal from aqueous solution
        Wu, Feng-Chin; Tseng, Ru-Ling
        Journal of Hazardous Materials (2008), 152 (3), 1256-1267CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The surface coverage ratio (Sc/Sp) and monolayer cover adsorption amt. per unit surface area (qmon/Sp) were employed to investigate the adsorption isotherm equil. of the adsorption of dyes (AB74, BB1, and MB) on NaOH-activated carbons (FWNa2, FWNa3, and FWNa4); the adsorption rate of the Elovich equation (1/b) and the ratio of 1 min adsorption amt. of adsorbate to the monolayer cover amt. of adsorbate (q 1/q mon) were employed to investigate adsorption kinetics. The qmon/Sp of NaOH-activated carbons was better than that of KOH-activated carbons prepd. from the same raw material (fir wood). The Sc/Sp values of the adsorption of all adsorbates on adsorbent FWNa3 in this study were found to be higher than those in related literature. Parameters 1/b and q1 of the adsorption of dyes on activated carbons in this study were higher than those on KOH-activated carbons; the q1/qmon value of FWNa3 was the highest. The pore structure and the TPD measurement of the surface oxide groups were employed to explain the superior adsorption performance of FWNa3. A high-surface activated carbon (FWNa3) with excellent adsorption performance on dyes with relation to adsorption isotherm equil. and kinetics was obtained in this study. Several adsorption data processing methods were employed to describe the adsorption performance.

        Selectively catalytic pastry-shape micro-crystals: A new linear metal-organic framework with [Cu(NO3)2(bpd)(DMF)]∞
        Meng, Qingxiang; Ye, Jing; Xu, Zhen-liang; Xu, Haitao
        Materials Letters (2014), 116 (), 378-381CODEN: MLETDJ; ISSN:0167-577X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Pastry-shaped micro-crystals of a new linear metal-org. framework (MOF), [Cu(NO3)2(bpd)(DMF)]∞ (1) (bpd = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-azo-1,3-butadiene), were synthesized and characterized. The crystals were monoclinic with space group P2(1)/c, a = 9.5401(8), b = 14.3545(12), c = 14.9823(12) Å, β = 106.37(10)° and Z = 4. In the title compd. (1), each Cu(II) center exists in a pentagonal-bipyramid environment, contributed by two N atoms from two bpds and five O atoms belonging to two nitrates and one DMF. The {Cu(NO3)2(DMF)} moieties are bridged by bpds to form 1-D mol. chains along the ac-axis. The catalytic degrdn. activity of the micro-crystals of 1 is high for methyl orange (90%), and lower for Orange G (55%), indicating that the catalyst synthesized in the authors' work is not only highly active and selective for org.-dye degrdn. reactions, but is also very efficient.

        Ye, Jing; Gou, Yongxia; Xu, Zhen-Liang; Xu, Haitao

        Metal-org. framework micro-crystals [Co(4-bpdh)(HIA)].varies. (1), crystd. in the monoclinic system (space group P12/n1, a 10.0009(16), b 15.472(3), c 18.563(3) Å, β 91.81(0)°, and Z = 4), were controllably synthesized through the adjustment of the solvent system. The Co2+ ion center located in a six-coordinated environment combined with 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (HIA, 2) to produce ladder-like structures, which again linked with 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (4-bpdh, 3) to yield a double-layer network. The authors' work detd. that the synthesized catalyst is not only highly selective for degrdn. of org. dyes, but also very efficient.

        15
        Electrochemical photolysis of water at a semiconductor electrode
        Fujishima, Akira; Honda, Kenichi
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1972), 238 (5358), 37-8CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        For electrochem. decompn. of H2O, a p.d. of >1.23 V is necessary between the anode and the cathode. This p.d. is equal to the energy of radiation with wavelength of ∼1000 nm. This energy, in the form of visible light, can be used effectively in an electrochem. system to decomp. H2O. A novel type of electrochem. cell was developed, in which a TiO2 electrode was connected with a Pt-black electrode through an external load. The direction of current revealed that oxidn. occurred at the TiO2 electrode and redn. at the Pt-black electrode. To increase the efficiency of the process, more reducible species, such as dissolved O2 or Fe3+, must be added in the Pt electrode compartment. The use of a p-type semiconductor electrode instead of Pt leads to more effective electrochem. photolysis of H2O.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE38XltVykurw%253D&md5=71f39843802b5cdb5f7cb0deb7f0c63c
      16. 16
        Aarthi, T.; Madras, G. Catal. Commun. 2008, 9 (5) 630– 634 DOI: 10.1016/j.catcom.2007.07.001
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Photocatalytic reduction of metals in presence of combustion synthesized nano-TiO2
        Aarthi, T.; Madras, Giridhar
        Catalysis Communications (2008), 9 (5), 630-634CODEN: CCAOAC; ISSN:1566-7367. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The photocatalytic redn. of the metal ions, Cu(II) and Cr(VI), was investigated in presence of soln. combustion synthesized (CS) nano-TiO2. The efficiency of this catalyst was compared with that of com. titania, Degussa P-25. For the redn. of Cu2+, the first-order rate consts. were 0.003 and 0.018 min-1 in presence of Degussa P-25 and CS TiO2, resp. For the redn. of Cr6+, the initial rate consts. were 0.007 and 0.247 min-1 in presence of Degussa P-25 and CS TiO2, resp. Thus, the rate of redn. of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) is higher in CS TiO2 compared to Degussa P-25 TiO2. The effect of pH and the effect of initial concn. on the photocatalytic redn. of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) in presence of soln. combustion synthesized TiO2 and Degussa P-25 catalyst were investigated. The variation of the photoredn. rate of Cu(II) and Cr(VI) with respect to pH correlates with the variation of the driving force, which is the difference between the std. redn. potential of the metal ion and the energy level of the electrons in the conduction band. The other metal ions like Zn(II), Cd(II), Pb(II) and Mn(II) could not be reduced in both the catalytic systems and this is attributed to the thermodn. in-feasibility of their redn. by photo generated electrons.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhvFyitLY%253D&md5=1b8b46e3d52e5785471a469901c247e6
      17. 17
        Jing, T.; Dai, Y.; Wei, W.; Ma, X.; Huang, B. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16 (34) 18596– 18604 DOI: 10.1039/C4CP01846J
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Near-infrared photocatalytic activity induced by intrinsic defects in Bi2MO6 (M = W, Mo)
        Jing, Tao; Dai, Ying; Wei, Wei; Ma, Xiangchao; Huang, Baibiao
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (34), 18596-18604CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The electronic structure and related photocatalytic properties of Bi2MO6 (M = W, Mo) with various intrinsic defects are studied based on the first-principles d. functional theory (DFT). Our results indicate that O vacancies form easily in both Bi2WO6 and Bi2MoO6 under Bi rich/O poor conditions. The near-IR light transitions can be realized involving electrons from the O vacancy induced impurity states within the band gap to the conduction band. Rather than acting as photogenerated carrier recombination centers, the impurity states caused by O vacancies favor the transfer of photogenerated holes and further benefit the photocatalytic process due to the delocalized nature. The spatial sepn. of photogenerated carriers among different layers can be realized, which reduces the carrier recombination and improves the photocatalytic activity. In addn., Bi2WO6 with O vacancies is desirable for having better near-IR photocatalytic performance than Bi2MoO6 due to the larger mobility of photogenerated holes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Journal of Electroceramics (2009), 22 (1-3), 110-113CODEN: JOELFJ; ISSN:1385-3449. (Springer)

Several kinds of TiO2 nanopowders were also tried to compare the photocatalytic reactivity. Surprisingly, SCM ZnO nanopowder shows 1.6 fold higher destruction rates of the org. pollutant than P-25 TiO2 nanopowder that is known as a kind of std. photocatalyst.

        (a) Xu, R.; Li, J.; Wang, J.; Wang, X.; Liu, B.; Wang, B.; Luan, X.; Zhang, X. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2010, 94 (6) 1157– 1165 DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2010.03.003

        19a
        Photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes under solar light irradiation combined with Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites
        Xu, Rui; Li, Jia; Wang, Jun; Wang, Xiaofang; Liu, Bin; Wang, Baoxin; Luan, Xiaoyu; Zhang, Xiangdong
        Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2010), 94 (6), 1157-1165CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In order to extend the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, two new photocatalysts of Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites were prepd. by the sol-gel process and characterized by XRD and TG-DTA. And then, their photocatalytic activities through the degrdn. of azo Fuchsine under solar light irradn. were evaluated by HPLC techniques and UV-vis spectra. The influencing factors such as the Er3+:YAlO3 content, heat-treated temp. and heat-treated time on the photocatalytic activities of Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites were reviewed. Otherwise, the solar light irradn. time, initial concn. of azo Fuchsine, photocatalyst addn. amt. and kind of org. dyes on the photocatalytic degrdn. of azo fuchsine were also studied. All exptl. results indicate that the Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites are more effective than Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 powders. That is because the Er3+:YAlO3 can transform the visible light into the UV light and enhance the photocatalytic activities of Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 powders. It is possible to provide a new way to utilize the Er3+:YAlO3/Fe- and Co-doped TiO2 coated composites under the solar light irradn. for the treatment of wastewater in the future.

        (b) Rauf, M. A.; Meetani, M. A.; Khaleel, A.; Ahmed, A. Chem. Eng. J. 2010, 157 (2–3) 373– 378 DOI: 10.1016/j.cej.2009.11.017

        19b
        Photocatalytic degradation of Methylene Blue using a mixed catalyst and product analysis by LC/MS
        Rauf, Muhammad A.; Meetani, Mohammed A.; Khaleel, A.; Ahmed, Amal
        Chemical Engineering Journal (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2010), 157 (2-3), 373-378CODEN: CMEJAJ; ISSN:1385-8947. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Cr-Ti binary oxide with 10% molar Cr3+ content (Ti-10Cr) was prepd. by sol-gel method and characterized by using transmission electron microscope (TEM) and x-ray diffraction anal. (XRD). The photoinduced degrdn. of Methylene Blue (MB) dye in the presence of Ti-10 Cr was studied with UV-vis absorption. The absorption intensity of the dye soln. monitored at 668 nm decreased with time upon irradn. in the presence of the catalyst. A max. degrdn. efficiency of 70% of the dye was achieved in the presence of Ti-10 Cr catalyst at pH 7. Photocatalytic degrdn. of the dye followed the pseudo-second-order-kinetics. Degrdn. product anal. was done using the LC-UV/vis-MS technique and the results showed that the dye degrdn. is initiated by demethylation of the mol. The intermediates structure was confirmed by tandem mass spectrometric anal.

        19c
        Photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue by ZnGa2O4 thin films
        Zhang, Weiwei; Zhang, Junying; Chen, Ziyu; Wang, Tianmin
        Catalysis Communications (2009), 10 (13), 1781-1785CODEN: CCAOAC; ISSN:1566-7367. (Elsevier B.V.)
        ZnGa2O4 thin films were synthesized using a sol-gel process, characterized by SEM, x-ray diffraction (XRD) and UV-vis spectrophotometry measurements. The photocatalytic decompg. properties to methylene blue (MB) dye were studied for the first time. Effects of calcining temp., crystallites size and film thickness on the photocatalytic activity were investigated. The film obtained at calcining temp. of 700°, consisting of the smallest crystallites, exhibits highest photocatalytic activity. With increasing the film thickness, the photocatalysis rate const. increased first to 0.0195, and then decreased drastically to 0.0089 due to the competition between UV absorption and carriers diffusion. The photocatalytic activity of ZnGa2O4 films maintained more than 90% of the initial value after 6 cycles, compared favorably with the 70% of ZnGa2O4 powder.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXosVGksL0%253D&md5=09b64ae2df370906c01314855c8eebb9
      20. 20
        (a) Wang, C.; Xie, Z.; de Krafft, K. E.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133 (34) 13445– 13454 DOI: 10.1021/ja203564w
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20a
        Doping Metal-Organic Frameworks for Water Oxidation, Carbon Dioxide Reduction, and Organic Photocatalysis
        Wang, Cheng; Xie, Zhigang; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (34), 13445-13454CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Catalytically competent Ir, Re, and Ru complexes H2L1-H2L6 with dicarboxylic acid functionalities were incorporated into a highly stable and porous Zr6O4(OH)4(bpdc)6 (UiO-67, bpdc = para-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) framework using a mix-and-match synthetic strategy. The matching ligand lengths between bpdc and L1-L6 ligands allowed the construction of highly cryst. UiO-67 frameworks (metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) 1-6) that were doped with L1-L6 ligands. MOFs 1-6 were isostructural to the parent UiO-67 framework as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and exhibited high surface areas ranging from 1092 to 1497 m2/g. MOFs 1-6 were stable in air up to 400 °C and active catalysts in a range of reactions that are relevant to solar energy utilization. MOFs 1-3 contg. [Cp*IrIII(dcppy)Cl] (H2L1), [Cp*IrIII(dcbpy)Cl]Cl (H2L2), and [IrIII(dcppy)2(H2O)2]OTf (H2L3) (where Cp* is pentamethylcyclopentadienyl, dcppy is 2-phenylpyridine-5,4'-dicarboxylic acid, and dcbpy is 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid) were effective water oxidn. catalysts (WOCs), with turnover frequencies (TOFs) of up to 4.8 h-1. The [ReI(CO)3(dcbpy)Cl] (H2L4) derivatized MOF 4 served as an active catalyst for photocatalytic CO2 redn. with a total turnover no. (TON) of 10.9, three times higher than that of the homogeneous complex H2L4. MOFs 5 and 6 contained phosphorescent [IrIII(ppy)2(dcbpy)]Cl (H2L5) and [RuII(bpy)2(dcbpy)]Cl2 (H2L6) (where ppy is 2-phenylpyridine and bpy is 2,2'-bipyridine) and were used in three photocatalytic org. transformations (aza-Henry reaction, aerobic amine coupling, and aerobic oxidn. of thioanisole) with very high activities. The inactivity of the parent UiO-67 framework and the reaction supernatants in catalytic water oxidn., CO2 redn., and org. transformations indicate both the mol. origin and heterogeneous nature of these catalytic processes. The stability of the doped UiO-67 catalysts under catalytic conditions was also demonstrated by comparing PXRD patterns before and after catalysis. This work illustrates the potential of combining mol. catalysts and MOF structures in developing highly active heterogeneous catalysts for solar energy utilization.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (b) Falkowski, J. M.; Sawano, T.; Zhang, T.; Tsun, G.; Chen, Y.; Lockard, J. V.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136 (14) 5213– 5216 DOI: 10.1021/ja500090y

        20b
        Privileged Phosphine-Based Metal-Organic Frameworks for Broad-Scope Asymmetric Catalysis
        Falkowski, Joseph M.; Sawano, Takahiro; Zhang, Teng; Tsun, Galen; Chen, Yuan; Lockard, Jenny V.; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (14), 5213-5216CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A robust and porous Zr metal-org. framework (MOF) based on a BINAP-derived dicarboxylate linker, BINAP-MOF, was synthesized and post-synthetically metalated with Ru and Rh complexes to afford highly enantioselective catalysts for important org. transformations. The Rh-functionalized MOF is not only highly enantioselective (up to >99% ee) but also 3 times as active as the homogeneous control. XAFS studies revealed that the Ru-functionalized MOF contains Ru-BINAP precatalysts with the same coordination environment as the homogeneous Ru complex. The post-synthetically metalated BINAP-MOFs provide a versatile family of single-site solid catalysts for catalyzing a broad scope of asym. org. transformations, including addn. of aryl and alkyl groups to α,β-unsatd. ketones and hydrogenation of substituted alkene and carbonyl compds.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A Multifunctional Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Structure Based on MnIII-Porphyrin and Polyoxometalate as a Highly Effective Dye Scavenger and Heterogenous Catalyst
        Zou, Chao; Zhang, Zhijuan; Xu, Xuan; Gong, Qihan; Li, Jing; Wu, Chuan-De
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (1), 87-90CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A two-step synthesis strategy has led to a unique layered polyoxometalate MnIII metalloporphyrin-based hybrid material. The hybrid solid demonstrates remarkable capability for scavenging of dyes and for heterogeneous selective oxidn. of alkylbenzenes with excellent product yields and 100% selectivity.

        Structure versatility of coordination polymers constructed from a semirigid ligand and polynuclear metal clusters
        Yang, De-Liang; Zhang, Xin; Yao, Yuan-Gen; Zhang, Jian
        CrystEngComm (2014), 16 (34), 8047-8057CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Five new coordination polymers, namely [Cd3(dcppa)(Hdcppa)(H2O)]·(Me2NH2)·(DMA)2 (1), [CdCa(dcppa)(DMA)2] (2), [CdCa(dcppa)(H2O)2(DMA)] (3), [Ba2(H2dcppa)2(μ2-H2O)(H2O)(DMA)]·(H2O) (4), and [Ba2(H2dcppa)2(μ2-H2O)(H2O)(DMF)]·(H2O) (5) (Me2NH2+ = dimethylammonium cation; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide; H4dcppa = 3-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid), were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Compd. 1 presents a unique binodal (3,6)-connected {43}2{47·88} topol. structure, which is a 2D layer anionic network with Me2NH2+ cations occupying the voids, built upon a trinuclear Cd3 unit. Compds. 2 and 3 are all bimetallic Cd-Ca compds. consisting of tetranuclear Cd2Ca2 units extending to a 3D (3,6)-connected rtl topol. structure and a 2D (3,6)-connected kgd topol. structure, resp. Compds. 4 and 5 are isostructural and exhibit an unprecedented 3D (4,10)-connected topol. structure in which a 1D infinite barium chain is obsd. From the viewpoint of crystal structure diversity and comparison, the authors' results further demonstrate that the coordination modes of metal ions and ligands are the vital elements in forming the final crystal structure. In addn., the thermal stabilities and solid-state luminescence properties of compds. 1-5 are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFWhs7zN&md5=f5a90a1874e25d5d90743dcff13ea1c7

        Seven Coordination Polymers Derived from Semirigid Tetracarboxylic Acids and N-Donor Ligands: Topological Structures, Unusual Magnetic Properties, and Photoluminescences
        Si, Chang-Dai; Hu, Dong-Cheng; Fan, Yan; Wu, Yu; Yao, Xiao-Qiang; Yang, Yun-Xia; Liu, Jia-Cheng
        Crystal Growth & Design (2015), 15 (5), 2419-2432CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Seven new complexes based on H4L1 and H4L2, namely, [Cd2(L1)(H2O)5]n (1), {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O}n (2), {[Cd2(L1)(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)3]·2H2O}n (3), [Zn2(L1)(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)3]n (4), {[Ni7(L1)4(4,4'-bipy)12(H2O)12]·2H2O}n (5), {[Ni1.5(L2)(4,4'-bipy)1.5(H2O)4]·H2O}n (6), and {[Ni9(L2)6(dib)12(H2O)18]·18H2O}n (7) [H4L1 = 4-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy)phthalic acid, H4L2 = 3-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy)phthalic acid, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, dib = 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene], were synthesized by solvothermal reactions. Complex 1 possesses a 4-connected chiral three-dimensional (3D) structure with a Schlafli symbol of (4.63.82). Complex 2 presents a (4,6)-connected porous architecture based on a chair-shaped [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ secondary building unit (SBU) with a Schlafli symbol of (43.63)2(46.66.83), revealing unusual ferromagnetic behavior. Complex 3 exhibits a 2-dimensional → 3-dimensional framework through H-bonding interactions, which is a (3,3,4)-connected 2-fold interpenetrated structure with a Schlafli symbol of (6.82)2(63.83). Complex 4 shows a (3,4,6)-connected (4.64.8)2(62.8)2(42.66.86.10) topol. Complex 5 displays a rare (3,4)-connected polycatenation structure, possessing identical topologies with a Schlafli symbol of (63)(65.8) and weakly ferromagnetic behavior. Complex 6 features a (3,4)-connected 3-dimensional framework with a Schlafli symbol of (4 × 102)2(42.103.12). Complex 7 can be regarded as a (4,4)-connected (63.83)2(85.10) topol. Also, diverse structural topologies were not documented hitherto. The magnetic properties of 2 and 5 are discussed. The fluorescence properties also were analyzed with d. functional theory calcns., indicating that the emissions can be ascribed to intraligand charge transfer for 1 and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer for 3-4.

        A Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed From a V-shaped Tripodal Carboxylate Ligand: Syntheses, Structures, Photoluminescent, and Magnetic Properties
        Zhao, Shu-Na; Su, Sheng-Qun; Song, Xue-Zhi; Zhu, Min; Hao, Zhao-Min; Meng, Xing; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhang, Hong-Jie
        Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (7), 2756-2765CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Six novel complexes, namely, {[Zn1.5(L)(bix)0.5(H2O)]·H2O}n (1), {[Co1.5(L)(bix)0.5(H2O)]·H2O}n (2), {[Co3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·5H2O}n (3), {[Cd3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·4.5H2O}n (4), {[Cu3(L)2(4,4'-bpy)3]·3H2O}n (5), and {[Ni1.5(L)(4,4'-bpy)1.5(H2O)3]·2H2O}n (6) were synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of 5-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenoxy)isophthalic acid (H3L) with different transition metal ions in the presence of ancillary ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy). Complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural, possessing a (3,8)-connected tfz-d type topol. with the Schlaefli symbol of {43}2{46·618·84}. The 3-dimensional structures of complexes 3-5 are very similar to complex 1 with only a little difference of the H3L coordination motif in complexes 4 and 5. The authors also use 4,4'-bpy instead of bix as the ancillary ligand in all three complexes. Complex 6 is a mixed 1-dimensional chain and two-dimensional sheet structure, which are further linked to each other in a three-dimensional framework by H-bond interactions. All the complexes were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG anal., and elemental anal. The luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 4 are discussed, and the magnetic properties of complexes 2 and 3 are also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXptFegtrY%253D&md5=9ad749547fb5d889c0b8484ab0641ae8

        24b
        Structural Diversity and Luminescence Properties of Coordination Polymers Built With a Rigid Linear Dicarboxylate and Zn(II)/Pb(II) Ion
        Sahu, Jhasaketan; Ahmad, Musheer; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (6), 2618-2627CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A rigid linear ligand incorporating a carboxylic acid group at either end, 2',5'-dimethyl-p-terphenyl-4,4''-dicarboxylic acid (H2L) was used to construct four coordination polymers with Zn(II) through solvothermal techniques. The four products formed are {[Zn3(L)2(OH)2]·8EtOH·4DMF}n (1), {[Zn(L)(bpmp)0.5]·EtOH·0.5DMF}n (2), {[(Zn)0.5(L)0.5(py)0.5]·5/2DMF·EtOH}n (3), and [Zn(L)(HNMe2)]n (4). With Pb(NO3)2 the ligand affords two polymers, {[Pb2(L)1.5(O)0.5]·EtOH·2H2O}n (5) and {[Pb3(L)3(H2O)]·6H2O}n (6). All of these compds. were characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TG, elemental anal., and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. Topol. analyses reveal that complex 2 is a 6-connected pcu net, while complexes 3 and 4 are simplified as a 4-connected sql net. In the case of complexes 1 and 6, 1-dimensional rod-shaped metal carboxylate based secondary building units were obtained. However, an uncommon structure and topol. were obtained in complex 5. Surprisingly, such type of parallel ladder-like packing is not explored much in coordination polymers. Solid-state photoluminescence studies were carried out for all of the complexes upon excitation at 347 nm at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXlvVyrsbo%253D&md5=fadfaf4cdc321263e04e4a22b3f1d6c5

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

        Fluorescence Detection of Anilines and Photocatalytic Degradation of Rhodamine B by a Multifunctional Metal-Organic Framework
        Wang, Fengqin; Dong, Caifu; Wang, Zechuan; Cui, Yaru; Wang, Chengmiao; Zhao, Yongnan; Li, Guodong
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (36), 6239-6245CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A multifunctional transition metal CdII coordination polymer based on an amide-inserted flexible multicarboxylate ligand, bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)terephthalamide (H4L), [CdL]·[+H2N(CH3)2] (DMF)(H2O)3 (MOF1) was synthesized by the solvothermal method. Its structure was detd. by single-crystal X-ray diffraction anal. and it was characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy and TGA. MOF1 shows selective sensitivity to detecting aniline pollutants in both aq. media and as vapors due to its strong fluorescence emission and microporous structure. In addn., the visible-light-driven photocatalytic degrdn. of Rhodamine B (RhB) by MOF1 and polyaniline (PANI) composite material (named PANI/MOF1), which was prepd. by loading PANI onto the surface of MOF1, was also studied. The results obtained illustrate that PANI/MOF1 exhibits improved photocatalytic activity over MOF1, which could be used to effectively treat wastewater contg. org. dyes in the future.

        Selective adsorption and degradation of Rhodamine B with modified titanium dioxide photocatalyst
        Bao, Lanlan; Meng, Minjia; Sun, Kaiyong; Li, Weibing; Zhao, Dexiang; Li, Huaming; He, Minqiang
        Journal of Applied Polymer Science (2014), 131 (20), 40890/1-40890/12CODEN: JAPNAB; ISSN:0021-8995. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        A new highly selective photocatalyst (RhB-MIP/TiO2) was prepd. by surface mol. imprinting technique using Rhodamine B (RhB) as the template mol. The adsorption kinetics show RhB-MIP/TiO2 possessed fast adsorption rate, and adsorption behavior followed the pseudo-2nd-order kinetics. The static binding expts. revealed RhB-MIP/TiO2 displayed strong affinity and high adsorption capacity for RhB. The equil. adsorption rate of RhB-MIP/TiO2 for RhB can be well fitted by the Langmuir isotherm model. The thermodn. parameters indicated that the binding system of RhB-MIP/TiO2 was endothermic and spontaneous. Compared with non-imprinted photocatalyst (NIP/TiO2), RhB-MIP/TiO2 exhibited excellent selectivity toward RhB, whose selectivity coeff. for RhB relative to rhodamine 6G (Rh6G) was 2.99. Selective photocatalytic degrdn. expts. indicated that the apparent rate const. for the photodegrdn. of RhB over RhB-MIP/TiO2 is 0.0212/min, being 216% of that over NIP/TiO2 (0.0098/min). Therefore, RhB-MIP/TiO2 exhibited higher photocatalytic selectivity toward RhB. The prepd. photocatalyst RhB-MIP/TiO2 has a promising perspective in industrial wastewater treatment. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Appl. Polym. Sci. 2014, 131, 40890.

        Reactivity and Operational Stability of N-Tailed TAMLs through Kinetic Studies of the Catalyzed Oxidation of Orange II by H2O2: Synthesis and X-ray Structure of an N-Phenyl TAML
        Warner, Genoa R.; Mills, Matthew R.; Enslin, Clarissa; Pattanayak, Shantanu; Panda, Chakadola; Panda, Tamas Kumar; Sen Gupta, Sayam; Ryabov, Alexander D.; Collins, Terrence J.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (16), 6226-6233CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The catalytic activity of the N-tailed (biuret) TAML (tetraamido macrocyclic ligand) activators [Fe{4-XC6H3-1,2-(NCOCMe2NCO)2NR}Cl]2- (3; N atoms in boldface are coordinated to the central iron atom; the same nomenclature is used in for compds. 1 and 2 below), [X, R=H, Me (a); NO2, Me (b); H, Ph (c)] in the oxidative bleaching of Orange II dye by H2O2 in aq. soln. is mechanistically compared with the previously studied activator [Fe{4-XC6H3-1,2-(NCOCMe2NCO)2CMe2}OH2]- (1) and the more aggressive analog [Fe(Me2C{CON(1,2-C6H3-4-X)NCO}2)OH2]- (2). Catalysis by 3 of the reaction between H2O2 and Orange II (S) occurs according to the rate law found generally for TAML activators (v =kIkII[FeIII][S][H2O2]/(kI[H2O2]+kII[S])) and the rate consts. kI and kII at pH 7 both decrease within the series 3 b>3 a>3 c. The pH dependency of kI and kII was studied for 3 a. As with all TAML activators studied to-date, bell-shaped profiles were found for both rate consts. For kI, the maximal activity was found at pH 10.7 marking it as having similar reactivity to 1 a. For kII, the broad bell pH profile exhibits a max. at pH about 10.5. The condition kI«kII holds across the entire pH range studied. Activator 3 b exhibits pronounced activity in neutral to slightly basic aq. solns. making it worthy of consideration on a tech. performance basis for water treatment. The rate consts. ki for suicidal inactivation of the active forms of complexes 3 a-c were calcd. using the general formula ln([S0]/[S∞])=(kII/ki)[FeIII]; here [FeIII], [S0], and [S∞] are the total catalyst concn. and substrate concn. at time zero and infinity, resp. The synthesis and x-ray characterization of 3 c are also described.

        UV-Light-Driven Photocatalysts of Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Acylamide-Inserted Multi-Carboxylic Acid
        Wang, Chengmiao; Wang, Fengqin; Dong, Caifu; Yu, Zongchao; Wang, Zechuan; Zhao, Yongnan; Li, Guodong
        Zeitschrift fuer Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie (2015), 641 (6), 1125-1129CODEN: ZAACAB; ISSN:1521-3749. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two functional metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), [Zn·L]·[+H2N(CH3)2]2(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (1) and [Cu2L(H2O)2]·xG (G = solvent mol.) (2) [H4L = bis(3,5-dicarboxypheny1)terephthalamide] were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Their photoresponses in the UV region make them promising candidates for photodegrdn. of Rhodamine B (RhB) under UV light irradation. We studied the photocatalytic activities of the two MOFs and polyaniline (PANI) composite materials (named PANI/MOFs), which were prepd. by loading the PANI on the surface of MOFs. The results indicate that PANI/MOFs composite materials exbibit excellent photostabilities and higher photocatalytic activities than the pure MOFs photocatalysts for degrdn./removal of org. pollutants from wastewaters.

        Nanoscaled Bismuth Oxido Clusters: Probing Factors of Structure Formation and Photocatalytic Activity
        Schlesinger, Maik; Weber, Marcus; Rueffer, Tobias; Lang, Heinrich; Mehring, Michael
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (2), 302-309CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Hydrolysis of bismuth(III) nitrate in the presence of sodium benzoate (NaOBz) in DMSO gave the bismuth oxido cluster [{Bi38O45(NO3)20(OBz)4(DMSO)24}·4DMSO][{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)26}·4DMSO] (1), which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with a 35.8728(12), b 20.2750(5), c 34.8624(11) Å, and β 111.797(4)°. The asym. unit contains two crystallog. independent bismuth oxido clusters of different compn. Because of the distinct structural relation of this type of bismuth oxido clusters with the photocatalytically active polymorph β-Bi2O3, colloidal suspensions of nanoscaled 1 as well as colloids composed of the recently reported clusters [Bi6O4(OH)4(NO3)6]·H2O (2), [{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)26}·2DMSO][{Bi38O45(NO3)24(DMSO)24}·0.5DMSO] (3), and [Bi38O45(OMc)24(DMSO)9]·2DMSO·7H2O (4; OMc = methacrylate) were probed for their photocatalytic activity. The bismuth oxido cluster 3 decomps. >85% of a 1 × 10-5M aq. soln. of rhodamine B (RhB) under visible-light irradn. within 150 min. Colloids of such clusters might serve as model compds. for indirect photodegrdn. processes of org. contaminants at the metal oxide surface.
