        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30a
        Magnetic iron/carbon nanorods derived from a metal organic framework as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the chemical oxidation process in water
        Andrew Lin, Kun-Yi; Hsu, Fu-Kong
        RSC Advances (2015), 5 (63), 50790-50800CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        By one-step carbonization, metal org. frameworks (MOFs) can be conveniently turned into hierarchical hybrid materials which exhibit versatile functionalities. Even though theor. all MOFs can be carbonized to yield carbon-based hybrids, iron-based MOFs seem to be suitable precursors owing to the abundance and low-toxicity of iron. While many iron-based MOFs have been developed, most of these MOFs are synthesized using DMF, a carcinogenic solvent. Thus, an iron-based MOF, MIL-88A, appears to be an ideal precursor because it can be prepd. just in water. MIL-88A-derived carbonaceous material consists of iron oxide nanoparticles and porous carbon, making it a magnetic porous support/adsorbent. However, its iron content and porosity in fact can enable it to be a promising heterogeneous and magnetic catalyst for chem. oxidn., which, however, has not been investigated. Herein, MIL-88A was used to prep. a magnetic iron/carbon nanorod (MICN). The MICN was characterized and then evaluated as a heterogeneous catalyst to activate oxidants, including hydrogen peroxide and sodium persulfate to decolorize Rhodamine B (RB) dye in water. While RB could not be removed via the adsorption to MICN, and degrdn. by oxidants, the combination of MICN and oxidants successfully decolorized RB owing to the iron content of MICN which activated peroxide and persulfate through a Fenton-like reaction. In addn., MICN loading was found to be a more crit. factor than the oxidant dosage for RB decolorization. Elevated temp. also improved the RB decolorization, whereas basic conditions were not favorable for MICN-activated oxidative processes. Ultrasonication represented a useful external facilitator to enhance the decolorization while the addn. of ascorbic acid greatly inhibited the activation process. The recyclability of MICN was also demonstrated, showing that MICN could be reused for multiple cycles without regeneration treatment. These features enable MICN to be an effective and easy-to-recover chem. oxidative catalyst.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXpsV2nsbw%253D&md5=2f2a6bbb4e13571574004a745a369481
        (b) Chen, Y.; Yao, Z.; Miras, H. N.; Song, Y.-F. Chem. - Eur. J. 2015, 21, 10812– 10820 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201501214
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30b
        Modular Polyoxometalate-Layered Double Hydroxide Composites as Efficient Oxidative Catalysts
        Chen, Yang; Yao, Zhixiao; Miras, Haralampos N.; Song, Yu-Fei
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (30), 10812-10820CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The exploitation of intercalation techniques in the field of two-dimensional layered materials offers unique opportunities for controlling chem. reactions in confined spaces and developing nanocomposites with desired functionality. In this study, the exploitation of the novel and facile "one-pot" anion-exchange method for the functionalization of layered double hydroxides (LDHs) is demonstrated. As a proof-of-concept, we demonstrate the intercalation of a series of polyoxometalate (POM) clusters, Na3[PW12O40].15 H2O (Na3PW12), K6[P2W18O62].14 H2O (K6P2W18), and Na9LaW10O36.32 H2O (Na9LaW10) into tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (Tris)-modified layered double hydroxides (LDHs) under ambient conditions without the necessity of degassing CO2. Investigation of the resultant intercalated materials of Tris-LDHs-PW12 (1), Tris-LDH-P2W18 (2), and Tris-LDH-LaW10 (3) for the degrdn. of methylene blue (MB), rhodamine B (RB) and crystal violet (CV) has been carried out, where Tris-LDH-PW12 reveals the best performance in the presence of H2O2. Addnl., degrdn. of a mixt. of RB, MB and CV by Tris-LDH-PW12 follows the order of CV>MB>RB, which is directly related to the designed accessible area of the interlayer space. Also, the composite can be readily recycled and reused at least ten cycles without measurable decrease of activity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        30c
        Removal of Anionic Dyes from Water by Potash Alum Doped Polyaniline: Investigation of Kinetics and Thermodynamic Parameters of Adsorption
        Patra, Braja N.; Majhi, Deola
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2015), 119 (25), 8154-8164CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
        Polyaniline was synthesized by the oxidative polymn. method by using ammonium persulfate as an oxidant. The pos. charge in the backbone of the polymer was generated by using Potash alum as a dopant. SEM, Fourier transform IR (FTIR), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques were used for characterization of doped polyaniline. The doped polyaniline can be used for selective adsorption of various dyes (selectively sulfonated dyes) from aq. soln. Adsorption studies regarding the effect of contact time, initial dye concn., pH, doses of adsorbent, and temp. on adsorption kinetics were investigated. The influence of other anions like Cl-, NO3-, and SO42- on the adsorption d. of dyes onto doped polyaniline was also explored. Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetics were found to be the most appropriate models to describe the removal of anionic dyes from water through adsorption. Thermodn. parameters such as free energy (ΔG0), enthalpy (ΔH0), and entropy (ΔS0) changes were also evaluated. The interaction of dyes with doped polyaniline was also investigated by FTIR and UV spectroscopy.

        Facile Fabrication of Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 Type II Heterostructures with High Visible Photocatalytic Activity
        Peng, Yin; Yu, Pian-Pian; Chen, Qing-Guo; Zhou, Hai-Yan; Xu, An-Wu
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (23), 13032-13040CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        One-dimensional (1D) Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 type II heterostructures were synthesized by calcining BiOBr/Bi(OHC2O4)·2H2O heterostructures in air at 400 °C. The photocatalytic activity of the as-prepd. products was evaluated by the degrdn. of phenol and Rhodamine B (RhB) under visible light irradn. The Bi12O17Br2/Bi24O31Br10 hierarchical heterostructures show enhanced visible light catalytic activity with the increase of the loaded/Bi24O31Br10 content, which results from the efficient sepn. of photogenerated charge carriers due to the staggered band potentials of the two materials. Radical scavenger expts. confirm that photogenerated holes (h+) are the main active species for oxidizing RhB mols. during the photocatalytic processes.

        30e
        Supramolecular Fluorescent Nanoparticles Constructed via Multiple Non-Covalent Interactions for the Detection of Hydrogen Peroxide in Cancer Cells
        Wei, Xuan; Dong, Ruijiao; Wang, Dali; Zhao, Tianyu; Gao, Yongsheng; Duffy, Patrick; Zhu, Xinyuan; Wang, Wenxin
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (32), 11427-11434CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Overabundance of hydrogen peroxide originating from environmental stress and/or genetic mutation can lead to pathol. conditions. Thus, the highly sensitive detection of H2O2 is important. Herein, supramol. fluorescent nanoparticles self-assembled from fluorescein isothiocyanate modified β-cyclodextrin (FITC-β-CD)/rhodamine B modified ferrocene (Fc-RB) amphiphile were prepd. through host-guest interaction between FITC-β-CD host and Fc-RB guest for H2O2 detection in cancer cells. The self-assembled nanoparticles based on a combination of multiple noncovalent interactions in aq. medium showed high sensitivity to H2O2 while maintaining stability under physiol. condition. Owing to the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) effect, addn. of H2O2 led to obvious fluorescence change of nanoparticles from red (RB) to green (FITC) in fluorescent expts. In vitro study showed the fluorescent nanoparticles could be efficiently internalized by cancer cells and then disrupted by endogenous H2O2, accompanying with FRET from "on" to "off". These supramol. fluorescent nanoparticles constructed via multiple noncovalent interactions are expected to have potential applications in diagnosis and imaging of diseases caused by oxidative stresses.

        30f
        Assembly of a basket-like {Sr ⊂ P6Mo18O73} cage from 0D dimer to 2D network and its photo-/electro-catalytic properties
        Zhang, He; Lv, Jing-hua; Yu, Kai; Wang, Chun-mei; Wang, Chun-xiao; Sun, Di; Zhou, Bai-bin
        Dalton Transactions (2015), 44 (28), 12839-12851CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Basket-like heteropoly blues, formulated as (H4bth)[{Cu(H2O)}2{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·4H2O (1), {H2bih}3[{FeII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (2), (H2bih)3[{CoII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (3), (H2bih)3[{NiII(H2O)2}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·2H2O (4), (H2bih)2(H2bip)[{Zn (H2O)0.5}{Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73}]·5.5H2O (5), (bth = 1,6-bis(triazolyl)hexane; bih = 1,6-bis(imidazolyl)hexane; bip = 1,5-bis(imidazolyl)pentane) were synthesized hydrothermally and fully characterized. The structural anal. shows that all the compds. contain two electron reduced polyanions [Sr ⊂ P6MoV2MoVI16O73]8- (abbreviated as {P6Mo18O73}), which consists of a tetra vacant γ-Dawson-type{P2Mo14} unit and a handle-shaped {P4Mo4} segment encapsulating a Sr2+ cation in the central cavity. Compd. 1 is a 6-connected two-dimensional (2D) layer, which represents the first 2D assembly of basket-type polyoxometalates. Compds. 2-4 are isostructural one-dimensional zigzag chains linked by an M(H2O)2 linker (M = iron for 2, cobalt for 3, and nickel for 4). Compd. 5 is a dimeric cluster supported by a binuclear {Zn2(H2O)} unit. The optical band gaps of 1-5 reveal their semiconductive natures. The compds. if used as photocatalysts exhibit a universal high efficiency degrdn. ability for dyes such as methylene blue, Rhodamine B, and Azophloxine. The lifetime and reaction mechanism of the catalysts were investigated with expts. The compds. also show good bifunctional electrocatalytic behavior for the oxidn. of ascorbic acid (AA) and redn. of nitrite ions.

        Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Materials Based on Basket-like {Ca⊂P6Mo18O73} Cages
        Zhang, He; Yu, Kai; Lv, Jing-hua; Gong, Li-hong; Wang, Chun-mei; Wang, Chun-xiao; Sun, Di; Zhou, Bai-Bin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (14), 6744-6757CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Four basket-like org.-inorg. hybrids, formulated as [{CuII(H2O)2}{Ca4(H2O)4(HO0.5)3(en)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV4Mo14VIO73}]·7H2O (1), (H4bth)[{FeII(H2O)}{Ca⊂P6Mo18VIO73}]·4H2O (2), (H2bih)3[{CuII(H2O)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV2Mo16VIO73}]·2H2O (3), (H2bib)3[{FeII(H2O)2}{Ca⊂P6MoV2 Mo16VIO73}]·4H2O (4), (bth = 1,6-bis(triazole)hexane; bih = 1,6-bis(imidazol)hexane; bib = 1,4-bis(imidazole)butane) were hydrothermally synthesized and fully characterized. Compds. 1-4 contain polyoxoanion [Ca⊂P6MoVnMo18-nVIO73](6+n)- (n = 0, 2, or 4) (abbreviated as {P6Mo18O73}) as a basic building block, which is composed of a basket body {P2Mo14} unit and a handle-like {P4Mo4} fragment encasing an alk.-earth metal Ca2+ cation in the cage. Compd. 1 exhibits an infrequent 2-dimensional layer structure linked by the Cu(H2O)2 linker and an uncommon tetranuclear Ca complex, while compd. 2 is 8-connected 2-dimensional layers connected by binuclear {Fe2(H2O)3} segments, which are obsd. for the first time as 2-dimensional basket-like assemblies. Compds. 3 and 4 are similar 1-dimensional Z-type chains bonded by M(H2O)2 units (M = Cu for 3 and Fe for 4). The optical band gaps of 1-4 reveal their semiconductive natures. They exhibit universal highly efficient degrdn. ability for typical dyes such as methylene blue, Methyl orange, and rhodamine B under UV light. The lifetime and catalysis mechanism of the catalysts were studied. The compds. also show good bifunctional electrocatalytic behavior for oxidn. of amino acids and redn. of NO2-.

        (a) Canivet, J.; Fateeva, A.; Guo, Y.; Coasne, B.; Farrusseng, D. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2014, 43 (16) 5594– 5617 DOI: 10.1039/C4CS00078A

        31a
        Water adsorption in MOFs: fundamentals and applications
        Canivet, Jerome; Fateeva, Alexandra; Guo, Youmin; Coasne, Benoit; Farrusseng, David
        Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5594-5617CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This review article presents the fundamental and practical aspects of water adsorption in Metal-Org. Frameworks (MOFs). The state of the art of MOF stability in water, a crucial issue to many applications in which MOFs are promising candidates, is discussed here. Stability in both gaseous (such as humid gases) and aq. media is considered. By considering a non-exhaustive yet representative set of MOFs, the different mechanisms of water adsorption in this class of materials are presented: reversible and continuous pore filling, irreversible and discontinuous pore filling through capillary condensation, and irreversibility arising from the flexibility and possible structural modifications of the host material. Water adsorption properties of more than 60 MOF samples are reported. The applications of MOFs as materials for heat-pumps and adsorbent-based chillers and proton conductors are also reviewed. Some directions for future work are suggested as concluding remarks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Slu7bO&md5=28aa081a483b68086bf3e93369d02a11
        (b) Feng, D.; Gu, Z.-Y.; Li, J.-R.; Jiang, H.-L.; Wei, Z.; Zhou, H.-C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2012, 51 (41) 10307– 10310 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201204475
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Zirconium-Metalloporphyrin PCN-222: Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Ultrahigh Stability as Biomimetic Catalysts
        Feng, Dawei; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Li, Jian-Rong; Jiang, Hai-Long; Wei, Zhangwen; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2012), 51 (41), 10307-10310, S10307/1-S10307/46CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Zirconium-metalloporphyrin PCN-222 mesoporous metal-org. frameworks with ultrahigh stability as biomimetic catalysts are discussed.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1aqtLvK&md5=1f53cd17d6e9bf7e130b29acdafc98cb
        (c) Jasuja, H.; Burtch, N. C.; Huang, Y.-g.; Cai, Y.; Walton, K. S. Langmuir 2013, 29 (2) 633– 642 DOI: 10.1021/la304204k

        31c
        Kinetic Water Stability of an Isostructural Family of Zinc-Based Pillared Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Jasuja, Himanshu; Burtch, Nicholas C.; Huang, You-gui; Cai, Yang; Walton, Krista S.
        Langmuir (2013), 29 (2), 633-642CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        The rational design of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with structural stability in the presence of humid conditions is crit. to the commercialization of this class of materials. However, the systematic water stability studies required to develop design criteria for the construction of water-stable MOFs are still scarce. In this work, the authors show that by varying the functional groups on the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) linker of DMOF [Zn(BDC)(DABCO)0.5], they can systematically tune the kinetic water stability of this isostructural, pillared family of MOFs. To illustrate this concept, water adsorption studies were performed on four novel, methyl-functionalized DMOF variations along with a no. of already reported functionalized analogs contg. polar (fluorine) and nonpolar (methyl) functional groups on the BDC ligand. These results are distinctly different from previous reports where the apparent water stability is improved through the inclusion of functional groups such as -CH3, -C2H5, and -CF3 which only serve to prevent significant amts. of water from adsorbing into the pores. In this study, the authors present the first demonstration of tuning the inherent kinetic stability of MOF structures in the presence of large amts. of adsorbed water. Notably, while the parent DMOF structure is unstable, the DMOF variation contg. the tetra-Me BDC ligand remains fully stable after adsorbing large amts. of water vapor during cyclic water adsorption cycles. These trends cannot be rationalized in terms of hydrophobicity alone; exptl. water isotherms show that MOFs contg. the same no. of Me groups per unit cell will have different kinetic stabilities and that the precise placements of the Me groups on the BDC ligand are therefore critically important in detg. their stability in the presence of water. Water adsorption isotherms, PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction) patterns, and BET surface areas before and after water exposure are presented to illustrate these trends. Furthermore, the important distinction between kinetic and thermodn. stability in MOFs is discussed. Mol. simulations are also used to provide insight into the structural characteristics governing these trends in kinetic water stability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslyltLbK&md5=dd3cb8bf8450c769ce9f5856751aedab
        (d) Mondloch, J. E.; Katz, M. J.; Planas, N.; Semrouni, D.; Gagliardi, L.; Hupp, J. T.; Farha, O. K. Chem. Commun. 2014, 50 (64) 8944– 8946 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC02401J
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Are Zr6-based MOFs water stable? Linker hydrolysis vs. capillary-force-driven channel collapse
        Mondloch, Joseph E.; Katz, Michael J.; Planas, Nora; Semrouni, David; Gagliardi, Laura; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (64), 8944-8946CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two Zr6-based frameworks, UiO-67 and NU-1000, are shown to be stable towards linker hydrolysis in water, but collapse during activation from water. This framework collapse can be overcome by utilizing solvent exchange to solvents exhibiting lower capillary forces such as acetone.

        Identification and determination of 34 water-soluble synthetic dyes in foodstuff by high performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection-ion trap time-of-flight tandem mass spectrometry
        Li, Xiu Qin; Zhang, Qing He; Ma, Kang; Li, Hong Mei; Guo, Zhen
        Food Chemistry (2015), 182 (), 316-326CODEN: FOCHDJ; ISSN:0308-8146. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        An accurate method combining high performance liq. chromatog. (HPLC) with diode array detection (DAD) and ion-trap time-of-flight mass spectrometry (IT-TOF/MS) was developed for simultaneous identification and quantification of 34 water-sol. synthetic dyes in foodstuff. Fragmentation patterns of synthetic dyes were proposed based on IT-TOF/MS. The mol. ion [M+H]+ was not obsd. in the conventional single-stage mass spectra for most of synthetic dyes. The single-stage mass spectra of synthetic dyes all afforded the diagnostic ions [(M-nNa+nH)+H]+ or [(M-nNa+nH)-H]- in the pos. or neg. mode. Doubly charged ions were the characteristic ions of azo dyes. An HPLC-DAD method was developed to analyze 34 synthetic dyes in foodstuffs. The limits of detection (LOD) for the dyes were 0.01-0.05 μg/mL. The recoveries were between 76.1% and 105.0% with a RSD ranging from 1.4% to 6.4%. This method was successfully applied to analyzing the 34 water-sol. synthetic dyes in 21 com. foods.

        (a) Inchaurrondo, N.; Font, J.; Ramos, C. P.; Haure, P. Appl. Catal., B 2016, 181, 481– 494 DOI: 10.1016/j.apcatb.2015.08.022
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33a
        Natural diatomites: Efficient green catalyst for Fenton-like oxidation of Orange II
        Inchaurrondo, N.; Font, J.; Ramos, C. P.; Haure, P.
        Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental (2016), 181 (), 481-494CODEN: ACBEE3; ISSN:0926-3373. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The Fenton-like oxidn. of the anionic azo-dye Orange II (100-500 mg/L) was batchwise performed using com. grade diatomites (3.5% Fe content) thermally treated. Solid samples were thoroughly characterized by several techniques. Peroxidn. expts. were performed varying the diatomite calcination temp. (500, 700, 1000°), reaction temp. (50, 60, 70, 80°), catalyst load (0.47, 0.94, 1.89 and 3.78 g), H2O2 concn. (11.0, 13.7, 20.6 mmol/L) and dosing, pH (2-3.5) and initial dye concn. (0.28, 0.57, 1.43 mmol/L). The effect of NaCl and oxalic acid on the catalytic performance and stability was also addressed. The best results were obtained with samples calcined at 700°, with initial pH 3, at 70° and using the stoichiometric amt. of H2O2, since complete decolorization, TOC redn. close to 67% and negligible Fe leaching were achieved. The stability of the catalyst maintains after 20 h of usage, with a final Fe loss of 2.25%. An av. of 0.88 mg/L Fe leached after each run, which is below the discharge limit.

        (b) Le, T. X. H.; Bechelany, M.; Lacour, S.; Oturan, N.; Oturan, M. A.; Cretin, M. Carbon 2015, 94, 1003– 1011 DOI: 10.1016/j.carbon.2015.07.086

        33b
        High removal efficiency of dye pollutants by electron-Fenton process using a graphene based cathode
        Le, Thi Xuan Huong; Bechelany, Mikhael; Lacour, Stella; Oturan, Nihal; Oturan, Mehmet A.; Cretin, Marc
        Carbon (2015), 94 (), 1003-1011CODEN: CRBNAH; ISSN:0008-6223. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A new cathode for electro-Fenton process was set up by electrochem. deposition of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) on the surface of C felt (CF). The structure and properties of modified electrode was studied. Among the different redn. methods used, the const. potential technique demonstrated significant advantages. The parameters affecting the conversion of GO to rGO, such as pH, applied potential and duration of the redn. process, were examd. The rGO modified cathode presents enhanced electrochem. properties like an increase of the redox current and a decrease of the charge transfer resistance in presence of the redox probe [Fe(CN)6]3-/[Fe(CN)6]4- showing better kinetic properties compared to raw CF. This improvement enhanced significantly the prodn. of H2O2, a key parameter in electro-Fenton (EF) process, which was confirmed by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) anal. Therefore, the use of graphene modified cathode could decolorize efficiently Acid Orange 7, a model azo dye mol., within only 5 min and almost completely mineralized (94.3%) it in 8 h treatment under optimal c.d. applied. The new cathode exhibited good stability as the mineralization ratio in 2 h that was still >64% after 10 cycles degrdn., showing that this rGO-CF is a powerful and promising electrode for improving the removal efficiency of dyes using EF technol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1Omtr7I&md5=97e9d6dcdf60054eb842a7c4dd00a530
      34. 34
        (a) Jiang, T.; Poyraz, A. S.; Iyer, A.; Zhang, Y.; Luo, Z.; Zhong, W.; Miao, R.; El-Sawy, A. M.; Guild, C. J.; Sun, Y.; Kriz, D. A.; Suib, S. L. J. Phys. Chem. C 2015, 119 (19) 10454– 10468 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b02057
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34a
        Synthesis of Mesoporous Iron Oxides by an Inverse Micelle Method and Their Application in the Degradation of Orange II under Visible Light at Neutral pH
        Jiang, Ting; Poyraz, Altug S.; Iyer, Aparna; Zhang, Yashan; Luo, Zhu; Zhong, Wei; Miao, Ran; El-Sawy, Abdelhamid M.; Guild, Curtis J.; Sun, Yu; Kriz, David A.; Suib, Steven L.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (19), 10454-10468CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Mesoporous iron oxides (2-line ferrihydrite, α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3, and Fe3O4) are successfully synthesized by modifying the reaction temps. and calcination atmospheres of the sol-gel-based inverse micelle method. Different characterization techniques, such as PXRD, N2 sorption, SEM, HRTEM, Raman spectroscopy, and XANES, are performed to det. the properties of the catalysts. Larger pore sizes can be obtained in mesoporous γ-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 compared with mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite and α-Fe2O3. The catalytic performance of mesoporous iron oxides are examd. as Fenton catalysts in orange II degrdn. in the presence of oxidant H2O2 at neutral pH under visible light. Adsorption capacities of mesoporous iron oxides on orange II are greater than that of com. Fe2O3. The greatest adsorption capacity is found to be 49.3 mg/g with mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite. In addn., the degrdn. efficiency of orange II is found to be markedly improved by mesoporous iron oxides compared with the com. catalyst. In the best case scenario, 2-line ferrihydrite shows the highest degrdn. rate const. (0.0258 min-1) among all the catalysts tested. The excellent performance of 2-line ferrihydrite is mainly attributed to the larger surface area but also related to surface hydroxyl groups, acidic products, and possible addnl. adsorption sites. The recyclability of mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite catalyst can be achieved up to 3 times without performance decay. At last, a discussion regarding the possible mechanisms of degrdn. of orange II over mesoporous 2-line ferrihydrite is proposed, based on the previous literature work and the obsd. reaction intermediates monitored by ESI/MS in this study.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXntVCgtro%253D&md5=c4210a226497191b8c8fb43718f68738
        (b) Su, Y.; Wu, Z.; Wu, Y.; Yu, J.; Sun, L.; Lin, C. J. Mater. Chem. A 2015, 3 (16) 8537– 8544 DOI: 10.1039/C5TA00839E
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34b
        Acid Orange II degradation through a heterogeneous Fenton-like reaction using Fe-TiO2 nanotube arrays as a photocatalyst
        Su, Yufeng; Wu, Zhi; Wu, Yongneng; Yu, Jiangdong; Sun, Lan; Lin, Changjian
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2015), 3 (16), 8537-8544CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The photocatalytic degrdn. of the non-biodegradable azo dye Acid Orange II (AO II) was performed via a heterogeneous Fenton-like process using Fe incorporated TiO2 nanotube arrays (Fe-TiO2 NTAs) as a photocatalyst in the presence of H2O2 under UV irradn. Fe-TiO2 NTAs were prepd. by an ultrasound-assisted impregnating-calcination method. The effects of reaction conditions including the amt. of Fe incorporated into TiO2 NTAs, initial concn. of H2O2, and initial pH of the AO II soln. on the photocatalytic degrdn. rate of AO II were investigated. The results revealed that the Fe-TiO2 NTAs prepd. by ultrasonic deposition for 25 min exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity compared with pure TiO2 NTA and other Fe-TiO2 NTA samples. In the presence of H2O2, the photocatalytic degrdn. rate of AO II was significantly enhanced. About 80% AO II can be decompd. at pH 2.96 using Fe-TiO2 NTAs prepd. by ultrasonic deposition for 25 min as a photocatalyst with 3mM H2O2 after 120 min of UV irradn., which was 1.7 times higher than that without H2O2 (∼30%). Very interestingly, there was an obvious synergistic effect between the photocatalytic process of Fe-TiO2 NTAs and H2O2 oxidn. The Fe-TiO2 NTA photocatalyst exhibited excellent stability in the heterogeneous Fenton-like process. Thus, we demonstrated that the heterogeneous Fenton-like process combining the Fe-TiO2 NTA photocatalyst with H2O2 oxidn. has a promising application in practical wastewater treatment.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlt1agurY%253D&md5=870957f44ab9e60e1c92233e76770a00
        (c) Yao, Y.; Lu, F.; Zhu, Y.; Wei, F.; Liu, X.; Lian, C.; Wang, S. J. Hazard. Mater. 2015, 297, 224– 233 DOI: 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2015.04.046
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34c
        Magnetic core-shell CuFe2O4@C3N4 hybrids for visible light photocatalysis of Orange II
        Yao, Yunjin; Lu, Fang; Chen, Hao; Wei, Fengyu; Liu, Xueting; Lian, Chao; Wang, Shaobin
        Journal of Hazardous Materials (2015), 297 (), 224-233CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Novel CuFe2O4@C3N4 core-shell photocatalysts were fabricated through a self-assembly method and characterized by x-ray diffraction, FTIR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric anal., XPS, transmission electron microscopy and Uv-vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy. The photocatalytic performances of the CuFe2O4@C3N4 catalysts were evaluated in photoFenton-like decolorization of Orange II dye using H2O2 as an oxidant under visible-light irradn. (λ >420 nm). It was found the CuFe2O4@C3N4 hybrid (mass ratio of CuFe2O4/g-C3N4 at 2:1) exhibits a superior activity as compared with single component of CuFe2O4 or g-C3N4 and the mixt. of g-C3N4 and CuFe2O4, due to the elevation of the sepn. efficiency of photoinduced electron-hole pairs, resulted from the heterojunction between the interfaces of g-C3N4 and CuFe2O4. The quenching tests of different scavengers displayed that O2•-, ·OH and h+ are responsible for the Orange II decolorization. The effects of initial concn. of the dye concn. (0.014-0.140mM), different anions (Cl-, SO42-, NO3-, CH3COO- and HCO3-) and temp. (15-65°) in photoreaction were studied. The CuFe2O4@C3N4 sample exhibited stable performance without obvious loss of catalytic activity after 5 successive runs, showing a promising application for the photo-oxidative degrdn. of environmental contaminants.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXmslyhs70%253D&md5=7b68060843c11d3cc46b94d5aed89d0a
      35. 35
        Xing, F.; Jia, J.; Liu, L.; Zhong, L.; Shao, M.; Bai, Y.-l.; Zhao, Y.; Zhu, S.; He, X.; Li, M. CrystEngComm 2013, 15 (24) 4970– 4980 DOI: 10.1039/c3ce40174j
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Synthesis, structure and adsorption of coordination polymers constructed from 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and Zn ions
        Xing, Feifei; Jia, Juan; Liu, Licong; Zhong, Lina; Shao, Min; Bai, Yue-ling; Zhao, Yongmei; Zhu, Shourong; He, Xiang; Li, Mingxing
        CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (24), 4970-4980CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        3,3',5,5'-Azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc) was synthesized by redn. of 5-nitroisophthalic acid in basic aq./ethanol soln. in the presence of Zn powder. Three novel coordination polymers {[Zn2(η6-ao2btc)(η2-2,2'-bpy)2(H2O)2]·2H2O}1n (1), {[Zn2(η8-aobtc)(η2-phen)(H2O)]·DMF}3n (2), and {(Hap)2[Zn3(η9-aobtc)2]·2H2O}3n (3) (2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, ap = 4-aminopyridine, ao2btc4- and aobtc4- are two oxidized forms of H4abtc ligand) were prepd. under hydrothermal conditions. The structures of 1-3 were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Complex 1 is a 1-dimensional chain polymer, while 2 and 3 are porous 3-dimensional metal-org. frameworks with a cavity size of 9 Å diam. and 7 × 15 Å rectangular cavities, resp. In 1, ao2btc4- links four mononuclear ZnO6 chromophores. Ligand aobtc4- in 2 links four dinuclear Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)N2, while aobtc4- in 3 bridges four trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8. From a topol. point of view, ao2btc4- or aobtc4- are all 4-connected linkers in 1-3, while the mononuclear ZnO6 in 1, dinuclear Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)N2 in 2 and trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8 in 3 are 2, 4 and 8 connected nodes, resp. Zn(II) in complex 2 can be replaced by Cu(II), Ni(II) and Co(II) with simultaneous loss of crystallinity. The metal ion exchange rate decrease in the order Co(II) < Ni(II) < Cu(II). Complex 2 can encapsulate iodine (I2) in cyclohexane soln. to form 2∋0.1I2. The encapsulated I2 can be released completely in ethanol. The Hap+ in 3 can be replaced by methylene blue in aq. soln. to form 3∋0.1methylene blue. The insignificant replacement is an indication that the guest mol. in the cavity channel is immobile, which prevents further substitution. With a bis-oxo group in the azo moiety, the framework of 1 is so unstable that it will decomp. at ∼150° with simultaneous release of NO. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable at 330°. IR and fluorescence spectra are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXot1eqtbg%253D&md5=2feaa3220559f52cae878b6f574f9ad5
      36. 36
        Sakaue, S.; Tsubakino, T.; Nishiyama, Y.; Ishii, Y. J. Org. Chem. 1993, 58 (14) 3633– 8 DOI: 10.1021/jo00066a012
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Oxidation of aromatic amines with hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by cetylpyridinium heteropolyoxometalates
        Sakaue, Sigeki; Tsubakino, Takashi; Nishiyama, Yutaka; Ishii, Yasutaka
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1993), 58 (14), 3633-8CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        Various substituted anilines XC6H4NH2 (I, X = H, 4-Me, 4-NO2, 2-CO2Me, etc.) were selectively converted into the corresponding nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N(O):N(O)C6H4X (II) or nitrobenzenes XC6H4NO2 (III) by oxidn. with aq. hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by heteropolyoxometalates. The oxidns. of I with 35% H2O2 catalyzed by peroxotungstophosphate (PCWP) at room temp. in chloroform under two-phase conditions afforded II with high selectivity. When the same reactions were carried out at higher temp. (e.g., refluxing chloroform), III were obtained in good yields. The oxidn. of PhNH2 with dil. H2O2 catalyzed by PCWP (2 wt %) in an aq. medium produced azoxybenzene, PhN(O):NPh with high selectivity. Phenylazoxyalkanes 4-XC6H4N(O):NR (R = Bu, n-hexyl, cyclohexyl, X = H, Me, Cl) were prepd. by the first direct cooxidn. of PhNH2 in the presence of primary aliph. amines RNH2. The reaction path for the conversion of anilines to azoxy-, nitroso-, and nitrobenzenes is described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXltFKrurk%253D&md5=5f0499d88d84afbd6d79003c26bdad8d
      37. 37
        Angeli, A. Atti Accad. Naz. Lincei, Cl. Sci. Fis., Mater. Nat., Rend. 1915, 24 (I) 1185– 1190
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        The oxidation of azoketones and azonitriles
        Angeli, A.
        Atti della Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei, Classe di Scienze Fisiche, Matematiche e Naturali, Rendiconti (1915), 24 (I), 1185-90CODEN: AANLAW; ISSN:0001-4435.
        In order to extend his expts. on the action of peracetic acid on the azo derivs. A. has studied its action on RN:NC6H4Ac, RN:NC6H4CN, RN:NC6H4CH2CN, RN:NC6H4NMe2, RN:NCN, and RN:N:N in which R for the present is an aromatic residue. The results with the ketones and nitriles are reported here. It was found that in order to limit the oxidation to the azo group it was necessary to work in dil. AcOH at not high temps. In this way PhN:NC6H4Ac gives PhN(:O):NC6H4Ac (a), m. 92°, and PhN:N(:O)C6H4Ac (b), m. 132°, and PhN:- NC6H4CH2CN gives PhN(:O)NC6H4CH2CN (C), in. 94°, and PhN:N(:O)C6H4CH2CN (d), m. 132°. Their structure was easily detd. by oxidizing with KMnO4 in alk. soln. by which the side chains were transformed into CO2H and the acids PhN(:O)NC6H4CO2H and PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H were obtained which were identical with those previously obtained by the oxidation of the azo acid (A. and Valori, C. A. 7, 2223). The azoketone, PhN:NC6H4Ac, prepd. by condensing equimol. amts. of PhNO and p-NH2C6H4Ac in AcOH, rose laminas from EtOH, m. 115°; with NH2OH it gives an oxime, PhN2C6H4C(:NOH)Me, m. 169°. The azoketone oxidized in AcOH with perhydrol gave 2 isomeric azoxy compounds that were sepd. by their different soly. in EtOH; the less sol. (b) recrystd. from C6H6 m. 132°; the other (a) purified from ligroin, m. 92°. (b) gave an oxime, m. 181°. (b) oxidized with KMnO4 in the presence of a little KOH gave a yellow liquid which on treatment with dil. H2SO4 sepd. PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H, which for better identification was converted with Br into p-BrC6H4N:N(:O)C6H4CO2H. Both (a) and (b) give on treatment with. H2SO4 p-HOC6H4N2C6H4Ac; red, sol. in alkalies, m. 134°. Similarly condensation of PhNO with p-H2NC6H4Bz gives the azoketone PhN:NC6H4Bz, m. 106°, which with H2O2 gives an azoxy compd., m. 72°. Lack of material prevented a further study. The azonitrile, PhN:NC6H4CH2CN, was obtained by condensing PhNO with p-H2NC6H4CH2CN, as orange-red laminas, m. 127°. Oxidized with H2O2 it gave 2 isomeric azoxy compounds, (c) and (d), that were purified by recrystn. from C6H6. The more sol. one (c) m. 94° and the less sol. one (d) m. 132°. (d) oxidized with KMnO4 gives PhN:N(:O)C6H4CO2H which thus dets. the structure of these isomers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaC28XntVSk&md5=9bf214fa7ed7e43cc014335a4b1cc046

      • Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (deg) for complexes 1–3, photographs of K+ test in 1, IR spectra, PXRD patterns, and thermogravimetric curves of complexes 1–3, UV–vis absorption spectra of dyes in the absence and presence of catalyst, UV–vis spectra at different pH, photographs of 10 mL 100 ppm RhB dye degradation in 0.32 M H2O2 aqueous solution, UV–vis absorption spectra at different concentrations of H2O2 at pH 4.8, plot of – ln(At/A0) vs degradation time for RhB in the presence of 1–3 at different H2O2 concentrations, plot of Kobs vs H2O2 concentration for RhB in the presence of 1–3, degradation efficiencies of 10 mL 8.0 ppm RhB aqueous solution in the absence and presence of 0.32 M H2O2 and 10 mg of 1–3 and at different pH, color changes of 24 ppm orange II in the absence and presence of catalyst in 0.32 M H2O2 in neutral aqueous solution, IR spectra of 1–3 before and after catalysis, and powder XRD pattern of 1–3 before and after catalysis (PDF)
